βασανιζω.definition: pr. to apply the lapis Lydius or touchstone; met. to examine, scrutinize, try, either by words or torture; in NT to afflict, torment; pass. to be afflicted, tormented, pained, by diseases, Mt. 8:6, 29, 35; to be tossed, agitated, as by the waves, Mt. 14:24

βασανισμος.definition: pr. examination by torture; torment, torture, Rev. 9:5; 14:11; 18:7, 10, 15*

βασανιστης.definition: pr. an inquisitor, tormentor; in NT a keeper of a prison, jailer, Mt. 18:34*

βασανος.definition: pr. lapis Lydius, a species of stone from Lydia, which being applied to metals was thought to indicate any alloy which might be mixed with them, and therefore used in the trial of metals; hence, examination of a person, especially by torture; in NT torture, torment, severe pain, Mt. 4:24; Lk. 16:23, 28*

βασιλεια.definition: a kingdom, realm, the region or country governed by a king; kingly power, authority, dominion, reign; royal dignity, the title and honor of king; ἡ βασιλεία, Mt. 9:35, ἡ βασιλεία τοῦ θεοῦ or τοῦ Χριστοῦ or τοῦ οὐρανοῦ or τῶν οὐρανῶν, the reign or kingdom of the Messiah, both in a false and true conception of it; used also with various limitation, of its administration and coming history, as in the parables; its distinctive nature, Rom. 14:17; its requirements, privileges, rewards, consummation

g934.definition: royal, regal; met. possessed of high prerogatives and distinction, 1 Pet. 2:9; τὰ βασίλεια, i.e. δώματα, regal mansion, palaces, Lk. 7:25*

βασιλευς.definition: a king, monarch, one possessing regal authority

βασιλευω.definition: to possess regal authority, be a king, reign; to rule, govern, Mt. 2:22; met. to be in force, predominate, prevail, Rom. 5:14, 17, 21; met. to be in kingly case, fare royally, 1 Cor. 4:8

βασιλικος.definition: royal, regal, Acts 12:20, 21; βασιλικός, used as a subst. a person attached to the king, courtier, Jn. 4:46, 49; met. royal, of the highest excellence, Jas. 2:8*

βασις.definition: pr. a step; the foot, Acts 3:7*

βασκαινω.definition: pr. to slander; thence, to bewitch by spells, or by any other means; to delude, Gal. 3:1*

βασταζω.definition: pr. to lift, raise, bear aloft; to bear, carry in the hands or about the person; carry as a message, Acts 9:15; to take away, remove, Mt. 8:17; Jn. 20:15; to take up, Jn. 10:31; Lk. 14:27; to bear as a burden endure, suffer; to sustain, Rom. 11:18; to bear with, tolerate; to sustain mentally, comprehend, Jn. 16:12

βατος.definition: a bath, a measure for liquids, which is stated by Josephus (Ant. 8.57) to contain seventy-two sextarii, or about thirteen and one half gallons. Others estimate it to be nine gallons; and others, seven and one half gallons, Lk. 16:6*

βατταλογεω.definition: also spelled βαττολογέω, pr. to stammer; hence, to babble; to use vain repetitions, Mt. 6:7*

βδελυγμα.definition: an abomination, an abominable thing, Mt. 24:15; Mk. 13:14; idolatry with all its pollution, Lk. 16:15; Rev. 17:4, 5; 21:27*

βδελυσσομαι.definition: to abominate, loathe, detest, abhor, Rom. 2:22; pass. to be abominable, detestable, Rev. 21:8*

βεβαιος.definition: firm, stable, steadfast, Heb. 3:14; 6:19; sure, certain, established, Rom. 4:16

βεβαιοω.definition: to confirm, establish; to render constant and unwavering, 1 Cor. 1:8; to strengthen or establish by arguments or proofs, ratify, Mk. 16:20; to verify, as promises, Rom. 15:8

βεβηλος.definition: pr. what is open and accessible to all; hence, profane, not religious, not connected with religion; unholy; a despiser, scorner, 1 Tim. 1:9; 4:7

βεβηλοω.definition: to profane, pollute, violate, Mt. 12:5; Acts 24:6*

βεελζεβουλ.definition: variant spellings of Βεελζεβούβ and βεελζεβούλ, Beelzeboul, pr. name, indecl., Mt. 10:25

βελονη.definition: pr. the point of a spear; a needle, Lk. 18:25*

βελος.definition: a missile weapon, dart, arrow, Eph. 6:16*

βελτιων.definition: better; βέλτιον, as an adv., very well, too well to need informing, 2 Tim. 1:18*

βενιαμιν.definition: Benjamin, pr. name, indecl. Acts 13:21; Rom. 11:1; Phil. 3:5; Rev. 7:8*

βεροια.definition: Berea, a town of Macedonia, Acts 17:10, 13*. See PhotoGuide.

βηθανια.definition: Bethany (1) A village near Jerusalem, at the Mount of Olives, Mt. 21:17; Mk. 11:1. (2) A village beyond the Jordan, Jn. 1:28. See PhotoGuide.

βηθλεεμ.definition: Bethlehem, indecl., a town in Palestine. See PhotoGuide.

βηθσαιδα.definition: also spelled Βηθσαϊδάν (G1035) Bethsaida, indecl. (1) A city of Galilee, Mt. 11:21; Mk. 6:45,. (2) A city of Lower Gaulanitis, near the Lake of Gennesareth, Lk. 9:10. See PhotoGuide.

βηθφαγη.definition: Bethphage, indecl., a part of the Mount of Olives, Mt. 21:1; Mk. 11:1; Lk. 19:29*. See PhotoGuide.

βημα.definition: a step, footstep, foot-breadth, space to set the foot on, Acts 7:5; an elevated place ascended by steps, tribunal, throne, Mt. 27:19; Acts 12:21

βηρυλλος.definition: a beryl, a precious stone of a sea-green color, found chiefly in India, Rev. 21:20*

βιαζω.definition: also written as a middle deponent, βιάζομαι, to urge, constrain, overpower by force; to press earnestly forward, to rush, Lk. 16:16; pass. to be an object of a forceful movement, Mt. 11:12*

βιαστης.definition: one who uses violence, or is impetuous; one who is forceful in eager pursuit, Mt. 11:12*

βιβλαριδιον.definition: a small volume or scroll, a little book, Rev. 10:2, 9, 10*

βιβλιον.definition: a written volume or roll, book, Lk. 4:17, 20; a scroll, bill, billet, Mt. 19:7; Mk. 10:4

βιβλος.definition: pr. the inner bark or rind of the papyrus, which was anciently used instead of paper; hence, a written volume or roll, book, catalogue, account, Mt. 1:1; Mk. 12:26

βιθυνια.definition: Bithynia, a province of Asia Minor, Acts 16:7; 1 Pet. 1:1*

βιος.definition: life; means of living; sustenance, maintenance, substance, goods, Mk. 12:44, Lk. 8:14, 43; 15:12, 30; 21:4; 1 Tim. 2:2; 2 Tim. 2:4; 1 Jn. 2:16; 3:17*

βιωτικος.definition: pertaining to this life or the things of this life, Lk. 21:34; 1 Cor. 6:3, 4*

βλαπτω.definition: pr. to weaken, hinder, disable; to hurt, harm, injure, Mk. 16:18; Lk. 4:35*

βλαστανω.definition: also spelled βλαστάω, intrans. to germinate, bud, sprout, spring up, Mt. 13:26; Mk. 4:27; Heb. 9:4; trans. and causative, to cause to shoot, to produce, yield, Jas. 5:18*

βλασφημεω.definition: to defame, revile, slander, Mt. 27:39; to speak of God or divine things in terms of impious irreverence, to blaspheme, Mt. 9:3; 26:65

βλασφημια.definition: slander, railing, reproach, Mt. 15:19; Mk. 7:22; blasphemy, Mt. 12:31; 26:65

βλασφημος.definition: slanderous, railing, reproachful, 2 Tim. 3:2; 2 Pet. 2:11; blasphemous, Acts 6:11, 13; 1 Tim. 1:13

βλεμμα.definition: a look; the act of seeing, sight, 2 Pet. 2:8*

βλεπω.definition: to have the faculty of sight, to see, Mt. 12:22; to exercise sight, to see, Mt. 6:4; to look towards or at, Mt. 22:16; to face, Acts 27:12; to take heed, Mt. 24:4; in NT, βλέπειν ἀπό, to beware of, shun, Mk. 8:15; trans., to cast a look on, Mt. 5:28; to see, behold, Mt. 13:17; to observe, Mt. 7:3; to have an eye to, see to, Mk. 13:9; Col. 4:17; 2 Jn. 8; to discern mentally, perceive, Rom. 7:23; 2 Cor. 7:8; Jas. 2:22; to guard against, Phil. 3:2; pass., to be an object of sight, be visible, Rom. 8:24

βλητεος.definition: requiring to be cast or put, Lk. 5:38*

βοαω.definition: to cry out; to exclaim, proclaim, Mt. 3:3; 15:34; Acts 8:7; πρός τινα, to invoke, implore the aid of any one, Lk. 18:7

βοηθεια.definition: help, succor, Heb. 4:16; meton. pl. helps, contrivances for relief and safety, Acts 27:17*

βοηθεω.definition: to run to the aid of those who cry for help; to advance to the assistance of any one, help, aid, succor, Mt. 15:25; Mk. 9:22, 24

βοθυνος.definition: a pit, well or cistern, Mt. 12:11; 15:14; Lk. 6:39*

βολη.definition: a cast, a throw; the distance to which a thing can be thrown, Lk. 22:41*

βοος.definition: also spelled Βόοζ, Boaz, pr. name, indecl., Lk. 3:32*

βορρας.definition: pr. the north or N.N.E. wind; meton. the north, Lk. 13:29; Rev. 21:13*

βοσκω.definition: to feed, pasture, tend while grazing; βόσκομαι, to feed, be feeding, Mt. 8:30, 33; Lk. 8:32, 34

βοτανη.definition: herb, herbage, produce of the earth, Heb. 6:7*

βοτρυς.definition: a bunch or cluster of grapes, Rev. 14:18*

βουλευτης.definition: a counsellor, senator; member of the Sanhedrin, Mk. 15:43; Lk. 23:50*

βουλευω.definition: mid., to give counsel; to deliberate, Lk. 14:31; Jn. 12:10; 11:53; to purpose, determine, Acts 27:39; 2 Cor. 1:17 (2x)*

βουλη.definition: counsel, purpose, design, determination, decree, Lk. 7:30; 23:51, et al. freq.; by impl. secret thoughts, cogitations of the mind, 1 Cor. 4:5

βουλημα.definition: purpose, will, determination, Acts 27:43; Rom. 9:19; 1 Pet. 4:3*

βουλομαι.definition: to be willing, disposed, Mk. 15:15; Acts 25:20; 28:18; to intend, Mt. 1:19; Acts 5:28; 12:4; 2 Cor. 1:15; to desire, 1 Tim. 6:9; to choose, be pleased, Jn. 18:39; Acts 18:15; Jas. 3:4; to will, decree, appoint, Lk. 22:42; Jas. 1:18; 1 Cor. 12:11; 1 Tim. 2:8; 5:14; ἐβουλόμην, I could wish, Acts 25:22

βους.definition: an ox, a bull or cow, an animal of the ox kind, Lk. 13:15

βραβειον.definition: a prize bestowed on victors in the public games, such as a crown, wreath, chaplet, garland, etc., 1 Cor. 9:24; Phil. 3:14*

βραβευω.definition: pr. to be a director or arbiter in the public games; in NT to preside, direct, rule, govern, be predominate, Col. 3:15*

βραδυνω.definition: to be slow, to delay, 1 Tim. 3:15; 2 Pet. 3:9*

βραδυς.definition: slow, not hasty, Jas. 1:19; slow of understanding, heavy, stupid, Lk. 24:25*

βραχιων.definition: the arm; the arm as a symbol of power, Lk. 1:51; Jn. 12:38; Acts 13:17*

βραχυς.definition: short, brief; few, small, Lk. 22:58; Jn. 6:7; Acts 5:34; 27:28; Heb. 2:7, 9; 13:22*

βρεφος.definition: a child; whether unborn, an embryo, fetus, Lk. 1:41, 44; or just born, an infant, Lk. 2:12, 16; Acts 7:19; or partly grown, Lk. 18:15; 2 Tim. 3:15; met. a babe in simplicity of faith, 1 Pet. 2:2*

βρεχω.definition: to wet, moisten, Lk. 7:38; to rain, cause or send rain, Mt. 5:45; Lk. 17:29

βρυχω.definition: to grate or gnash the teeth, Acts 7:54*

βρυω.definition: pr. to be full, to swell with anything; to emit, send forth, Jas. 3:11*

βρωμα.definition: food, Mt. 14:15; Mk. 7:19; solid food, 1 Cor. 3:2

βρωσιμος.definition: eatable, that may be eaten, Lk. 24:41*

βρωσις.definition: eating, the act of eating, Rom. 14:17; 1 Cor. 8:4; meat, food, Jn. 6:27; Heb. 12:16; a canker or rust, Mt. 6:19, 20

βυθιζω.definition: to immerse, submerge, cause to sink, Lk. 5:7; to plunge deep, drown, 1 Tim. 6:9*

βυθος.definition: the bottom, lowest part; the deep, sea, 2 Cor. 11:25*

βυσσινος.definition: made of fine linen or fine cotton, Rev. 18:16; 18:8 (2x), 14*

βυσσος.definition: byssus, a species of fine cotton highly prized by the ancients, Lk. 16:19*

βωμος.definition: pr. a slightly-elevated spot, base, pedestal; hence, an altar, Acts 17:23*

γαδαρηνος.definition: an inhabitant of Gadara, the chief city of Perea, Mt. 8:28*

γαζοφυλακιον.definition: also spelled γαζοφυλακεῖον, a treasury; the sacred treasure, Mk. 12:41, 43; Lk. 21:1; Jn. 8:20*

γαιος.definition: Gaius, pr. name. (1) Of Macedonia, Acts 19:29. (2) Of Corinth, 1 Cor. 1:14. (3) Of Derbe, Acts 20:4. (4) A Christian to whom John addressed his third Epistle, 3 Jn. 1; Rom. 16:23*

γαλα.definition: milk, 1 Cor. 9:7; met. spiritual milk, consisting in the elements of Christian instruction, 1 Cor. 3:2; Heb. 5:12, 13; spiritual nutriment, 1 Pet. 2:2*

γαλατης.definition: a Galatian, inhabitant of Galatia, Gal. 3:1*

γαλατια.definition: Galatia or Gallo-Graecia, a province of Asia Minor, 1 Cor. 6:1; Gal. 1:2; 2 Tim. 4:10; 1 Pet. 1:1*

γαληνη.definition: tranquillity of the sea, a calm, Mt. 8:26; Mk. 4:39; Lk. 8:24*

γαλιλαια.definition: Galilee, a district of Palestine north of Samaria, Mt. 4:15

γαλιλαιος.definition: a native of Galilee, Mt. 26:69; Mk. 14:70; Lk. 13:1; Jn. 4:45; Acts 1:11

γαμεω.definition: to marry, Mt. 5:32, et al.; absol. to marry, enter the marriage state, Mt. 19:10, et al.; mid. to marry, be married, Mk. 10:12; 1 Cor. 7:39

γαμιζω.definition: also spelled γαμίσκω, to give in marriage, permit to marry, 1 Cor. 7:38

γαμος.definition: a wedding; nuptial festivities, a marriage festival, Mt. 22:2; 25:10; Jn. 2:1, 2; Rev. 19:7, 9; any feast or banquet, Lk. 12:36; 14:8; the marriage state, Heb. 13:4

γαρ.definition: for; it is, however, frequently used with an ellipsis of the clause to which it has reference, and its force must then be variously expressed: Mt. 15:27; 27:23, et al.; it is also sometimes epexegetic, or introductory of an intimated detail of circumstances, now, then, Mt. 1:18

γαστηρ.definition: the belly, stomach; the womb, Lk. 1:31; ἐν γαστρὶ ἔχειν, to be with child, Mt. 1:18, 23; 24:19, et al.; γαστέρες, gluttons, Tit. 1:12

γε.definition: an enclitic particle imparting emphasis; indicating that a particular regard is to be had to the term to which it is attached. Its force is to be conveyed, when this is possible, by various expression; at least, indeed, even

γεεννα.definition: Gehenna, pr. the valley of Hinnom, south of Jerusalem, once celebrated for the horrid worship of Moloch, and afterwards polluted with every species of filth, as well as the carcasses of animals, and dead bodies of malefactors; to consume which, in order to avert the pestilence which such a mass of corruption would occasion, constant fires were kept burning; hence, hell, the fires of Tartarus, the place of punishment in Hades, Mt. 5:22, 29, 30; 10:28; 18:9, et al.

γεθσημανι.definition: Gethsemane, pr. name, indecl., Mt. 26:36; Mk. 14:32*

γελαω.definition: to laugh, smile; by impl. to be merry, happy, to rejoice, Lk. 6:21, 25*

γελως.definition: laughter; by impl. mirth, joy, rejoicing, Jas. 4:9*

γεμω.definition: to be full, Mt. 23:27; Lk. 11:39, et al.

γενεα.definition: pr. birth; hence, progeny; a generation of mankind, Mt. 11:16; 23:36, et al.; a generation, a step in a genealogy, Mt. 1:17; a generation, an interval of time, an age; in NT course of life, in respect of its events, interests, or character, Lk. 16:8; Acts 13:36

γενεαλογεω.definition: to reckon one’s descent, derive one’s origin, Heb. 7:6*

γενεαλογια.definition: genealogy, catalogue of ancestors, history of descent, 1 Tim. 1:4; Tit. 3:9*

γενεσια.definition: pr. a day observed in memory of the dead; in NT equivalent to γενέθλια, celebration of one’s birthday, birthday-festival, Mt. 14:6; Mk. 6:21*

γενεσις.definition: birth, nativity, Mt. 1:18; Lk. 1:14; Jas. 1:23; successive generation, descent, lineage, Mt. 1:1; meton. life, Mt. 1:18; Jas. 3:6*

γενημα.definition: natural produce, fruit, increase, Mt. 26:29; Mk. 14:25; Lk. 12:18; 22:18; 2 Cor. 9:10*

γενναω.definition: to beget, generate, Mt. 1:2-16, et al.; of women, to bring forth, bear, give birth to, Lk. 1:13, 57, et al.; pass. to be born, produced, Mt. 2:1, 4, et al.; met. to produce, excite, give occasion to, effect, 2 Tim. 2:23; from the Hebrew, to constitute as son, to constitute as king, or as the representative or viceregent of God, Acts 13:33; Heb. 1:5; 5:5; by impl. to be a parent to any one; pass. to be a son or child to any one, Jn. 1:13; 1 Cor. 4:15, et al.

γεννημα.definition: what is born or produced, offspring, progeny, brood, Mt. 3:7; 12:34, et al.; fruit, produce, Mt. 26:29; Mk. 14:25, et al.; fruit, increase, Lk. 12:18; 2 Cor. 9:10

γεννησαρετ.definition: Gennesaret, a lake of Palestine, called also the Sea of Tiberias, Mt. 14:34; Mk. 6:53; Lk. 5:1*

γεννητος.definition: born or produced of, Mt. 11:11; Lk. 7:28*

γενος.definition: offspring, progeny, Acts 17:28, 29; family, kindred, lineage, Acts 7:13, et al.; race, nation, people, Mk. 7:26; Acts 4:36, et al.; kind, sort, species, Mt. 13:47, et al.

γερασηνος.definition: also spelled Γεργεσηνός, from Gerasene, belonging to the city of Gerasa, Mk. 5:1; Lk. 8:26, 37*. See PhotoGuide

γερουσια.definition: a senate, assembly of elders; the elders of Israel collectively, Acts 5:21*

γευομαι.definition: to taste, Mt. 27:34; Jn. 2:9; absol. to take food, Acts 10:10, et al.; met. to have perception of, experience, Heb. 6:4, 5; 1 Pet. 2:3; θανάτου γεύεσθαι, to experience death, to die, Mt. 16:28, et al.

γεωργεω.definition: to cultivate, till the earth, Heb. 6:7*

γεωργιον.definition: cultivated field or ground, a farm, 1 Cor. 3:9*

γεωργος.definition: a farmer, one who tills the earth, 2 Tim. 2:6; Jas. 5:7; in NT spc. a vine-dresser, keeper of a vineyard, i.q. ἀμπελουργός, Mt. 21:33, 34, et al.

γη.definition: earth, soil, Mt. 13:5; Mk. 4:8, et al.; the ground, surface of the earth, Mt. 10:29; Lk. 6:49, et al.; the land, as opposed to the sea or a lake, Lk. 5:11; Jn. 21:8, 9, 11; the earth, world, Mt. 5:18, 35, et al.; by synec. the inhabitants of the earth, Mt. 5:13; 6:10; 10:34; a land, region, tract, country, territory, Mt. 2:20; 14:34;by way of eminence, the chosen land, Mt. 5:5; 24:30; 27:45; Eph. 6:3; the inhabitants of a region or country, Mt. 10:15; 11:24, et al.

γηρασκω.definition: to be or become old, Jn. 21:18; Heb. 8:13*

γινομαι.definition: pluperfect, ἐγενόει (3rd sg), to come into existence; to be created, exist by creation, Jn. 1:3, 10; Heb. 11:3; Jas. 3:9; to be born, produced, grow, Mt. 21:19; Jn. 8:58, et al.; to arise, come on, occur, as the phenomena of nature, etc.; Mt. 8:24, 26; 9:16, et al.; to come, approach, as morning or evening, Mt. 8:16; 14:15, 23; to be appointed, constituted, established, Mk. 2:27; Gal. 3:17, et al.; to take place, come to pass, happen, occur, Mt. 1:22; 24:6, 20, 21, 34, et al. freq.; to be done, performed, effected, Mt. 21:42, et al.; to be fulfilled, satisfied, Mt. 6:10; 26:42, et al.; to come into a particular state or condition; to become, assume the character and appearance of anything, Mt. 5:45, et al.; to become or be made anything, be changed or converted, Mt. 4:3; 21:42; Mk. 1:17, et al.; to be, Mt. 11:26; 19:8; γίνεσθαι ὑπό τινα, to be subject to, Gal. 4:4; γίνεσθαι ἐν ἑαυτῷ, to come to one’s self, to recover from a trance or surprise, Acts 12:11; μὴ γένοιτο, let it not be, far be it from, God forbid, Lk. 20:16; Rom. 3:4, 31, et al.; to be kept, celebrated, solemnized, as festivals, Mt. 26:2, et al.; to be finished, completed, Heb. 4:3

γινωσκω.definition: to know, whether the action be inceptive or complete and settled; to perceive, Mt. 22:18; Mk. 5:29; 8:17; 12:12; Lk. 8:46; to mark, discern, Mt. 25:24; Lk. 19:44; to ascertain by examination, Mk. 6:38; Jn. 7:51; Acts 23:28; to understand, Mk. 4:13; Lk. 18:34; Jn. 12:16; 13:7; Acts 8:30; 1 Cor. 14:7, 9; to acknowledge, Mt. 7:23; 2 Cor. 3:2; to resolve, conclude, Lk. 16:4; Jn. 7:26; 17:8; to be assured, Lk. 21:20; Jn. 6:69; 8:52; 2 Pet. 1:20; to be skilled, to be master of a thing, Mt. 16:3; Acts 21:37; to know carnally, Mt. 1:25; Lk. 1:34; from the Hebrew, to view with favor, 1 Cor. 8:3; Gal. 4:9

γλευκος.definition: pr. the unfermented juice of grapes; hence, sweet new wine, Acts 2:13*

γλωσσα.definition: the tongue, Mk. 7:33, 35, et al.; meton. speech, talk, 1 Jn. 3:18; a tongue, language, Acts 2:11; 1 Cor. 13:1, et al.; meton. a language not proper to a speaker, a gift or faculty of such language, Mk. 16:17; 1 Cor. 14:13, 14, 26, et al.; from Hebrew, a nation, as defined by its language, Rev. 5:9, et al.; lit. a tongue-shaped flail, Acts 2:3

γλωσσοκομον.definition: pr. a box for keeping the tongues, mouth-pieces, or reeds of musical instruments; hence, genr. any box or receptacle; in NT a purse, money-bag, Jn. 12:6; 13:29*

γνησιος.definition: lawful, legitimate, as children; genuine, in faith, etc.; 1 Tim. 1:2; Tit. 1:4; true, sincere, 2 Cor. 8:8; Phil. 4:3*

γνωμη.definition: the mind, as the means of knowing and judging; assent, Phlm. 14; purpose, resolution, Acts 20:3; opinion, judgment, 1 Cor. 1:10; 7:40; suggestion, suggested advice, as distinguished from positive injunction, Acts 20:3; 1 Cor. 7:25; 2 Cor. 8:10

γνωριζω.definition: to make known, reveal, declare, Jn. 15:15; 17:26, et al.; to know, Phil. 1:22

γνωσις.definition: knowledge, Lk. 1:77; knowledge of an especial kind and relatively high character, Lk. 11:52; Rom. 2:20; 1 Tim. 6:20; more particularly in respect of Christian enlightenment, Rom. 15:14; 1 Cor. 8:10; 12:8; 2 Cor. 11:6, et al.

γνωστης.definition: one acquainted with a thing, knowing, skilful, Acts 26:3*

γνωστος.definition: known, Jn. 18:15, 16, et al.; certain, incontrovertible, Acts 4:16; τὸ γνωστόν, that which is known or is cognizable, the unquestionable attributes, Rom. 1:19; subst. an acquaintance, Lk. 2:44; 23:49

γογγυζω.definition: to speak privately and in a low voice, mutter, Jn. 7:32; to utter secret and sullen discontent, express indignant complaint, murmur, grumble, Mt. 20:11; Lk. 5:30; Jn. 6:41, 43, 61; 1 Cor. 10:10*

γογγυσμος.definition: a muttering, murmuring, low and suppressed discourse, Jn. 7:12; the expression of secret and sullen discontent, murmuring, complaint, Acts 6:1; Phil. 2:14; 1 Pet. 4:9*

γοης.definition: a juggler, diviner; hence, by impl. an impostor, cheat, 2 Tim. 3:13*

γολγοθα.definition: Golgotha, pr. name, Mt. 27:33; Mk. 15:22; Jn. 19:17*

γομορρα.definition: Gomorrha (Gen. 19), pr. name, Mt. 10:15; Rom. 9:29; 2 Pet. 2:6; Jude 7*

γομος.definition: the cargo of a ship, Acts 21:3; by impl. merchandise, Rev. 18:11, 12*

γονευς.definition: a father; pl. in NT parents, Mt. 10:21; Lk. 2:27, 41; 2 Cor. 12:14

γονυ.definition: the knee, Lk. 22:41; Heb. 12:12, et al.

γονυπετεω.definition: to fall upon one’s knees, to kneel before, Mt. 17:14; 27:29; Mk. 1:40; 10:17*

γραμμα.definition: pr. that which is written or drawn; a letter, character of the alphabet, a writing, book, Jn. 5:47; an acknowledgment of debt, an account, a bill, note, Lk. 16:6, 7; an epistle, letter, Acts 28:21; Gal. 6:11; ἱερὰ γράμματα, the sacred books of the Old Testament, the Jewish Scriptures, 2 Tim. 3:15; spc. the letter of the law of Moses, the bare literal sense, Rom. 2:27, 29; 7:6; 2 Cor. 3:6, 7; pl. letters, learning, Jn. 7:15; Acts 26:24*

γραμματευς.definition: a scribe; a clerk, town-clerk, registrar, recorder, Acts 19:35; one skilled in the Jewish law, a teacher or interpreter of the law, Mt. 2:4; 5:20, et al. freq.; genr. a religious teacher, Mt. 13:52; by synec. any one distinguished for learning or wisdom, 1 Cor. 1:20

γραφη.definition: a writing; in NT the Holy Scriptures, the Jewish Scriptures, or Books of the Old Testament, Mt. 21:42; Jn. 5:39, et al.; by synec. doctrines, declarations, oracles, or promises contained in the sacred books, Mt. 22:29; Mk. 12:24, et al.; spc. a prophecy, Mt. 26:54; Mk. 14:49; Lk. 4:21; 24:27, 32; with the addition of προφητική, Rom. 16:26; of τῶν προφητῶν, Mt. 26:56

γραφω.definition: to engrave, write, according to the ancient method of writing on plates of metal, waxes tables, etc., Jn. 8:6, 8; to write on parchment, paper, etc., generally, Mt. 27:37, et al.; to write letters to another, Acts 23:25; 2 Cor. 2:9; 13:10, et al.; to describe in writing, Jn. 1:46; Rom. 10:5; to inscribe in a catalogue, etc., Lk. 10:20; Rev. 13:8; 17:8, et al.; to write a law, command, or enact in writing, Mk. 10:5; 12:19; Lk. 2:23, et al.

γραωδης.definition: old-womanish; by impl. silly, absurd, 1 Tim. 4:7*

γρηγορεω.definition: to be awake, to watch, Mt. 26:38, 40, 41; Mk. 14:34; 37, 38; to be alive, 1 Thess. 5:10; met. to be watchful, attentive, vigilant, circumspect, Mt. 25:13; Mk. 13:35, et al.

γυμναζω.definition: pr. to train in gymnastic discipline; hence, to exercise in anything, train to use, discipline, 1 Tim. 4:7; Heb. 5:14; 12:11; 2 Pet. 2:14*

γυμνασια.definition: pr. gymnastic exercise; hence, bodily discipline of any kind, 1 Tim. 4:8*

γυμνος.definition: naked, without clothing, Mk. 14:51, 52; without the upper garment, and clad only with an inner garment or tunic, Jn. 21:7; poorly or meanly clad, destitute of proper and sufficient clothing, Mt. 25:36, 38, 43, 44; Acts 19:16; Jas. 2:15; met. unclothed with a body, 2 Cor. 5:3; not covered, uncovered, open, manifest, Heb. 4:13; bare, mere, 1 Cor. 15:37; naked of spiritual clothing, Rev. 3:17; 16:15; 17:16

γυμνοτης.definition: nakedness; want of proper and sufficient clothing, Rom. 8:35; 2 Cor. 11:27; spiritual nakedness, being destitute of spiritual clothing, Rev. 3:18*

γυναικαριον.definition: a little woman; a trifling, weak, silly woman, 2 Tim. 3:6*

γυνη.definition: a woman, Mt. 5:28, et al.; a married woman, wife, Mt. 5:31, 32; 14:3, et al.; in the voc. ὦ γύναι, O woman! an ordinary mode of addressing females under every circumstance; met. used of the Church, as united to Christ, Rev. 19:7; 21:9

γωγ.definition: Gog, pr. name of a nation, indecl., Rev. 20:8*

γωνια.definition: an exterior angle, projecting corner, Mt. 6:5; 21:42; an interior angle; by impl. a dark corner, obscure place, Acts 26:26; corner, extremity, or quarter of the earth, Rev. 7:1; 20:8

δαιμονιζομαι.definition: in NT to be possessed, afflicted, vexed, by a demon or evil spirit, i.q. δαιμόνιον ἔχειν, Mt. 4:24; 8:16, 28, 33

δαιμονιον.definition: a heathen god, deity, Acts 17:18; 1 Cor. 10:20, 21; Rev. 9:20; in NT, a demon, evil spirit, Mt. 7:22; 9:33, 34; 10:8; 12:24

δαιμονιωδης.definition: pertaining to or proceeding from demons; demonic, devilish, Jas. 3:15*

δαιμων.definition: a god, a superior power; in NT a malignant demon, evil angel, Mt. 8:31*

δακνω.definition: to bite, sting; met. to molest, vex, injure, Gal. 5:15*

δακτυλιος.definition: a ring for the finger, Lk. 15:22*

δακτυλος.definition: a finger, Mt. 23:4; Mk. 7:33; from Hebrew, power, Lk. 11:20

δαλμανουθα.definition: Dalmanutha, indecl., a small town on the shore of the Sea of Tiberias, Mk. 8:10*

δαμαζω.definition: also spelled δανείζω, to subdue, tame, Mk. 5:4; Jas. 3:7; met. to restrain within proper limits, Jas. 3:8*

δαμασκηνος.definition: A Damascene, a native of Damascus, 2 Cor. 11:32*

δαμασκος.definition: Damascus, the capital city of Syria

δαπαναω.definition: to expend, be at expense, Mk. 5:26; Acts 21:24; 2 Cor. 12:15; to spend, waste, consume by extravagance, Lk. 15:14; Jas. 4:3*

δαυιδ.definition: also spelled Δανείδ and Δαβίδ, David, pr. name, indecl., Mt. 1:6; Lk. 1:27; Acts 2:29; Rom. 1:3; 2 Tim. 2:28

δε.definition: a conjunctive particle, marking the superaddition of a clause, whether in opposition or in continuation, to what has preceded, and it may be variously rendered but, on the other hand, and, also, now, etc.; καὶ δέ, when there is a special superaddition in continuation, too, yea, etc. It sometimes is found at the commencement of the apodosis of a sentence, Acts 11:17. It serves also to mark the resumption of an interrupted discourse, 2 Cor. 2:10; Gal. 2:6

δει.definition: it is binding, it is necessary, it is proper; it is inevitable, Acts 21:22

δειγμα.definition: pr. that which is shown, a specimen, sample; met. an example by way of warning, Jude 7*

δειγματιζω.definition: to make a public show or spectacle of, Mt. 1:19; Col. 2:15*

δεικνυμι.definition: also formed as δεικνύω 3x, to show, point out, present to the sight, Mt. 4:8; 8:4; to exhibit, permit to see, cause to be seen, Jn. 2:18; 10:32; 1 Tim. 6:15; to demonstrate, prove, Jas. 2:18; 3:13; met. to teach, make known, declare, announce, Mt. 16:21; Jn. 5:20; Acts 10:28

δειλιαω.definition: to be timid, be in fear, Jn. 14:27*

δειλος.definition: timid, fearful, cowardly, Mt. 8:26; Mk. 4:40; Rev. 21:8*

δεινα.definition: such a one, a certain one, Mt. 26:18*

δεινως.definition: dreadfully, grievously, greatly, terribly, Mt. 8:6; Lk. 11:53*

δειπνεω.definition: to eat or dine, Lk. 17:8; 22:20; 1 Cor. 11:25; Rev. 3:20

δειπνον.definition: pr. a meal; supper, the principal meal taken in the evening, Lk. 14:12; Jn. 13:2, 4; meton. food, 1 Cor. 11:21; a feast, banquet, Mt. 23:6; Mk. 6:21; 12:39

δεισιδαιμονια.definition: fear of the gods; in a bad sense, superstition; a form of religious belief, Acts 25:19*

δεισιδαιμων.definition: reverencing the gods and divine things, religious; in a bad sense, superstitious; in NT careful and precise in the discharge of religious services, Acts 17:22*

δεκα.definition: ten, Mt. 20:24; 25:1; ἡμερῶν δέκα, ten days, a few days, a short time, Rev. 2:10

δεκαπολις.definition: Decapolis, a district of Palestine beyond Jordan, Mk. 5:20; 7:31; Mt. 4:25*

g1182.definition: tenth, Jn. 1:39; Rev. 11:13; 21:20; δεκάτη, i.e. μερίς, a tenth part, tithe, Heb. 7:2, 4, 8, 9*

δεκατοω.definition: to cause to pay tithes; pass. to be tithed, pay tithes, Heb. 7:6, 9*

δεκτος.definition: accepted, acceptable, agreeable, approved, Lk. 4:24; Acts 10:35; Phil. 4:18; by impl. when used of a certain time, marked by divine acceptance, propitious, Lk. 4:19; 2 Cor. 6:2*

δελεαζω.definition: pr. to entrap, take or catch with a bait; met. allure, entice, Jas. 1:14; 2 Pet. 2:14, 18*

δεξιολαβος.definition: one posted on the right hand; a flank guard; a light armed spearman, Acts 23:23*

δεξιος.definition: right, as opposed to left, Mt. 5:29, 30; Lk. 6:6; ἡ δεξιά, i.e. χείρ, the right hand, Mt. 6:3; 27:29; τὰ δεξιά, i.e. μέρη, the parts towards the right hand, the right hand side; καθίζειν, or, καθῆσθαι, or, ἑστάναι, ἐκ δεξιῶν [μερῶν] τινος, to sit or stand at the right hand of any one, as a mark of the highest honor and dignity which he can bestow, Mt. 20:20; 26:64; εἶνι ἐκ δεξιῶν [μερῶν] τινος, to be at one’s right hand, as a helper, Acts 2:25; δεξιὰς (χεῖρας) διδόναι, to give the right hand to any one, as a pledge of sincerity in one’s promises, Gal. 2:9

δεομαι.definition: to be in want, to need; to ask, request, Mt. 9:38; Lk. 5:12; 8:28, 38; in NT absol. to pray, offer prayer, beseech, supplicate, Lk. 21:36; 22:32; Acts 4:31; 8:22, 24

δερβη.definition: Derbe, a city of Lycaonia, Acts 14:6, 20; 16:0*. See PhotoGuide.

δερμα.definition: the skin of an animal, Heb. 11:37*

δερματινος.definition: made of skin, leathern, Mt. 3:4; Mk. 1:6*

δερω.definition: to skin, flay; hence, to eat, scourge, beat, Mt. 21:35; Mk. 12:3, 5; 13:9

δεσμευω.definition: to bind, bind up, as a bundle, Mt. 23:4; to bind, confine, Lk. 8:29; Acts 22:4*

δεσμη.definition: a bundle, as of tares, Mt. 13:30*

δεσμιος.definition: one bound, a prisoner, Mt. 27:15, 16; Mk. 15:6

δεσμος.definition: a bond, anything by which one is bound, a cord, chain, fetters, etc.; and by meton. imprisonment, Lk. 8:29; Acts 16:26; 20:23; a string or ligament, as of the tongue, Mk. 7:35; met. an impediment, infirmity, Lk. 13:16

δεσμοφυλαξ.definition: a keeper of a prison, jailer, Acts 16:23, 27, 36*

δεσποτης.definition: a lord, master, especially of slaves, 1 Tim. 6:1, 2; 2 Tim. 2:21; Tit. 2:9; 1 Pet. 2:18; by impl. as denoting the possession of supreme authority, Lord, sovereign, used of God, Lk. 2:29; Acts 4:24; Rev. 6:10; and of Christ, 2 Pet. 2:1; Jude 4

δευρο.definition: here; used also as a sort of imperative, come, Come here! Mt. 19:21; Mk. 10:21; used of time, ἄχρι τοῦ δεῦρο, i.e. χρόνου, to the present time, Rom. 1:13

δευτε.definition: come, Mt. 4:19; 11:28; as a particle of exhortation, incitement, etc., and followed by an imperative, come now, etc., Mt. 21:38; 28:6

δευτεραιος.definition: on the second day of a certain state or process, and used as an epithet of the subject or agent, Acts 28:13*

δευτερος.definition: second, Mt. 22:26; τὸ δεύτερον, again, the second time, another time, Jude 5; so ἐκ δευτέρου, Mt. 26:42; and ἐν τῷ δευτέρῳ, Acts 7:13

δεχομαι.definition: to take into one’s hands, etc., Lk. 2:28; 16:6, 7; to receive, Acts 22:5; 28:21; Phil. 4:18; to receive into and retain, contain, Acts 3:21; met. to receive by the hearing, learn, acquire a knowledge of, 2 Cor. 11:4; Jas. 1:21; to receive, admit, grant access to, receive kindly, welcome, Mt. 10:40, 41; 18:5; to receive in hospitality, entertain, Lk. 9:53; Heb. 11:31; to bear with, bear patiently, 2 Cor. 11:16; met. to receive, approve, assent to, Mt. 11:14; Lk. 8:13; Acts 8:14; 11:1; to admit, and by impl. to embrace, follow, 1 Cor. 2:14; 2 Cor. 8:17

δεω.definition: to bind, tie, Mt. 13:30; 21:2; to bind, confine, Mt. 27:2; 14:3; to impede, hinder, 2 Tim. 2:9; to bind with infirmity, Lk. 13:16; to bind by a legal or moral tie, as marriage, Rom. 7:2; 1 Cor. 7:27, 39; by impl. to impel, compel, Acts 20:22; in NT to pronounce or declare to be binding or obligatory, or, to declare to be prohibited and unlawful, Mt. 16:19; 18:18

δη.definition: a particle that adds an intensity of expression to a term or clause. Its simplest and most ordinary uses are when it gives impressiveness to an affirmation, indeed, really, doubtless, Mt. 13:23; or earnestness to a call, injunction, or entreaty, Lk. 2:15; Acts 13:2; 15:36; 1 Cor. 16:20*

δηλος.definition: pr. clearly visible; plain, manifest, evident, Mt. 26:73; 1 Cor. 15:27; Gal. 3:11*

δηλοω.definition: to render manifest or evident; to make known, to tell, relate, declare, 1 Cor. 1:11; Col. 1:8; to show, point out, bring to light, 1 Cor. 3:13; to indicate, signify, Heb. 9:8; 12:27; 1 Pet. 1:11

δημας.definition: Demas, pr. name, Col. 4:14; 2 Tim. 4:10; Phlm. 24*

δημηγορεω.definition: to address a public assembly, to deliver a public oration, Acts 12:21*

δημητριος.definition: Demetrius, pr. name (1) The Ephesian silversmith, Acts 19:24, 38 (2) A certain Christian, 3 Jn. 12*

δημιουργος.definition: pr. one who labors for the public, or, exercises some public calling; an architect, especially, the Divine Architect of the universe, Heb. 11:10

δημοσιος.definition: public, belonging to the public, Acts 5:18; δημοσίᾳ, publicly, Acts 16:37; 18:28; 20:20*

δηναριον.definition: Latin denarius, a Roman silver coin; the name originally meant ten asses, Mt. 18:28; Mk. 6:37; Rev. 6:6

δηπου.definition: now in some way, surely, Heb. 2:16*

δια.definition: (1) gen., through, used of place or medium, Mt. 7:13; Lk. 6:1; 2 Cor. 11:33; through, of time, during, in the course of, Heb. 2:15; Acts 5:19; through, of immediate agency, causation, instrumentality, by means of, by, Jn. 1:3; Acts 3:18; of means or manner, through, by, with, Lk. 8:4; 2 Cor. 5:7; 8:8; of state or condition, in a state of, Rom. 4:11; (2) acc., used of causation which is not direct and immediate in the production of a result, on account of, because of, for the sake of, with a view to, Mk. 2:27; Jn. 1:31; rarely, through, while subject to a state of untoward circumstances, Gal. 4:13

διαβαινω.definition: to pass through or over, Lk. 16:26; Acts 16:9; Heb. 11:29*

διαβαλλω.definition: to throw or convey through or over; to thrust through; to defame, inform against, Lk. 16:1*

διαβεβαιοομαι.definition: to assert strongly, insist, 1 Tim. 1:7; Tit. 3:8*

διαβλεπω.definition: to look through; to view steadily, Mk. 8:25; to see clearly or steadily, Mt. 7:5; Lk. 6:42*

διαβολος.definition: slanderer, 1 Tim. 3:11; 2 Tim. 3:3; Tit. 2:3; a treacherous informer, traitor, Jn. 6:70; ὁ διάβολος, the devil

διαγγελλω.definition: to publish abroad, Lk. 9:60; Rom. 9:17; to certify to the public, Acts 21:26*

διαγινομαι.definition: pass., to continue through; to intervene, elapse of time, Mk. 16:1; Acts 25:13; 27:9*

διαγινωσκω.definition: pr. to distinguish; to resolve determinately; to examine, inquire into, judicially, Acts 23:15; 24:22*

διαγνωσις.definition: pr. an act of distinguishing or discernment; a determination; examination judicially, hearing, trial, Acts 25:21*

διαγρηγορεω.definition: to remain awake; to wake thoroughly, Lk. 9:32*

διαγω.definition: to conduct or carry through or over; to pass or spend time, live, 1 Tim. 2:2; Tit. 3:3*

διαδεχομαι.definition: to receive by transmission; to receive in return, Acts 7:45*

διαδημα.definition: pr. a band or fillet; a diadem, the badge of a sovereign, Rev. 12:3; 13:1; 19:12*

διαδιδωμι.definition: to deliver from hand to hand; to distribute, divide, Lk. 11:22; 18:22; Jn. 6:11; Acts 4:35*

διαζωννυμι.definition: to gird firmly round, Jn. 13:4, 5; mid. to gird round one’s self, Jn. 21:7*

διαθηκη.definition: a testamentary disposition, will; a covenant, Heb. 9:16, 17; Gal. 3:15; in NT, a covenant of God with men, Gal. 3:17; 4:24; Heb. 9:4; Mt. 26:28; the writings of the old covenant, 2 Cor. 3:14

διαιρεσις.definition: a division; a distinction, difference, diversity, 1 Cor. 12:4, 5, 6*

διαιρεω.definition: to divide, to divide out, distribute, Lk. 15:12; 1 Cor. 12:11*

διακατελεγχομαι.definition: to maintain discussion strenuously and thoroughly, to totally refute, Acts 18:28*

διακονεω.definition: to wait, attend upon, serve, Mt. 8:15; Mk. 1:31; Lk. 4:39; to be an attendant or assistant, Acts 19:22; to minister to, relieve, assist, or supply with the necessaries of life, provide the means of living, Mt. 4:11; 27:55; Mk. 1:13; 15:41; Lk. 8:3; to fill the office of διάκονος, deacon, perform the duties of deacon, 1 Tim. 3:10, 13; 1 Pet. 4:11; to convey in charge, administer, 2 Cor. 3:3; 8:19, 20; 1 Pet. 1:12; 4:10; pass. to receive service, Mt. 20:28; Mk. 10:45

διακονια.definition: serving, service, waiting, attendance, the act of rendering friendly offices, Lk. 10:40; 2 Tim. 4:11; Heb. 1:14; relief, aid, Acts 6:1; 11:29; 2 Cor. 8:4; 9:1, 12, 13; a commission, Acts 12:25; Rom. 15:31; a commission or ministry in the service of the Gospel, Acts 1:17, 25; 20:24; Rom. 11:13; 2 Cor. 4:1; 5:18; 1 Tim. 1:12; service in the Gospel, Acts 6:4; 21:19; 1 Cor. 16:15; 2 Cor. 6:3; 11:8; Eph. 4:12; Rev. 2:19; a function, ministry, or office in the Church, Rom. 12:7; 1 Cor. 12:5; Col. 4:17; 2 Tim. 4:5; a ministering in the conveyance of a revelation from God, 2 Cor. 3:7, 8, 9

διακονος.definition: one who renders service to another; an attendant, servant, Mt. 20:26; 22:13; Jn. 2:5, 9; one who executes a commission, a deputy, Rom. 13:4; Χριστοῦ, Θεοῦ, ἐν κυρίῳ, etc. a commissioned minister or preacher of the Gospel, 1 Cor. 3:5; 2 Cor. 6:4; a minister charged with an announcement or sentence, 2 Cor. 3:6; Gal. 2:17; Col. 1:23; a minister charged with a significant characteristic, Rom. 15:8; a servitor, devoted follower, Jn. 12:26; a deacon or deaconess, whose official duty was to superintend the alms of the Church, with other kindred services, Rom. 16:1; Phil. 1:1; 1 Tim. 3:8, 12

διακουω.definition: to hear a thing through; to hear judicially, Acts 23:35*

διακρινω.definition: to separate, sever; to make a distinction or difference, Acts 15:9; 1 Cor. 11:29; to make to differ, distinguish, prefer, confer a superiority, 1 Cor. 4:7; to examine, scrutinize, estimate, 1 Cor. 11:31; 14:29; to discern, discriminate, Mt. 16:3; to judge, to decide a cause, 1 Cor. 6:5; to dispute, contend, Acts 11:2; Jude 9; to make a distinction mentally, Jas. 2:4; Jude 22; in NT to hesitate, be in doubt, doubt, Mt. 21:21; Mk. 11:23

διακρισις.definition: a separation; a distinction, or, doubt, Rom. 14:1; a discerning, the act of discerning or distinguishing, Heb. 5:14; the faculty of distinguishing and estimating, 1 Cor. 12:10*

διαλαλεω.definition: to talk with; by impl. to consult, deliberate, Lk. 6:11; to divulge, publish, spread by rumor, Lk. 1:65*

διαλεγομαι.definition: to discourse, argue, reason, Acts 17:2, 17; 24:12; to address, speak to, Heb. 12:5; to contend, dispute, Mk. 9:34; Jude 9

διαλειπω.definition: to leave an interval; to intermit, cease, Lk. 7:45*

διαλεκτος.definition: speech; manner of speaking; peculiar language of a nation, dialect, vernacular idiom, Acts 1:19; 2:6, 8; 21:40; 22:2; 26:14

διαλλασσομαι.definition: to be reconciled to another, Mt. 5:24*

διαλογιζομαι.definition: pr. to make a settlement of accounts; to reason, deliberate, ponder, consider, Mt. 16:7, 8; Mk. 2:6, 8; Jn. 11:50; to dispute, contend, Mk. 9:33

διαλογισμος.definition: reasoning, thought, cogitation, purpose, Mt. 15:19; Mk. 7:21; discourse, dispute, disputation, contention, Lk. 9:46; doubt, hesitation, scruple, Lk. 24:38

διαμαρτυρομαι.definition: to make solemn affirmation, protest; to make a solemn and earnest charge, Lk. 16:28; Acts 2:40; to declare solemnly and earnestly, Acts 8:25; 18:5

διαμαχομαι.definition: to fight out, to fight resolutely; met. to contend vehemently, insist, Acts 23:9*

διαμενω.definition: to continue throughout; to continue, be permanent or unchanged, Lk. 1:22; Gal. 2:5; Heb. 1:11; 2 Pet. 3:4; to continue, remain constant, Lk. 22:28

διαμεριζω.definition: to divide into parts and distribute, Mt. 27:35; Mk. 15:24; Acts 2:3; pass. in NT to be in a state of dissension, Lk. 11:17, 18; 12:52, 53

διαμερισμος.definition: division; met. in NT disunion, dissension, Lk. 12:51*

διανεμω.definition: to distribute; to divulge, spread abroad, Acts 4:17*

διανευω.definition: to signify by a nod, beckon, make signs, Lk. 1:22*

διανοια.definition: pr. thought, intention; the mind, intellect, understanding, Mt. 22:37; Mk. 12:30; Lk. 10:27; an operation of the understanding, thought, imagination, Lk. 1:51; insight, comprehension, 1 Jn. 5:20; mode of thinking and feeling, disposition of mind and heart, the affection, Eph. 2:3; Col. 1:21

διανοιγω.definition: to open, Mk. 7:34, 35; Lk. 2:23; 24:31; Acts 7:56; met. to open the sense of a thing, explain, expound, Lk. 24:32; Acts 17:3; διανοίγειν τὸν νοῦν, τὴν καρδίαν, to open the mind, the heart, so as to understand and receive, Lk. 24:45; Acts 16:14*

διανυκτερευω.definition: to pass the night, spend the whole night, Lk. 6:12*

διαπεραω.definition: to pass through or over, Mt. 9:1; 14:34; Mk. 5:21; 6:53; Lk. 16:26; Acts 21:2*

διαπλεω.definition: to sail through or over, Acts 27:5*

διαπονεομαι.definition: pr. to be thoroughly exercised with labor; to be wearied; to be vexed, Acts 4:2; 16:18*

διαπορευομαι.definition: to go or pass through, Lk. 6:1; 13:22; Acts 16:4; to pass by, Lk. 18:36

διαπορεω.definition: to be utterly at a loss; to be in doubt and perplexity, Lk. 9:7; Acts 2:12; 5:24; 10:17

διαπραγματευομαι.definition: to despatch a matter thoroughly; to make profit in business, gain in trade, Lk. 19:15*

διαπριω.definition: to divide with a saw, saw asunder; to grate the teeth in a rage; pass. met. to be cut to the heart, to be enraged, Acts 5:33; 7:54*

διαρπαζω.definition: to plunder, spoil, pillage, Mt. 12:29; Mk. 3:27 (2x)*

διασαφεω.definition: to make known, declare, tell plainly, or fully, Mt. 13:36; 18:31*

διασειω.definition: pr. to shake thoroughly or violently; to harass, intimidate, extort from, Lk. 3:14*

διασκορπιζω.definition: to disperse, scatter, Mt. 26:31; Mk. 14:27; to dissipate, waste, Lk. 15:13; 16:1; to winnow, or, to strew, Mt. 25:24, 26

διασπαω.definition: to pull or tear asunder or in pieces, burst, Mk. 5:4; Acts 23:10*

διασπειρω.definition: to scatter abroad or in every direction, as seen; to disperse, Acts 8:1, 4; 11:19*

διασπορα.definition: pr. a scattering, as of seed; dispersion; in NT meton. the dispersed portion of the Jews, specially termed the dispersion, Jn. 7:35; Jas. 1:1; 1 Pet. 1:1*

διαστελλω.definition: to determine, issue a decision; to state or explain distinctly and accurately; hence, to admonish, direct, charge, command, Acts 15:24; Heb. 12:20; when followed by a negative clause, to interdict, prohibit, Mt. 16:30; Mk. 5:43

διαστρεφω.definition: to distort, turn away; met. to pervert, corrupt, Mt. 17:17; Lk. 9:41; to turn out of the way, cause to make defection, Lk. 23:2; Acts 13:8; διεστραμμένος, perverse, corrupt, erroneous

διασωζω.definition: to bring safely through; to convey in safety, Acts 23:24; pass. to reach a place or state of safety, Acts 27:43, 44; 28:1, 4; 1 Pet. 3:20; to heal, to restore to health, Mt. 14:36; Lk. 7:3*

διαταγη.definition: an injunction, institute, ordinance, Rom. 13:2; Acts 7:53*

διαταρασσω.definition: to throw into a state of perturbation, to move or trouble greatly, Lk. 1:29*

διατασσω.definition: pr. to arrange, make a precise arrangement; to prescribe, 1 Cor. 11:34; 16:1; Tit. 1:5; to direct, Lk. 8:55; Acts 20:13; to charge, Mt. 11:1; to command, Acts 18:2; to ordain, Gal. 3:19

διατελεω.definition: to complete, finish; intrans. to continue, persevere, in a certain state or course of action, Acts 27:33*

διατηρεω.definition: to watch carefully, guard with vigilance; to treasure up, Lk. 2:51; ἑαυτὸν ἐκ, to keep one’s self from, to abstain wholly from, Acts 15:29*

διατιθημι.definition: in NT only mid., so some list as διατίθεμαι, to arrange; to arrange according to one’s own mind; to make a disposition, to make a will; to settle the terms of a covenant, to ratify, Acts 3:25; Heb. 8:10; 10:16; to assign, Lk. 22:29

διατριβω.definition: pr. to rub, wear away by friction; met. to pass or spend time, to remain, stay, tarry, continue, Jn. 3:22; 11:54; Acts 12:19; 14:3, 28

διαυγαζω.definition: to shine through, shine out, dawn, 2 Pet. 1:19*

διαφερω.definition: to convey through, across, Mk. 11:16; to carry different ways or into different parts, separate; pass. to be borne, driven, or tossed hither and thither, Acts 27:27; to be proclaimed, published, Acts 13:49; intrans. met. to differ, 1 Cor. 15:41; to excel, be better or of greater value, be superior, Mt. 6:26; 10:31; impers. διαφέρει, it makes a difference, it is of consequence; with οὐδέν, it makes no difference, it is nothing, Gal. 2:6

διαφευγω.definition: to flee through, escape by flight, Acts 27:42*

διαφημιζω.definition: to report, proclaim, publish, spread abroad, Mt. 9:31; 28:15; Mk. 1:45*

διαφθειρω.definition: to corrupt or destroy utterly; to waste, bring to decay, Lk. 12:33; 2 Cor. 4:16; to destroy, Rev. 8:9; 11:18 (2x); met. to corrupt, pervert utterly, 1 Tim. 6:5*

διαφορος.definition: different, diverse, of different kinds, Rom. 12:6; Heb. 9:10; excellent, superior, Heb. 1:4; 8:6*

διαφυλασσω.definition: to keep or guard carefully or with vigilance; to guard, protect, Lk. 4:10*

διαχειριζω.definition: pr. to have in the hands, to manage; mid. later, to kill, Acts 5:30; 26:21*

διδακτικος.definition: apt or qualified to teach, 1 Tim. 3:2; 2 Tim. 2:24*

διδακτος.definition: pr. taught, teachable, of things; in NT taught, of person, Jn. 6:45; 1 Cor. 2:13*

διδασκαλια.definition: the act or occupation of teaching, Rom. 12:7; 1 Tim. 4:13; information, instruction, Rom. 15:4; 2 Tim. 3:16; matter taught, precept, doctrine, Mt. 15:9; 1 Tim. 1:10

διδασκαλος.definition: a teacher, master, Rom. 2:20; in NT as an equivalent, to ῥαββί, Jn. 1:39

διδασκω.definition: to teach, Mt. 4:23; 22:16; to teach or speak in a public assembly, 1 Tim. 2:12; to direct, admonish, Mt. 28:15; Rom. 2:21

διδαχη.definition: instruction, the giving of instruction, teaching, Mk. 4:2; 12:38; instruction, what is taught, doctrine, Mt. 16:12; Jn. 7:16, 17; meton. mode of teaching and kind of doctrine taught, Mt. 7:28; Mk. 1:27

διδραχμον.definition: a didrachmon or double drachma, a silver coin equal to the drachma of Alexandria, to two Attic drachmas, to two Roman denarii, and to the half-shekel of the Jews, Mt. 17:24 (2x)*

διδυμος.definition: a twin; Didymus, the Greek equivalent to the name Thomas, Jn. 11:16; 20:24; 21:2*

διδωμι.definition: pluperfect, ἐδεδώκειν, to give, bestow, present, Mt. 4:9; 6:11; Jn. 3:16; 17:2, et al. freq.; to give, cast, throw, Mt. 7:6; to supply, suggest, Mt. 10:19; Mk. 13:11; to distribute alms, Mt. 19:21; Lk. 11:41; to pay tribute, etc., Mt. 22:17; Mk. 12:14; Lk. 20:22; to be the author or source of a thing, Lk. 12:51; Rom. 11:8; to grant, permit, allow, Acts 2:27; 13:35; Mt. 13:11; 19:11; to deliver to, entrust, commit to the charge of anyone, Mt. 25:15; Mk. 12:9; to give or deliver up, Lk. 22:19; Jn. 6:51; to reveal, teach, Acts 7:38; to appoint, constitute, Eph. 1:22; 4:11; to consecrate, devote, offer in sacrifice, 2 Cor. 8:5; Gal. 1:4; Rev. 8:3; to present, expose one’s self in a place, Acts 19:31; to recompense, Rev. 2:23; to attribute, ascribe, Jn. 9:24; Rev. 11:13; from the Hebrew, to place, put, fix, inscribe, Heb. 8:10; 10:16; to infix, impress, 2 Cor. 12:7; Rev. 13:16; to inflict, Jn. 18:22; 19:3; 2 Thess. 1:8; to give in charge, assign, Jn. 5:36; 17:4; Rev. 9:5; to exhibit, put forth, Mt. 24:24; Acts 2:19; to yield, bear fruit, Mt. 13:8; διδόναι ἐργασίαν, to endeavor, strive, Lk. 12:58; διδόναι ἀπόκρισιν, to answer, reply, Jn. 1:22; διδόναι τόπον, to give place, yield, Lk. 14:9; Rom. 12:19

διεγειρω.definition: to arouse or awake thoroughly, Mt. 1:24; Mk. 4:38, 39; Lk. 8:24; pass. to be raised, excited, agitated, as a sea, Jn. 6:18; met. to stir up, arouse, animate, 2 Pet. 1:13; 3:1

διενθυμεομαι.definition: to revolve thoroughly in the mind, consider carefully, ponder, reflect, Acts 10:19*

διεξοδος.definition: a passage throughout; a line of road, a thoroughfare, Mt. 22:9*

διερμηνευω.definition: to explain, interpret, translate, Lk. 24:27; Acts 9:36; 1 Cor. 14:5, 13, 27; to be able to interpret, 1 Cor. 12:30*

διερχομαι.definition: to pass through, Mk. 10:25; Lk. 4:30; to pass over, cross, Mk. 4:35; Lk. 8:22; to pass along, Lk. 19:4; to proceed, Lk. 2:15; Acts 9:38; to travel through or over a country, wander about, Mt. 12:43; Lk. 9:6; to transfix, pierce, Lk. 2:35; to spread abroad, be prevalent, as a rumor, Lk. 5:15; met. to extend to, Rom. 5:12

διερωταω.definition: to sift by questioning, of persons; in NT, of things, to ascertain by inquiry, Acts 10:17*

διετης.definition: of two years; of the age of two years, Mt. 2:16*

διετια.definition: the space of two years, Acts 24:27; 28:30*

διηγεομαι.definition: pr. to lead throughout; to declare thoroughly, detail, recount, relate, tell, Mk. 5:16; 9:9; Lk. 8:39; Acts 8:33; Heb. 11:32

διηνεκης.definition: continuous, uninterrupted; εἰς τὸ διηνεκές, perpetually, Heb. 7:3; 10:1, 12, 14*

διθαλασσος.definition: surrounded on both sides by the sea; τόπος διθάλασσος, a shoal or sand-bank formed by the confluence of opposite currents, Acts 27:41*

διικνεομαι.definition: to go or pass through; to penetrate, Heb. 4:12*

διιστημι.definition: to set at an interval, apart; to station at an interval from a former position, Acts 27:28; intrans. to stand apart; to depart, be parted, Lk. 24:51; of time, to intervene, be interposed, Lk. 22:59*

διισχυριζομαι.definition: to feel or express reliance; to affirm confidently, insist, Lk. 22:59; Acts 12:15*

δικαιος.definition: just, equitable, fair, Mt. 20:4; Lk. 12:57; Jn. 5:30; Col. 4:1; of persons, just, righteous, absolutely, Jn. 17:25; Rom. 3:10, 26; 2 Tim. 4:8; 1 Pet. 3:18; 1 Jn. 1:9; 2:1, 29; Rev. 16:5; righteous by account and acceptance, Rom. 2:13; 5:19; in ordinary usage, just, upright, innocent, pious, Mt. 5:45; 9:13, et al. freq.; ὁ δίκαιος, the Just One, one of the distinctive titles of the Messiah, Acts 3:14; 7:52; 22:14

δικαιοσυνη.definition: fair and equitable dealing, justice, Acts 17:31; Heb. 11:33; Rom. 9:28; integrity, virtue, Lk. 1:75; Eph. 5:9; in NT generosity, alms, 2 Cor. 9:10, v.r.; Mt. 6:1; piety, godliness, Rom. 6:13; investiture with the attribute of righteousness, acceptance as righteous, justification, Rom. 4:11; 10:4, et al. freq.; a provision or mean for justification, Rom. 1:17; 2 Cor. 3:9; an instance of justification, 2 Cor. 5:21

δικαιοω.definition: pr. to make or render right or just; mid. to act with justice, Rev. 22:11; to avouch to be good and true, to vindicate, Mt. 11:19; Lk. 7:29; to set forth as good and just, Lk. 10:29; 16:15; in NT to hold as guiltless, to accept as righteous, to justify, Rom. 3:26, 30; 4:5; 8:30, 33; pass. to be held acquitted, to be cleared, Acts 13:39; Rom. 3:24; 6:7; to be approved, to stand approved, to stand accepted, Rom. 2:13; 3:20, 28

δικαιωμα.definition: pr. a rightful act, act of justice, equity; a sentence, of condemnation, Rev. 15:4; in NT, of acquittal, justification, Rom. 5:16; a decree, law, ordinance, Lk. 1:6; Rom. 1:32; 2:26; 8:4; Heb. 9:1, 10; a meritorious act, an instance of perfect righteousness, Rom. 5:18; Rev. 19:8*

δικαιως.definition: justly, with strict justice, 1 Pet. 2:23; deservedly, Lk. 23:41; as it is right, fit or proper, 1 Cor. 15:34; uprightly, honestly, piously, religiously, 1 Thess. 2:10; Tit. 2:12*

δικαιωσις.definition: pr. a making right or just; a declaration of right or justice; a judicial sentence; in NT, acquittal, acceptance, justification, Rom. 4:25; 5:18*

δικη.definition: right, justice; in NT judicial punishment, vengeance, 2 Thess. 1:9; Jude 7; sentence of punishment, judgment, Acts 25:15; personified, the goddess of justice or vengeance, Nemesis, Paena, Acts 28:4

διλογος.definition: pr. saying the same thing twice; in NT double-tongued, speaking one thing and meaning another, deceitful in words, 1 Tim. 3:8*

διο.definition: inferential conj., on which account, wherefore, therefore, Mt. 27:8; 1 Cor. 12:3

διοδευω.definition: to travel through a place, traverse, Lk. 8:1; Acts 17:1

διοπερ.definition: inferential conj., on this very account, for this very reason, wherefore, 1 Cor. 8:13; 10:14*

διοπετης.definition: which fell from Jupiter, or heaven; τοῦ διοπετοῦς, i.e. ἀγάλματος, image or statue; for discussion of ellipsis see grammars, Acts 19:35*

διορυσσω.definition: to dig or break through, Mt. 6:19, 20; 24:43; Lk. 12:39*

διοσκουροι.definition: the Dioscuri, Castor and Pollux, sons of Jupiter by Leda, and patrons of sailors, Acts 28:11*

διοτι.definition: on the account that, because, Lk. 2:7; 21:28; in as much as, Lk. 1:13; Acts 18:10

διπλοω.definition: to double; to render back double, Rev. 18:6*

δις.definition: twice, Mk. 14:30, 72; in the sense of entirely, utterly, Jude 12; ἅπαξ καὶ δίς, once and again, repeatedly, Phil. 4:16

δισμυριας.definition: twice ten thousand, two myriads, Rev. 9:16*

διστομος.definition: pr. having two mouths; two-edged, Heb. 4:12; Rev. 1:16; 2:12*

διυλιζω.definition: to strain, filter thoroughly; to strain out or off, Mt. 23:24*

διχαζω.definition: to cut asunder, disunite; met. to cause to disagree, set at variance, Mt. 10:35*

διχοστασια.definition: a standing apart; a division, dissension, Rom. 16:17; Gal. 5:20*

διχοτομεω.definition: pr. to cut into two parts, cut asunder; in NT to inflict a punishment of extreme severity, Mt. 24:51; Lk. 12:46*

διψαω.definition: to thirst, be thirsty, Mt. 25:35, 37, 42, 44; met. to thirst after in spirit, to desire or long for ardently, Mt. 5:6; Jn. 4:14; 6:35

διωγμος.definition: pr. chase, pursuit; persecution (specifically for religious reasons), Mt. 13:21; Mk. 4:17; 10:30

διωκω.definition: to put in rapid motion; to pursue; to follow, pursue the direction of, Lk. 17:23; to follow eagerly, endeavor earnestly to acquire, Rom. 9:30, 31; 12:13; to press forwards, Phil. 3:12, 14; to pursue with malignity, persecute, Mt. 5:10, 11, 12, 44

δογμα.definition: a decree, statute, ordinance, Lk. 2:1; Acts 16:4; 17:7; Eph. 2:15; Col. 2:14*

δογματιζω.definition: to decree, prescribe an ordinance; mid. to suffer laws to be imposed on one’s self, to submit to, bind one’s self by, ordinances, Col. 2:20*

δοκεω.definition: to think, imagine, suppose, presume, Mt. 3:9; 6:7; to seem, appear, Lk. 10:36; Acts 17:18; it seems; it seems good, best, or right, it pleases, Lk. 1:3; Acts 15:22, 25

δοκιμαζω.definition: to test, assay metals, 1 Pet. 1:7; to prove, try, examine, scrutinize, Lk. 14:19; Rom. 12:2; to put to the proof, tempt, Heb. 3:9; to approve after trial, judge worthy, choose, Rom. 14:22; 1 Cor. 16:3; 2 Cor. 8:22; to decide upon after examination, judge of, distinguish, discern, Lk. 12:56; Rom. 2:18; Phil. 1:10

δοκιμη.definition: trial, proof by trial, 2 Cor. 8:2; the state or disposition of that which has been tried and approved, approved character or temper, Rom. 5:4; 2 Cor. 2:9; Phil. 2:22; proof, document, evidence, 2 Cor. 8:2; 13:3*

δοκιμιον.definition: that by means of which anything is tried, proof, criterion, test; trial, the act of trying or putting to proof, Jas. 1:3; approved character, 1 Pet. 1:7*

δοκιμος.definition: proved, tried; approved after examination and trial, Rom. 16:10; Jas. 1:12; by impl. acceptable, Rom. 14:18

δοκος.definition: a beam or spar of timber, Mt. 7:3, 4, 5; Lk. 6:41, 42*

δολιοω.definition: to deceive, use fraud or deceit, Rom. 3:13*

δολος.definition: pr. a bait or contrivance for entrapping, fraud, deceit, cunning, guile, Mt. 26:4; Mk. 7:22; 14:1

δολοω.definition: pr. to entrap, beguile; to adulterate, corrupt, falsify, 2 Cor. 4:2*

δομα.definition: a gift, present, Mt. 7:11; Lk. 11:13; Eph. 4:8; Phil. 4:17*

δοξα.definition: pr. a seeming; appearance; a notion, imagination, opinion; the opinion which obtains respecting one; reputation, credit, honor, glory; in NT honorable consideration, Lk. 14:10; praise, glorification, honor, Jn. 5:41, 44; Rom. 4:20; 15:7; dignity, majesty, Rom. 1:23; 2 Cor. 3:7; a glorious manifestation, glorious working, Jn. 11:40; 2 Pet. 1:3; pl. dignitaries, 2 Pet. 2:10; Jude 8; glorification in a future state of bliss, 2 Cor. 4:17; 2 Tim. 2:10; pride, ornament, 1 Cor. 11:15; 1 Thess. 2:20; splendid array, pomp, magnificence, Mt. 6:29; 19:28; radiance, dazzling lustre, Lk. 2:9; Acts 22:11

δοξαζω.definition: to think, suppose, judge; to extol, magnify, Mt. 6:2; Lk. 4:15; in NT to adore, worship, Rom. 1:21; to invest with dignity or majesty, 2 Cor. 3:10; Heb. 5:5; to signalize with a manifestation of dignity, excellence, or majesty, Jn. 12:28; 13:32; to glorify by admission to a state of bliss, to beatify, Rom. 8:30

δορκας.definition: Dorcas, pr. name, signifying a gazelle or antelope, Acts 9:36, 39*

δοσις.definition: pr. giving, outlay; Phil. 4:15; a donation, gift, Jas. 1:17*

δουλαγωγεω.definition: pr. to bring into slavery; to treat as a slave; to discipline into subjection, 1 Cor. 9:27*

δουλεια.definition: slavery, bondage, servile condition; in NT met. with reference to degradation and unhappiness, Rom. 8:15, 21; Gal. 4:24; 5:1; Heb. 2:15*

δουλευω.definition: to be a slave or servant; to be in slavery or subjection, Jn. 8:33; Acts 7:7; Rom. 9:12; to discharge the duties of a slave or servant, Eph. 6:7; 1 Tim. 6:2; to serve, be occupied in the service of, be devoted, subservient, Mt. 6:24; Lk. 15:29; Acts 20:19; Rom. 14:18; 16:18; met. to be enthralled, involved in a slavish service, spiritually or morally, Gal. 4:9, 25; Tit. 3:3

g1401.definition: a male slave, or servant, of various degrees, Mt. 8:9, et al. freq.; a servitor, person of mean condition, Phil. 2:7; fem. δούλη, a female slave; a handmaiden, Lk. 1:38, 48; Acts 2:18; δοῦλος, used figuratively, in a bad sense, one involved in moral or spiritual thraldom, Jn. 8:34; Rom. 6:17, 20; 1 Cor. 7:23; 2 Pet. 2:19; in a good sense, a devoted servant or minister, Acts 16:17; Rom. 1:1; one pledged or bound to serve, 1 Cor. 7:22; 2 Cor. 4:5

δουλοω.definition: to reduce to servitude, enslave, oppress by retaining in servitude, Acts 7:6; 2 Pet. 2:19; met. to render subservient, 1 Cor. 9:19; pass. to be under restraint, 1 Cor. 7:15; to be in bondage, spiritually or morally, Gal. 4:3; Tit. 2:3; to become devoted to the service of, Rom. 6:18, 22*

δοχη.definition: pr. reception of guests; in NT a banquet, feast, Lk. 5:29; 14:13

δρακων.definition: a dragon or large serpent; met. the devil or Satan, Rev. 12:3, 4, 7, 9, 13, 16, 17; 13:2, 4, 11; 16:13; 20:2

δρασσομαι.definition: pr. to grasp with the hand, clutch; to lay hold of, seize, take, catch, 1 Cor. 3:19*

δραχμη.definition: a drachma, an Attic silver coin of nearly the same value as the Roman denarius, Lk. 15:8, 9*

δρεπανον.definition: an instrument with a curved blade, as a sickle, Mk. 4:29; Rev. 14:14, 15, 16, 17, 18, 19*

δρομος.definition: a course, race, race-course; met. course of life or ministry, career, Acts 13:25; 20:24; 2 Tim. 4:7*

δυναμαι.definition: to be able, either intrinsically and absolutely, which is the ordinary signification; or, for specific reasons, Mt. 9:15; Lk. 16:2 See ability; (be) able; can.

δυναμις.definition: power; strength, ability, Mt. 25:15; Heb. 11:11; efficacy, 1 Cor. 4:19, 20; Phil. 3:10; 1 Thess. 1:5; 2 Tim. 3:5; energy, Col. 1:29; 2 Tim. 1:7; meaning, purport of language, 1 Cor. 14:11; authority, Lk. 4:36; 9:1; might, power, majesty, Mt. 22:29; 24:30; Acts 3:12; Rom. 9:17; 2 Thess. 1:7; 2 Pet. 1:16; in NT a manifestation or instance of power, mighty means, Acts 8:10; Rom. 1:16; 1 Cor. 1:18, 24; ἡ δύναμις, omnipotence, Mt. 26:64; Lk. 22:69; Mt. 14:62; pl. authorities, Rom. 8:38; Eph. 1:21; 1 Pet. 3:22; miraculous power, Mk. 5:30; Lk. 1:35; 5:17; 6:19; 8:46; 24:49; 1 Cor. 2:4; a miracle, Mt. 11:20, 21, et al. freq.; a worker of miracles, 1 Cor. 12:28, 29; from the Hebrew αἱ δυνάμεις τῶν οὐρανῶν, the heavenly luminaries, Mt. 24:29; Mk. 13:25; Lk. 21:26; αἱ δυνάμεις, the spiritual powers, Mt. 14:2; Mk. 6:14

δυναστης.definition: a potentate, sovereign; prince, Lk. 1:52; 1 Tim. 6:15; a person of rank and authority, Acts 8:27*

δυνατεω.definition: to be powerful, mighty, to show one’s self powerful, 2 Cor. 9:8; 13:3; Rom. 14:4*

δυνατος.definition: able, having power, powerful, mighty; δυνατὸς εἶναι, to be able, i.q. δύνασθαι, Lk. 14:31; Acts 11:17; ὁ δυνατός, the Mighty One, God, Lk. 1:49; τὸ δυνατόν, power, i.q. δύναμις, Rom. 9:22; valid, powerful, efficacious, 2 Cor. 10:4; distinguished for rank, authority, or influence, Acts 25:5; 1 Cor. 1:26; distinguished for skill or excellence, Lk. 24:19; Acts 7:22; Rom. 15:1; δυνατόν and δυνατά, possible, capable of being done, Mt. 19:26; 24:24 See ability; mighty; possible.

δυνω.definition: to sink, go down, set as the sun, Mk. 1:32; Lk. 4:40*

δυο.definition: two, Mt. 6:24; 21:38, 31, et al. freq.; οἱ δύο, both, Jn. 20:4; δύο ἠ τρεῖς, two or three, some, a few, Mt. 18:20; from the Hebrew, δύο δύο, two and two, Mk. 6:7, i.q. ἀνὰ δύο, Lk. 10:1, and κατὰ δύο, 1 Cor. 14:27

δυσβαστακτος.definition: difficult or grievous to be borne, oppressive, Lk. 11:46

δυσερμηνευτος.definition: difficult to be explained, hard to be understood, Heb. 5:11*

δυσκολος.definition: pr. peevish about food; hard to please, disagreeable; in NT, difficult, Mk. 10:24*

δυσκολως.definition: with difficulty, hardly, Mt. 19:23; Mk. 10:23; Lk. 18:24*

δυσμη.definition: a sinking or setting; pl. δυσμαί, the setting of the sun; hence, the west, Mt. 8:11; 24:27

δυσφημεω.definition: pr. to use ill words; to reproach, revile, 1 Cor. 4:13*

δυσφημια.definition: ill words; words of ill omen; reproach, contumely, 2 Cor. 6:8*

δωδεκα.definition: twelve, Mt. 9:20; 10:1; οἱ δώδεκα, the twelve apostles, Mt. 26:14, 20

δωμα.definition: pr. a house; synec. a roof, Mt. 10:27; 24:17

δωρεα.definition: a gift, free gift, benefit, Jn. 4:10; Acts 2:38

δωρεαν.definition: gratis, gratuitously, freely, Mt. 10:8; Rom. 3:24; in NT undeservedly, without cause, Jn. 15:25; in vain, Gal. 2:21

δωρεομαι.definition: to give freely, grant, Mk. 15:45; 2 Pet. 1:3, 4*

δωρημα.definition: a gift, free gift, Rom. 5:16; Jas. 1:17*

δωρον.definition: a gift, present, Mt. 2:11; Eph. 2:8; Rev. 11:10; an offering, sacrifice, Mt. 5:23, 24; 8:4; δῶρον, i.e. ἐστι[ν], it is consecrated to God, Mt. 15:5; Mk. 7:11; contribution to the temple, Lk. 21:1, 4

εα.definition: Ha! an expression of surprise or displeasure, Lk. 4:34*

εαν.definition: if, ἐὰν μή, except, unless; also equivalent to ἀλλά, Gal. 2:16. Ἐάν, in NT as in the later Greek, is substituted for ἄν after relative words, Mt. 5:19. Tends to be an indicator for the subjunctive mood.

εανπερ.definition: if it be that, if indeed, if at all events, Heb. 3:6, 14; 6:3

εαυτου.definition: himself, herself, itself, Mt. 8:22; 12:26; 9:21; also used for the first and second persons, Rom. 8:23; Mt. 23:31; also equivalent to ἀλλήλων, Mk. 10:26; Jn. 12:19; ἀφ’ ἑαυτοῦ, ἀφ’ ἑαυτῶν, of himself, themselves, voluntarily, spontaneously, Lk. 12:57; 21:30; of one’s own will merely, Jn. 5:19; δι’ ἑαυτοῦ, of itself, in its own nature, Rom. 14:14; ἐξ ἑαυτῶν, of one’s own self, 2 Cor. 3:5; καθ’ ἑαυτόν, by one’s self, alone, Acts 28:16; Jas. 2:17; παρ’ ἑαυτῷ, with one’s self, at home, 1 Cor. 16:2; πρὸς ἑαυτόν, to one’s self, to one’s home, Lk. 24:12; Jn. 20:10; or, with one’s self, Lk. 18:11

εαω.definition: to let, allow, permit, suffer to be done, Mt. 24:43; Lk. 4:41; to let be, let alone, desist from, stop, Lk. 22:51; to commit a ship to the sea, let her drive, Acts 27:40

εβδομηκοντα.definition: seventy, indecl., Acts 7:14; οἱ ἑβδομήκοντα, the seventy disciples, Lk. 10:1, 17; Acts 23:23*

εβραιος.definition: a Hebrew, one descended from Abraham the Hebrew, 2 Cor. 11:22; Phil. 3:5; in NT, a Jew of Palestine, one speaking Aramaic, opp. to Ἑλληνιστής, Acts 6:1*

εβραις.definition: the Hebrew dialect, i.e., the Hebrew-Aramaic dialect of Palestine, Acts 21:40; 22:2; 26:14*

εγγιζω.definition: pr. to cause to approach; in NT intrans. to approach, draw near, Mt. 21:1; Lk. 18:35; met. to be at hand, Mt. 3:2; 4:17; μέχρι θανάτου ἐγγίζειν, to be at the point of death, Phil. 2:30; from Hebrew to draw near to God, to offer Him reverence and worship, Mt. 15:8; Heb. 7:19; Jas. 4:8; used of God, to draw near to men, assist them, bestow favors on them, Jas. 4:8

εγγραφω.definition: to engrave, inscribe, Lk. 10:20; met. ἐγγεγραμμένος, imprinted, 2 Cor. 3:2, 3*

εγγυς.definition: some view as an improper prep., followed by gen. or dat., near, as to place, Lk. 19:11; close at hand, Rom. 10:8; near, in respect of ready interposition, Phil. 4:5; near, as to time, Mt. 24:32, 33; near to God, as being in covenant with him, Eph. 2:13; οἱ ἐγγύς, the people near to God, the Jews, Eph. 2:17

εγειρω.definition: to excite, arouse, awaken, Mt. 8:25; mid. to awake, Mt. 2:13, 20, 21; met. mid. to rouse one’s self to a better course of conduct, Rom. 13:11; Eph. 5:14; to raise from the dead, Jn. 12:1; and mid. to rise from the dead, Mt. 27:52; Jn. 5:21; met. to raise as it were from the dead, 2 Cor. 4:14; to raise up, cause to rise up from a prone posture, Acts 3:7; and mid. to rise up, Mt. 17:7; to restore to health, Jas. 5:15; met. et seq. ἐπή, to excite to war; mid. to rise up against, Mt. 24:7; to raise up again, rebuild, Jn. 2:19, 20; to raise up from a lower place, to draw up or out of a ditch, Mt. 12:10; from Hebrew, to raise up, to cause to arise or exist, Acts 13:22, 23; mid. to arise, exist, appear, Mt. 3:9; 11:11

εγερσις.definition: pr. the act of waking or rising up; resurrection resuscitation, Mt. 27:53*

εγκαινια.definition: initiation, consecration; in NT the feast of rededication, an annual festival of eight days in the month Kislev, Jn. 10:22*

εγκαινιζω.definition: to initiate, consecrate, dedicate, renovate; to institute, Heb. 9:18; 10:20*

εγκαλεω.definition: can be followed by a dative, to bring a charge against, accuse; to institute judicial proceedings, Acts 19:38, 40; 23:28, 29; 26:2, 7; Rom. 8:33

εγκαταλειπω.definition: to leave, leave behind; to forsake, abandon, Mt. 27:46; Mk. 15:34; Acts 2:27, 30; Rom. 9:29; 2 Cor. 4:9; 2 Tim. 4:10, 16; Heb. 10:25; 13:5* See abandon; desert; forsake.

εγκατοικεω.definition: to dwell in, or among, 2 Pet. 2:8*

εγκαυχαομαι.definition: to boast in, or of, 2 Thess. 1:4*

εγκομβοομαι.definition: pr. to put on a garment which is to be tied; in NT to put on, clothe one’s self with; met. 1 Pet. 5:5*

εγκοπη.definition: alsn spelled ἐκκοπή, pr. an incision, e.g. a trench, etc., cut in the way of an enemy; an impediment, hindrance, 1 Cor. 9:12*

εγκοπτω.definition: pr. to cut or strike in; hence, to impede, interrupt, hinder, Rom. 15:22; 1 Thess. 2:18; 1 Pet. 3:7; Gal. 5:7; Acts 24:4*

εγκρατεια.definition: self-control, continence, temperance, Acts 24:25; Gal. 4:23; 2 Pet. 1:6*

εγκρατευομαι.definition: to possess the power of self-control or continence, 1 Cor. 7:9; to practise abstinence, 1 Cor. 9:25*

εγκρατης.definition: strong, stout; possessed of mastery; master of self, Tit. 1:8*

εγκρινω.definition: to judge or reckon among, consider as belonging to, adjudge to the number of; class with, place in the same rank, 2 Cor. 10:12*

εγκρυπτω.definition: to conceal in anything; to mix, intermix, Mt. 13:33; Lk. 13:21*

g1691,.definition: I, gen., ἐμοῦ [μου], dat., ἐμοί [μοι], acc., ἐμέ [με]

εδαφιζω.definition: pr. to form a level and firm surface; to level with the ground, overthrow, raze, destroy, Lk. 19:44*

εδαφος.definition: pr. a bottom, base; hence, the ground, Acts 22:7*

εδραιος.definition: sedentary; met. settled, steady, firm, steadfast, constant, 1 Cor. 7:37; 15:58; Col. 1:23*

εθελοθρησκια.definition: also spelled ἐθελοθρησκεία, self-made religion, Col. 2:23*

εθιζω.definition: to accustom; pass. to be customary, Lk. 2:27*

εθναρχης.definition: a governor, chief of any tribe or nation, 2 Cor. 11:32*

εθνικος.definition: national; in NT Gentile, heathen, not Israelites, Mt. 5:47; 6:7; 18:17; 3 Jn. 7*

εθνος.definition: a multitude, company, Acts 17:26; 1 Pet. 2:9; Rev. 21:24; a nation, people, Mt. 20:25; 21:43; pl. ἔθνη, from the Hebrew, nations or people as distinguished from the Jews, the heathen, Gentiles, Mt. 4:15; 10:5; Lk. 2:32

εθος.definition: a custom, usage, habit, Lk. 2:42; 22:39; an institute, rite, Lk. 1:9; Acts 6:14; 15:1

ει.definition: if, Mt. 4:3, 6; 12:7; Acts 27:39, freq.; since, Acts 4:9; whether, Mk. 9:23; Acts 17:11; that, in certain expressions, Acts 26:8, 23; Heb. 7:15; by a suppression of the apodosis of a sentence, εἰ serves to express a wish; O if! O that! Lk. 19:42; 22:42; also a strong negation, Mk. 8:12; Heb. 3:11; 4:3; εἰ καί, if even, though, although, Lk. 18:4; εἰ μή, unless, except, Mt. 11:27; also equivalent to ἀλλά, but, Mt. 12:4; Mk. 13:32; Lk. 4:26, 27; εἰ μήτι, unless perhaps, unless it be, Lk. 9:13; εἴ τις, εἴ τι, pr. if any one; whosoever, whatsoever, Mt. 18:28. The syntax of this particle must be learned from the grammars. As an interrogative particle, whether, Acts 17:11; in NT as a mere note of interrogation, Lk. 22:49

ειδος.definition: form, external appearance, Lk. 3:22; 9:29; Jn. 5:37; kind, species, 1 Thess. 5:22; sight, perception, 2 Cor. 5:7*

ειδωλοθυτος.definition: as a noun meat offered to an idol, Acts 15:29; 21:25; 1 Cor. 8:1, 4, 7, 10; 10:19; Rev. 2:14, 20*

ειδωλολατρης.definition: an idolater, worshipper of idols, 1 Cor. 5:10, 11; 6:9; 10:7; Eph. 5:5; Rev. 21:8; 22:15*

ειδωλολατρια.definition: idolatry, worship of idols, 1 Cor. 10:14; Gal. 5:20; Col. 3:5; 1 Pet. 4:3*

ειδωλον.definition: pr. a form, shape, figure; image or statue; hence, an idol, image of a god, Acts 7:41; a heathen god, 1 Cor. 8:4, 7; for εἰδωλόθυτον, the flesh of victims sacrificed to idols, Acts 15:20; Rom. 2:22; 1 Cor. 10:19; 12:12; 2 Cor. 6:16; 1 Thess. 1:9; 1 Jn. 5:21; Rev. 9:20*

εικη.definition: without plan or system; without cause, rashly, Col. 2:18; to no purpose, in vain, Rom. 13:4; 1 Cor. 15:2; Gal. 3:4 (2x); 4:11*

εικω.definition: (1) to yield, give place, submit, Gal. 2:5. (2) the perfect form ἔοικα (G2036) is from this same root and functions as a present, Jm 1:6, 23 (ἔοικεν, 3 sg). Some list it as a separate word, but see the discussion in Liddell and Scott*

εικων.definition: a material image, likeness, effigy, Mt. 22:20; Mk. 12:16; a representation, exact image, 1 Cor. 11:7; 15:49; Rev. 13:14f.; resemblance, Rom. 1:23; 8:29; Col. 3:10; Heb. 10:1

ειλικρινεια.definition: clearness, purity; met. sincerity, integrity, ingenuousness, 1 Cor. 5:8; 2 Cor. 1:12; 2:17*

ειλικρινης.definition: pr. that which being viewed in the sunshine is found clear and pure; met. spotless, sincere, ingenuous, Phil. 1:10; 2 Pet. 3:1*

g1498,.definition: to be, to exist, Jn. 1:1; 17:5; Mt. 6:30; Lk. 4:25, freq.; ἐστί[ν], it is possible, proper, Heb. 9:5; a simple linking verb (“copula”) to the subject and predicate, and therefore in itself affecting the force of the sentence only by its tense, mood, etc., Jn. 1:1; 15:1, freq.; it also forms a frequent circumlocution with the participles of the present and perfect of other verbs, Mt. 19:22; Mk. 2:6

εινεκεν.definition: see ἕνεκα, on account of, Lk. 4:18; Acts 28:20; 2 Cor. 3:10*

ειπερ.definition: if indeed, if it be so that, granted, Rom. 8:9; 1 Cor. 15:15; since indeed, since, 2 Thess. 1:6; 1 Pet. 2:3; although indeed, 1 Cor. 8:5

ειρηνευω.definition: to be at peace; to cultivate peace, concord, or harmony, Mt. 9:50; Rom. 12:18; 2 Cor. 13:11; 1 Thess. 5:13*

ειρηνη.definition: peace, Lk. 14:32; Acts 12:20; tranquillity, Lk. 11:21; Jn. 16:33; 1 Thess. 5:3; concord, unity, love of peace, Mt. 10:34; Lk. 12:51; meton. the author of peace, Eph. 2:14; from the Hebrew every kind of blessing and good, Lk. 1:79; 2:14, 29; meton. a salutation expressive of good wishes, a benediction, blessing, Mt. 10:13

ειρηνικος.definition: pertaining to peace; peaceable, disposed to peace, Jas. 3:17; from the Hebrew, profitable, blissful, Heb. 12:11*

ειρηνοποιος.definition: a peace-maker, one who cultivates peace and concord, Mt. 5:9*

εις.definition: to, as far as, to the extent of, Mt. 2:23; 4:24; until, Jn. 13:1; against, Mt. 18:15; Lk. 12:10; before, in the presence of, Acts 22:30; in order to, for, with a view to, Mk. 1:38; for the use or service of, Jn. 6:9; Lk. 9:13; 1 Cor. 16:1; with reference to, 2 Cor. 10:13, 16; in accordance with, Mt. 12:41; Lk. 11:32; 2 Tim. 2:26; also equivalent to ἐν, Jn. 1:18; by, in forms of swearing, Mt. 5:35; from the Hebrew, εἶναι, γίνεσθαι εἰς, to become, result in, amount to, Mt. 19:5; 1 Cor. 4:3; εἰς τί, why, wherefore, Mt. 26:8

g3391.definition: numeral one, Mt. 10:29, freq.; only, Mk. 12:6; one virtually by union, Mt. 19:5, 6; Jn. 10:30; one and the same, Lk. 12:52; Rom. 3:30; one in respect of office and standing, 1 Cor. 3:8; equivalent to τις, a certain one, Mt. 8:19; 16:14; a, an, Mt. 21:19; Jas. 4:13; εἱς ἕκαστος, each one, every one, Lk. 4:40; Acts 2:3; εἱς τὸν ἕνα, one another, 1 Thess. 5:11; εἱς καὶ εἱς, the one- and the other, Mt. 20:21; εἱς καθ’ εἱς and ὁδὲ καθ’ εἱς, one by one, one after another, in succession, Mk. 14:19; Jn. 8:9; as an ordinal, first, Mt. 28:1

εισαγω.definition: to lead or bring in, introduce, conduct or usher in or to a place or person, Lk. 2:27; 14:21; 22:54; Jn. 18:16; Acts 9:8; 21:28f., 37; Heb. 1:6

εισακουω.definition: to hear or hearken to, to heed, 1 Cor. 14:21; to listen to the prayers of any one, accept one’s petition, Mt. 6:7; Lk. 1:13; Acts 10:31; Heb. 5:7*

εισδεχομαι.definition: to admit; to receive into favor, receive kindly, accept with favor, 2 Cor. 6:17*

εισειμι.definition: to go in, enter, Acts 3:3; 21:18, 26; Heb. 9:6*

εισερχομαι.definition: to go or come in, enter, Mt. 7:13; 8:5, 8; spc. to enter by force, break in, Mk. 3:27; Acts 20:29; met. with εἰς κόσμον, to begin to exist, come into existence, Rom. 5:12; 2 Jn. 7; or, to make one’s appearance on earth, Heb. 10:5; to enter into or take possession of, Lk. 22:3; Jn. 13:27; to enter into, enjoy, partake of, Mt. 19:23, 24; to enter into any one’s labor, be his successor, Jn. 4:38; to fall into, be placed in certain circumstances, Mt. 26:41; to be put into, Mt. 15:11; Acts 11:8; to present one’s self before, Acts 19:30; met. to arise, spring up, Lk. 9:46; from the Hebrew, εἰσέρχεσθαι καὶ ἐξέρχεσθαι, to go in and out, to live, discharge the ordinary functions of life, Acts 1:21

εισκαλεομαι.definition: to call in; to invite in, Acts 10:23*

εισοδος.definition: a place of entrance; the act of entrance, Heb. 10:19; admission, reception, 1 Thess. 1:9; 2 Pet. 1:11; a coming, approach, access, 1 Thess. 2:1; entrance upon office, commencement or beginning of ministry, Acts 13:24*

εισπηδαω.definition: to leap or spring in, rush in eagerly, Acts 16:29*

εισπορευομαι.definition: to go or come in, enter, Mk. 1:21; 5:40; to come to, visit, Acts 28:30; to be put in, Mt. 15:17; Mk. 7:15, 18, 19; to intervene, Mk. 4:19

εισφερω.definition: to bring in or into, Lk. 5:18, 19; 1 Tim. 6:7; Heb. 13:11; to bring to the ears of any one, to announce, Acts 17:20; to lead into, Mt. 6:13; Lk. 11:4; drag in, Lk. 12:11*

ειτα.definition: then, afterwards, Mk. 4:17, 28; Lk. 8:12; in the next place, 1 Cor. 12:28; besides, furthermore, Heb. 12:9

ειωθα.definition: perfect of an obsolete present ἔθω, pluperfect is εἰώθειν, to be accustomed, to be usual, Mt. 27:15; Mk. 10:1; Lk. 4:16; Acts 17:2*

εκ.definition: ἐχ before vowels, with genitive, from, out of, a place, Mt. 2:15; 3:17; of, from, out of, denoting origin or source, Mt. 1:3; 21:19; of, from some material, Mt. 3:9; Rom. 9:21; of, from, among, partitively, Mt. 6:27; 21:31; Mk. 9:17; from, denoting cause, Rev. 8:11; 17:6; means or instrument, Mt. 12:33, 37; by, through, denoting the author or efficient cause, Mt. 1:18; Jn. 10:32; of, denoting the distinguishing mark of a class, Rom. 2:8; Gal. 3:7; of time, after, 2 Cor. 4:6; Rev. 17:11; from, after, since, Mt. 19:12; Lk. 8:27; for, with, denoting a rate of payment, price, Mt. 20:2; 27:7; at, denoting position, Mt. 20:21, 23; after passive verbs, by, of, from, marking the agent, Mt. 15:5; Mk. 7:11; forming with certain words a periphrasis for an adverb, Mt. 26:42, 44; Mk. 6:51; Lk. 23:8; put after words of freeing, Rom. 7:24; 2 Cor. 1:10; used partitively after verbs of eating, drinking, etc., Jn. 6:26; 1 Cor. 9:7

εκατονταρχης.definition: the text varies between this form and ἑκατόνταρχος, commander of a hundred men, a centurion, Lk. 23:47; Acts 10:1; 27:1ff.

εκβαινω.definition: to go forth, go out of, Heb. 11:15*

εκβαλλω.definition: pluperfect, ἐκβεβλήκειν, to cast out, eject by force, Mt. 15:17; Acts 27:38; to expel, force away, Lk. 4:29; Acts 7:58; to refuse, Jn. 6:37; to extract, Mt. 7:4; to reject with contempt, despise, contemn, Lk. 6:22; in NT to send forth, send out, Mt. 9:38; Lk. 10:2; to send away, dismiss, Mt. 9:25; Mk. 1:12; met. to spread abroad, Mt. 12:20; to bring out, produce, Mt. 12:35; 13:52

εκβασις.definition: a way out, egress; hence, result, issue, Heb. 13:7; means of clearance or successful endurance, 1 Cor. 10:13*

εκβολη.definition: a casting out; especially, a throwing overboard of a cargo, Acts 27:18*

εκγονος.definition: born of, descended from; as a noun ἔκγονα, descendants, grandchildren, 1 Tim. 5:4*

εκδεχομαι.definition: pr. to receive from another; to expect, look for, Acts 17:16; to wait for, to wait, 1 Cor. 11:33; 16:11; Heb. 11:10; 10:13; Jas. 5:7*

εκδημεω.definition: pr. to be absent from home, go abroad, travel; hence, to be absent from any place or person, 2 Cor. 5:6, 8, 9*

εκδιδωμι.definition: middle, to give out, to give up; to put out at interest; in NT to let out to tenants, Mt. 21:33, 41; Lark 12:1; Lk. 20:9*

εκδικεω.definition: pr. to execute right and justice; to punish, 2 Cor. 10:6; Rev. 6:10; 19:2; in NT to right, avenge a person, Lk. 18:3, 5; Rom. 12:9*

εκδικησις.definition: vengeance, punishment, retributive justice, Lk. 21:22; Rom. 12:19; 2 Cor. 7:11; 1 Pet. 2:14; ἐκδίκησιν ποιεῖν, to vindicate, avenge, Lk. 18:7, 8; διδόναι ἐκδίκησιν, to inflict vengeance, Acts 7:24; 2 Thess. 1:8; Heb. 10:30*

εκδικος.definition: an avenger, one who inflicts punishment, Rom. 13:4; 1 Thess. 4:6*

εκδιωκω.definition: pr. to chase away, drive out; in NT to persecute, vex, harass, 1 Thess. 2:15*

εκδυω.definition: pr. to go out from; to take off, strip, unclothe, Mt. 27:28, 31; mid. to lay aside, to put off, Mk. 15:20; Lk. 10:30; 2 Cor. 5:3f.*

εκει.definition: there, in that place, Mt. 2:13, 15; to that place, Mt. 2:22; 17:20

εκεινος.definition: demonstrative adjective or noun, that, this, he, etc., Mt. 17:27; 10:14; 2 Tim. 4:8; in contrast with οὗτος, referring to the former of two things previously mentioned, Lk. 18:14

εκζητεω.definition: to seek out, investigate diligently, scrutinize, 1 Pet. 1:10; to ask for, beseech earnestly, Heb. 12:17; to seek diligently or earnestly after, Acts 15:17; Rom. 3:11; Heb. 10:6; from the Hebrew, to require, exact, demand, Lk. 11:50, 51; Heb. 12:07*

εκθαμβεω.definition: pass., to be amazed, astonished, awe-struck, Mk. 9:15; 14:33; 16:5, 6*

εκθαυμαζω.definition: to wonder at, wonder greatly, Mk. 12:17*

εκκαθαιρω.definition: to cleanse thoroughly, purify, 2 Tim. 2:21; to purge out, eliminate, 1 Cor. 5:7*

εκκαιω.definition: pass., to blaze out, to be inflamed, Rom. 1:27*

εκκεντεω.definition: to stab, pierce deeply, Jn. 19:37; Rev. 1:7*
