θαυμαστος.definition: wondrous, glorious, 1 Pet. 2:9; Rev. 15:1; marvellous, strange, uncommon, Mt. 21:42; Mk. 12:11; Jn. 9:30; Rev. 15:3*

θεαομαι.definition: to gaze upon, Mt. 6:1; 23:5; Lk. 7:24; to see, discern with the eyes, Mk. 16:11, 14; Lk. 5:27; Jn. 1:14, 32, 38; to see, visit, Rom. 15:24

θεατριζω.definition: to be exposed as in a theater, to be made a gazing-stock, object of scorn, Heb. 10:33*

θεατρον.definition: a theater, a place where public games and spectacles are exhibited, Acts 19:29, 31; meton. a show, gazing-stock, 1 Cor. 4:9*

θειος.definition: divine, pertaining to God, 2 Pet. 1:3, 4; τὸ θεῖον, the divine nature, divinity, Acts 17:29*

θειοτης.definition: divinity, deity, godhead, divine majesty, Rom. 1:20*

θελημα.definition: will, bent, inclination, 1 Cor. 16:12; Eph. 2:3; 1 Pet. 4:3; resolve, 1 Cor. 7:37; will, purpose, design, 2 Tim. 2:26; 2 Pet. 1:21; will, sovereign pleasure, behest, Mt. 18:14; Lk. 12:47; Acts 13:22, et al. freq.; ἐν τῷ θελήματι θεοῦ, Deo permittente, if God please or permit, Rom. 1:10

θελω.definition: to exercise the will, properly by an unimpassioned operation; to be willing, Mt. 17:4; to be inclined, disposed, Rom. 13:3; to choose, Lk. 1:62; to intend, design, Lk. 14:28; to will, Jn. 5:21; 21:22; ἤθελον, I could wish, Gal. 4:20

θεμελιον.definition: in Acts 16:26 themelion is used as a neuter noun from themelios (G2529), foundation such as the foundation of a prison*

θεμελιος.definition: see θεμέλιον (G2528) a foundation, Lk. 6:48, 49; Heb. 11:10; met. a foundation laid in elementary instruction, Heb. 6:1; a foundation of a superstructure of faith, doctrine, or hope, 1 Cor. 3:10, 11, 12; Eph. 2:20; 1 Tim. 6:19; a foundation laid in the commencement of the preaching of the Gospel, Rom. 15:20*

θεμελιοω.definition: to found, lay the foundation of, Mt. 7:25; Heb. 1:10; met. to ground, establish, render firm and unwavering, Eph. 3:17; Col. 1:23; 1 Pet. 5:10*

θεοδιδακτος.definition: taught of God, divinely instructed, 1 Thess. 4:9*

θεομαχος.definition: fighting against God, in conflict with God, Acts 5:39*

θεος.definition: a deity, Acts 7:43; 1 Cor. 8:5; an idol, Acts 7:40; God, the true God, Mt. 3:9, et al. freq.; God, possessed of true godhead, Jn. 1:1; Rom. 9:5; from the Hebrew, applied to potentates, Jn. 10:34, 35; τῷ θεῷ, an intensive term, from the Hebrew, exceedingly, Acts 7:20, and, perhaps, 2 Cor. 10:4

θεοσεβεια.definition: worshipping of God, reverence towards God, piety, 1 Tim. 2:10*

θεοσεβης.definition: reverencing God, pious, godly, devout, a sincere worshipper of God, Jn. 9:31*

θεοστυγης.definition: God-hated; in NT a hater and despiser of God, Rom. 1:30*

θεραπεια.definition: service, attendance; healing, cure, Lk. 9:11; Rev. 22:2; meton. those who render service, servants, domestics, family household, Lk. 12:42*

θεραπευω.definition: to heal, cure, Mt. 4:23, 24; 8:16; pass. to receive service, Acts 17:25; to serve, minister to, render service and attendance; to render divine service, worship, Acts 17:25

θεραπων.definition: an attendant, a servant; a minister, Heb. 3:5*

θεριζω.definition: to gather in harvest, reap, Mt. 6:26; 25:24, 26; met. to reap the reward of labor, 1 Cor. 9:11; 2 Cor. 9:6; to reap the harvest of vengeance, Rev. 14:15, 16

θερισμος.definition: a harvest, the act of gathering in the harvest, reaping, Jn. 4:35; met. the harvest of the Gospel, Mt. 9:37, 38; Lk. 10:2; a crop; met. the crop of vengeance, Rev. 14:15

θεριστης.definition: one who gathers in the harvest, a reaper, Mt. 13:30, 39*

θερμαινω.definition: to warm; mid. to warm one’s self, Mt. 14:54, 67; Jn. 18:18, 25; Jas. 2:16*

θερμη.definition: also formed as θέρμα, heat, warmth, Acts 28:3*

θερος.definition: the warm season of the year, summer, Mt. 24:32; Mk. 13:28; Lk. 21:30*

θεσσαλονικευς.definition: Thessalonian, of Thessalonica, Acts 20:4; 27:2; inscription to 1 and 2 Thess.*

θεσσαλονικη.definition: Thessalonica, a city of Macedonia, Acts 17:1, 11, 13; Phil. 4:16; 2 Tim. 4:10*. See PhotoGuide.

θεωρεω.definition: to be a spectator, to gaze on, contemplate; to behold, view with interest and attention, Mt. 27:55; 28:1; to contemplate mentally, consider, Heb. 7:4; in NT to see, perceive, Mk. 3:11; to come to a knowledge of, Jn. 6:40; from the Hebrew, to experience, undergo, Jn. 8:51

θεωρια.definition: a beholding; a sight, spectacle, Lk. 23:48*

θηκη.definition: a repository, receptacle; a case, sheath, scabbard, Jn. 18:11*

θηλαζω.definition: to suckle, give suck, Mt. 24:19; Mk. 13:17; Lk. 21:23; to suck, Mt. 21:16; Lk. 11:27*

θηλυς.definition: female; τὸ θῆλυ, i.e. γένος, a female, Mt. 19:4; Mk. 10:6; Gal. 3:28; ἡ θήλεια, woman, Rom. 1:26, 27*

θηρα.definition: hunting, the chase; met. means of capture, a cause of destruction, Rom. 11:9*

θηρευω.definition: to hunt, catch; met. to seize on, lay hold of, Lk. 11:54*

θηριομαχεω.definition: to fight with wild beasts; met. to be exposed to furious hostility, 1 Cor. 15:32*

θηριον.definition: a beast, wild animal, Mk. 1:13; Acts 10:12; met. a brute, brutish man, Tit. 1:12

θησαυριζω.definition: to collect and lay up stores or wealth, treasure, Mt. 6:19, 20; Lk. 12:21; 2 Cor. 12:14; Jas. 5:3; to heap up, accumulate, Rom. 2:5; 1 Cor. 16:2; to reserve, keep in store, 2 Pet. 3:7

θησαυρος.definition: a treasury, a store, treasure, precious deposit, Mt. 6:19, 20, 21; a receptacle in which precious articles are kept, a casket, Mt. 2:11; a storehouse, Mt. 12:35

θιγγανω.definition: to touch, Col. 2:21; Heb. 12:20; to harm, Heb. 11:28*

θλιβω.definition: to squeeze, press; to press upon, encumber, throng, crowd, Mk. 3:9; met. to distress, afflict, 2 Cor. 1:6; 4:8; pass. to be compressed, narrow, Mt. 7:14

θλιψις.definition: pr. pressure, compression; met. affliction, distress of mind, 2 Cor. 2:4; distressing circumstances, trial, affliction, Mt. 25:9

θνησκω.definition: to die; in NT to be dead, Mt. 2:20; Mk. 15:44

θνητος.definition: mortal, subject to death, Rom. 6:12; 8:11; 2 Cor. 4:11; τὸ θνητόν, mortality, 1 Cor. 15:53, 54; 2 Cor. 5:4*

θορυβεω.definition: to make a din, uproar; trans. to disturb, throw into commotion, Acts 17:5; in NT mid. to manifest agitation of mind, to raise a lament, Mt. 9:23; Mk. 5:39; Acts 20:10*

θορυβος.definition: an uproar, din; an outward expression of mental agitation, outcry, Mk. 5:38; a tumult, commotion, Mt. 26:5

θραυω.definition: to break, shiver; met., shattered, crushed by cruel oppression, Lk. 4:18*

θρεμμα.definition: that which is reared (especially sheep and goats); pl. cattle, Jn. 4:12*

θρηνεω.definition: to lament, bewail, Mt. 11:17; Lk. 7:32; 23:27; Jn. 16:20*

θρησκεια.definition: religious worship, Col. 2:18; religion, a religious system, Acts 26:5; religion, piety, Jas. 1:26, 27*

θριαμβευω.definition: pr. to celebrate a triumph; trans. to lead in triumph, celebrate a triumph over, Col. 2:15; in NT to cause to triumph, or, to render conspicuous, 2 Cor. 2:14*

θριξ.definition: a hair; the hair of the head, Mt. 5:36; 10:30; of an animal, Mt. 3:4; Mk. 1:6

θροεω.definition: to cry aloud; in NT pass., to be disturbed, disquieted, alarmed, terrified, Mt. 24:6; Mk. 13:7; 2 Thess. 2:2*

θρομβος.definition: a lump; esp. a clot of blood, drop, Lk. 22:44*

θρονος.definition: a seat, a throne, Mt. 5:34; 19:28; Lk. 1:52; meton. power, dominion, Lk. 1:32; Heb. 1:8; a potentate, Col. 1:16

θυατειρα.definition: Thyatira, a city of Lydia, Acts 16:14; Rev. 1:11; 2:18, 24*. See PhotoGuide.

θυγατηρ.definition: a daughter, Mt. 9:18; 10:35, 37; in the vocative, an expression of affection and kindness, Mt. 9:22; from the Hebrew, one of the female posterity of any one, Lk. 1:5; met. a city, Mt. 21:5; Jn. 12:15; pl. female inhabitants, Lk. 23:28

θυγατριον.definition: a little daughter, female child, Mk. 5:23; 7:25*

θυινος.definition: thyme, of θυία, thya, an aromatic evergreen tree, arbor vitae, resembling the cedar, and found in Libya, Rev. 18:12*

θυμιαμα.definition: incense, any odoriferous substance burnt in religious worship, Rev. 5:8; 8:3, 4; 18:13; or, the act of burning incense, Lk. 1:10, 11*

θυμιατηριον.definition: an altar of burning incense, Heb. 9:4*

θυμομαχεω.definition: to wage war fiercely; to be warmly hostile to, be enraged against, Acts 12:20*

θυμος.definition: pr. the soul, mind; hence, a strong passion or emotion of the mind; anger, wrath, Lk. 4:28; Acts 19:28; pl. swellings of anger, 2 Cor. 12:20; Gal. 5:20

θυμοω.definition: to provoke to anger; pass. to be angered, enraged, Mt. 2:16*

θυρα.definition: a door, gate, Mt. 6:6; Mk. 1:33; an entrance, Mt. 27:60; in NT met. an opening, occasion, opportunity, Acts 14:27; 1 Cor. 16:9; meton. a medium or means of entrance, Jn. 10:7, 9

θυρεος.definition: a stone or other material employed to close a doorway; later, a large oblong shield, Eph. 6:16*

θυρις.definition: a small opening; a window, Acts 20:9; 2 Cor. 11:33*

θυσια.definition: sacrifice, the act of sacrificing, Heb. 9:26; the thing sacrificed, a victim, Mt. 9:13; 12:7; the flesh of victims eaten by the sacrificers, 1 Cor. 10:18; in NT an offering or service to God, Phil. 4:18

θυσιαστηριον.definition: an altar, Mt. 5:23, 24; Lk. 1:11; spc. the altar of burnt-offering, Mt. 23:35; Lk. 11:51; meton. a class of sacrifices, Heb. 13:10

θυω.definition: to offer; to kill in sacrifice, sacrifice, immolate, Acts 14:13, 18; in NT to slaughter for food, Mt. 22:4

θωραξ.definition: a breast-plate, armor for the body, consisting of two parts, one covering the breast and the other the back, Eph. 6:14; 1 Thess. 5:8; Rev. 9:9, 17*

ιαιρος.definition: also spelled Ἰάειρος, Jairus, pr. name, Mk. 5:22; Lk. 8:41*

ιακωβ.definition: Jacob, pr. name, indecl. (1) Son of Issac, Matt 1:2. (2) Father of Joseph, Mary’s husband, Matt 1:15, 16

ιακωβος.definition: James, pr. name (1) Son of Zebedee, Mt. 4:21. (2) Son of Alphaeus and Mary, brother of Jude, Mt. 10:3. (3) James the less, brother of Jesus, Gal. 1:19

ιαομαι.definition: to heal, cure, Mt. 8:8; Lk. 9:2; met. to heal, spiritually, restore from a state of sin and condemnation, Mt. 13:15; Heb. 12:13

ιασπις.definition: jasper, a precious stone of various colors, as purple, cerulian green, etc. Rev. 4:3; 21:11, 18, 19*

ιδε.definition: the imperative of εἶδον used as a particle, Lo! Behold! Jn. 16:29; 19:4, 5

ιδιος.definition: one’s own, Mk. 15:20; Jn. 7:18; due, proper, specially assigned, Gal. 6:9; 1 Tim. 2:6; 6:15; Tit. 1:3; also used in NT as a simple possessive, Eph. 5:22; τὰ ἴδια, one’s home, household, people, Jn. 1:11; 16:32; 19:17; οἱ ἴδιοι, members of one’s own household, friends, Jn. 1:11; Acts 24:23; ἰδίᾳ, adverbially, respectively, 1 Cor. 12:11; κατ’ ἰδίαν, adv., privately, aside, by one’s self, alone, Mt. 14:13, 23

ιδιωτης.definition: pr. one in private life, one devoid of special learning or gifts, a plain person, Acts 4:13; 2 Cor. 11:6; ungifted, 1 Cor. 14:16, 23, 24*

ιδου.definition: aorist middle imperative of εἶδον used as an interjection, Look! See! Lo! Mt. 1:23; Lk. 1:38; Acts 8:36

ιδουμαια.definition: Idumaea, a country south of Judea, Mk. 3:8*

ιεζαβελ.definition: Jezebel, (1 Ki. 16:31), pr. name, indecl., Rev. 2:20*

ιεραπολις.definition: Hierapolis, a city of Phrygia, Col. 4:13*. See PhotoGuide.

ιερατευμα.definition: a priesthood; meton. a body of priests, 1 Pet. 2:5, 9*

ιερατευω.definition: to officiate as a priest, perform sacred rites, Lk. 1:8*

ιερευς.definition: a priest, one who performs sacrificial rites, Mt. 8:4; Lk. 1:5; Jn. 1:19

ιεριχω.definition: Jericho, a city of Palestine, Mt. 20:29; Mk. 10:46; Lk. 10:30; 18:35; 19:1; Heb. 11:30*. See PhotoGuide.

ιερος.definition: holy, divine, set apart, 2 Tim. 3:15; tὰ ἱερά, sacred rites, 1 Cor. 9:13*

ιεροσολυμιτης.definition: a native of Jerusalem, Mk. 1:5; Jn. 7:25*

ιεροσυλεω.definition: to despoil temples, commit sacrilege, Rom. 2:22*

ιεροσυλος.definition: one who despoils temples, commits sacrilege, Acts 19:37*

ιερουργεω.definition: to officiate as priest, perform sacred rites; in NT to minister in a divine commission, Rom. 15:16*

ιερουσαλημ.definition: Jerusalem, pr. name, indecl., also spelled Ἱεροσόλυμα 62x in our text. See PhotoGuide.

ιεσσαι.definition: Jesse, father of David (1 Sam. 16), pr. name, indecl., Mt. 1:5f.; Lk. 3:32; Acts 13:22; Rom. 15:12*

ιησους.definition: a Savior, Jesus, Mt. 1:21, 25; 2:1, et al. freq.; Joshua, Acts 7:45; Heb. 4:8; Jesus, a Jewish Christian, Col. 4:11

ικανος.definition: befitting; sufficient, enough, Lk. 22:38; ἱκανὸν ποιεῖν τινί, to satisfy, gratify, Mk. 15:15; τὸ ἱκανὸν λαμβάνειν, to take security or bail of any one, Acts 17:9; or persons, adequate, competent, qualified, 2 Cor. 2:16; fit, worthy, Mt. 3:11; 8:8; of number or quantity, considerable, large, great, much, and pl. many, Mt. 28:12; Mk. 10:46

ικανοω.definition: to make sufficient or competent, qualify, 2 Cor. 3:6; Col. 1:12*

ικετηρια.definition: pr. an olive branch borne by suppliants in their hands; prayer, supplication, Heb. 5:7*

ικονιον.definition: Iconium, a city of Lycaonia, in Asia Minor, Acts 13:51; 14:1, 19, 21; 16:2; 2 Tim. 3:11*. See PhotoGuide.

ιλασκομαι.definition: to appease, render propitious; in NT to expiate, make an atonement or expiation for, Heb. 2:17; ἱλάσθητι, be gracious, show mercy, pardon, Lk. 18:13*

ιλασμος.definition: atoning sacrifice, sin offering, propitiation, expiation; one who makes propitiation/expiation, 1 Jn. 2:2; 4:10*

ιλαστηριον.definition: the cover of the ark of the covenant, the mercy-seat, the place of propitiation, Rom. 3:25; Heb. 9:5*

ιλεως.definition: propitious, favorable, merciful, gracious, Heb. 8:12; from the Hebrew, ἵλεως σοι (ὁ θεός) God have mercy on thee, God forbid, far be it from thee, Mt. 16:22*

ιλλυρικον.definition: Illyricum, a country between the Adriatic and the Danube, Rom. 15:19*

ιμας.definition: a strap or thong of leather, Acts 22:25; a shoe-latchet, Mk. 1:7; Lk. 3:16; Jn. 1:27*

ιματιζω.definition: to clothe; pass. to be clothed, Mk. 5:15; Lk. 8:35*

ιματιον.definition: a garment; the upper garment, mantle, Mt. 5:40; 9:16, 20, 21; pl. the mantle and tunic together, Mt. 26:65; pl. genr. garments, raiment, Mt. 11:8; 24:18

ιματισμος.definition: garment; raiment, apparel, clothing, Lk. 7:25; 9:29; Jn. 19:24; Acts 20:33; 1 Tim. 2:9*

ινα.definition: that, in order that, Mt. 19:13; Mk. 1:38; Jn. 1:22; 3:15; 17:1; ἵνα μή, that not, lest, Mt. 7:1; in NT equivalent to ὥστε, so that, so as that, Jn. 9:2; also, marking a simple circumstance, the circumstance that, Mt. 10:25; Jn. 4:34; 6:29; 1 Jn. 4:17; 5:3

ινατι.definition: Why is it that? For what reason? Why? Mt. 9:4; 27:46; Lk. 13:7; Acts 4:25; 7:26; 1 Cor. 10:29*

ιοππη.definition: Joppa, a city of Palestine, Acts 9:36, 38, 42f.; 10:5, 8, 23, 32; 11:5, 13*. See PhotoGuide.

ιορδανης.definition: the river Jordan, Mt. 3:5; Mk. 10:1; Lk. 4:1; Jn. 3:26

ιος.definition: a missile weapon, arrow, dart; venom, poison, Rom. 3:13; Jas. 3:8; rust, Jas. 5:3*

ιουδαια.definition: Judea, the southern party of the country, below Samaria, Mt. 2:1, 5, 22; 3:1; meton. the inhabitants of Judea

ιουδαικος.definition: Jewish, current among the Jews, Tit. 1:14*

ιουδαικως.definition: in the manner of Jews, according to Jewish custom, Gal. 2:14*

ιουδαιος.definition: Jewish, Mk. 1:5; Jn. 3:22; Acts 16:1; 24:24; pr. one sprung from the tribe of Judah, or a subject of the kingdom of Judah; in NT a descendant of Jacob, a Jew, Mt. 28:15; Mk. 7:3; Acts 19:34; Rom. 2:28, 29

ιουδαισμος.definition: Judaism, the character and condition of a Jew; practice of the Jewish religion, Gal. 1:13, 14*

ιουδας.definition: Judas, Jude, pr. name. (1) Judah, son of Jacob; the tribe of Judah, Mt. 1:2; Lk. 1:39. (2) Juda, son of Joseph, of the ancestry of Jesus, Lk. 3:30. (3) Juda, son of Joanna, of the ancestry of Jesus, Lk. 3:26. (4) Judas, brother of James, Jude, Lk. 6:16; Jude 1. (5) Judas Iscariot, son of Simon, Mt. 10:4; Jn. 6:71. (6) Judas, brother of Jesus, Mt. 13:55; Mk. 6:3. (7) Judas of Galilee, Acts 5:37 . (8) Judas, surnamed Barsabas, Acts 15:22. (9) Judas of Damascus, Acts 9:11

ιουστος.definition: Justus, pr. name (1) Joseph Barsabas, Acts 1:23 (2) Justus of Corinth, Acts 18:7 (3) Jesus, called Justus, Col. 4:11*

ιππευς.definition: a horseman; pl. ἱππεῖς, horsemen, cavalry, Acts 23:23, 32*

ιππικος.definition: equestrian; τὸ ἱππικόν, cavalry, horse, Rev. 9:16*

ισαακ.definition: Isaac, pr. name, indecl., Mt. 1:2; 8:11; 23:32; Acts 3:13;. Rom. 9:7f.; Gal. 4:28; Heb. 11:9ff.; Jas. 2:21

ισαγγελος.definition: equal or similar to angels, Lk. 20:36*

ισος.definition: equal, like, Mt. 20:12; Lk. 6:34; on an equality, Phil. 2:6; met. correspondent, consistent, Mk. 14:56, 59

ισοτης.definition: equality, equal proportion, 2 Cor. 8:13, 14; fairness, equity, what is equitable, Col. 4:1*

ισοτιμος.definition: of equal price, equally precious or valuable, 2 Pet. 1:1*

ισοψυχος.definition: likeminded, of the same mind and spirit, Phil. 2:20*

ισραηλιτης.definition: an Israelite, a descendant of Ἰσραήλ, Israel or Jacob, Jn. 1:47; Acts 2:22

ιστημι.definition: pluperfect, ἑστάμην, also formed as στήκω 10x, trans. to make to stand, set, place, Mt. 4:5; to set forth, appoint, Acts 1:23; to fix, appoint, Acts 17:31; to establish, confirm, Rom. 10:3; Heb. 10:9; to set down, impute, Acts 7:60; to weigh out, pay, Mt. 26:15; intrans. to stand, Mt. 12:46; to stand fast, be firm, be permanent, endure, Mt. 12:25; Eph. 6:13; to be confirmed, proved, Mt. 18:16; 2 Cor. 13:1; to stop, Lk. 7:14; 8:44; Acts 8:38

ιστορεω.definition: to ascertain by inquiry and examination; to inquire of; in NT to visit in order to become acquainted with, Gal. 1:18*

ισχυρος.definition: strong, mighty, robust, Mt. 12:29; Lk. 11:21; powerful, mighty, 1 Cor. 1:27; 4:10; 1 Jn. 2:14; strong, fortified, Rev. 18:10; vehement, Mt. 14:20; energetic, 2 Cor. 10:10; sure, firm, Heb. 6:18

ισχυς.definition: strength, might, power, Rev. 18:2; Eph. 1:19; faculty, ability, 1 Pet. 4:11; Mk. 12:30, 33; Lk. 10:27

ισχυω.definition: to be strong, be well, be in good health, Mt. 9:12; to have power, be able, Mt. 8:28; 26:40; to have power or efficiency, avail, be valid, Gal. 5:6; Heb. 9:17; to be of service, be serviceable, Mt. 5:13; meton. to prevail, Acts 19:16; Rev. 12:8

ισως.definition: equally; perhaps, it may be that, Lk. 20:13*

ιτουραιος.definition: Ituraea, a district of Palestine beyond Jordan, Lk. 3:1*

ιξνος.definition: a footstep, track; in NT pl. footsteps, line of conduct, Rom. 4:12; 2 Cor. 12:18; 1 Pet. 2:21*

g2490.definition: also spelled Ἰωάνα, Joanna, pr. name, Lk. 8:3; 24:10*

ιωαννης.definition: also spelled Ἰωάνης, Joannes, John, pr. name (1) John the Baptist, Mt. 3:1, et al. (2) John, son of Zebedee, the apostle, Mt. 4:21, et al. (3) John, surnamed Mark, Acts 12:12, et al. (4) John, the high-priest, Acts 4:6

ιωβηδ.definition: Obed, David’s grandfather, pr. name, indecl., Mt. 1:5; Lk. 3:32*

ιωηλ.definition: Joel, an Old Testament prophet, pr. name, indecl., Acts 2:16*

ιωνας.definition: Jonas, pr. name Jonah, the prophet, Mt. 12:39; Lk. 11:29

ιωραμ.definition: Joram, king of Judah (2 Ki. 8:16ff.), pr. name, indecl., Mt. 1:8*

ιωσαφατ.definition: Josaphat, king of Judah (1 Ki. 22:41), pr. name, indecl., Mt. 1:8*

ιωσης.definition: Joses, Joseph pr. name Mt. 27:56; Mk. 6:3; 15:40, 47*

ιωσηφ.definition: Joseph, pr. name, indecl. (1) Joseph, son of Jacob, Jn. 4:5. (2) Joseph, son of Jonan, Lk. 3:30. (3) Joseph, son of Judas, Lk. 3:26. (4) Joseph, son of Mattathias, Lk. 3:24. (5) Joseph, the husband of Mary, Mt. 1:16. (6) Joseph of Arimathea, Mt. 27:57. (7) Joseph Barsabas, Acts 1:23. (8) Joseph Barnabas, Acts 4:36

ιωσιας.definition: Josiah, king of Judah (2 Ki. 22), Mt. 1:10, 11*

ιωτα.definition: iota; in NT used like the Hebrew/Aramaic yod, the smallest letter in the Hebrew/Aramaic alphabet, as an expression for the least or minutest part; a jot, Mt. 5:18*

καγω.definition: and I, I also, but I, a crasis of καί and ἐγώ, dat., κἀμοί, acc., κἀμέ

καθα.definition: can function as an adverb, just as, Mt. 27:10*

καθαιρεω.definition: take or bring down, Mk. 15:36, 46; Lk. 1:52; 23:53; Acts 13:29; tear down, destroy, Lk. 12:18; Acts 13:19; 19:27; 2 Cor. 10:4*

καθαιρω.definition: to cleanse from filth; to clear by pruning, prune, Jn. 15:2; met. to cleanse from sin, make expiation

καθαπτω.definition: trans. to fasten or fit to; in NT equivalent to καθάπτομαι, to fix one’s self upon, fasten upon, take hold of, seize, Acts 28:3*

καθαριζω.definition: to cleanse, render pure, purify, Mt. 23:25; Lk. 11:39; to cleanse from leprosy, Mt. 8:2, 3; 10:8; met. to cleanse from sin, purify by an expiatory offering, make expiation for, Heb. 9:22, 23; 1 Jn. 1:7; to cleanse from sin, free from the influence of error and sin, Acts 15:9; 2 Cor. 7:1; to pronounce ceremonially clean, Acts 10:15; 11:9

καθαρισμος.definition: ceremonial cleansing, purification, Lk. 2:22; 5:14; mode of purification, Jn. 2:6; 3:25; cleansing of lepers, Mk. 1:44; met. expiation, Heb. 1:3; 2 Pet. 1:9*

καθαρος.definition: clean, pure, unsoiled, Mt. 23:26; 27:59; met. clean from guilt, guiltless, innocent, Acts 18:6; 20:26; sincere, upright, virtuous, void of evil, Mt. 5:8; Jn. 15:3; clean ceremonially and morally, Lk. 11:41

καθεζομαι.definition: to seat one’s self, sit down, Mt. 26:55; Lk. 2:46; Jn. 4:6; 1:20; 20:12; Acts 6:15; 20:9*

καθεξης.definition: in a continual order or series, successively, consecutively, Lk. 1:3; Acts 11:4; 18:23; ὁ, ἡ, καθεξῆς, succeeding, subsequent, Lk. 8:1; Acts 3:24*

καθευδω.definition: to sleep, be fast asleep, Mt. 8:24; 9:24; met. to sleep in spiritual sloth, Eph. 5:14; 1 Thess. 5:6; to sleep the sleep of death, to die, 1 Thess. 5:10

καθηγητης.definition: pr. a guide, leader; in NT a teacher, instructor, Mt. 23:10*

καθηκω.definition: to reach, extend to; καθήκει, impers. it is fitting, meet, Acts 22:22; τὸ καθῆκον, what is fit, right, duty; τὰ μὴ καθήκοντα, by litotes for what is abominable or detestable, Rom. 1:28*

καθημαι.definition: to sit, be sitting, Mt. 9:9; Lk. 10:13; to be seated, 1 Cor. 14:30; to be enthroned, Rev. 18:7; to dwell, reside, Mt. 4:16; Lk. 1:79; 21:35

καθιζω.definition: (1) trans. to cause to sit, place; καθίζομαι, to be seated, sit, Mt. 19:28; Lk. 22:30; to cause to sit as judges, place, appoint, 1 Cor. 6:4; (2) intrans. to sit, sit down, Mt. 13:48; 26:36; to remain, settle, stay, continue, live, Lk. 24:49

καθιημι.definition: to let down, lower, Lk. 5:19; Acts 9:25; 10:11; 11:5*

καθιστημι.definition: also formed as καθιστάνω, to place, set, Jas. 3:6; to set, constitute, appoint, Mt. 24:45, 47; Lk. 12:14; to set down in a place, conduct, Acts 17:15; to make, render, or cause to be, 2 Pet. 1:8; pass. to be rendered, Rom. 5:19

καθο.definition: as, Rom. 8:26; according as, in proportion as, to the degree that, 2 Cor. 8:12; 1 Pet. 4:13*

καθολου.definition: on the whole, entirely, in general, altogether, completely; with a negative, not at all, Acts 4:18*

καθοραω.definition: pr. to look down upon, in the NT to mark, perceive, discern, Rom. 1:20*

καθοτι.definition: as, just as, according as, in proportion as, Acts 2:45; 4:35; inasmuch as, Lk. 1:7; 19:9; Acts 2:24; 17:31*

καθως.definition: as, just as, in the manner that, Mt. 21:6; 26:24; how, in what manner, Acts 15:14; according as, Mk. 4:33; inasmuch as, Jn. 17:2; of time, when, Acts 7:17

και.definition: (1) and, Mt. 2:2, 3, 11; 4:22; (2) καί ... καί, both ... and; (3) as a cumulative particle, also, too, Mt. 5:39; Jn. 8:19; 1 Cor. 11:6; (4) emphatic, even, also, Mt. 10:30; 1 Cor. 2:10; in NT adversative, but, Mt. 11:19; also introductory of the apodosis of a sentence, Gal. 3:28; Jas. 2:4

καιαφας.definition: Caiaphas, pr. name, the high priest from A.D. 18-36, Mt. 26:3, 57; Lk. 3:2; Jn. 11:49; 18:13f., 24, 28; Acts 4:6*

καιν.definition: Cain, pr. name, indecl., Heb. 11:4; 1 Jn. 3:12; Jude 11*

καινος.definition: new, recently made, Mt. 9:17; Mk. 2:22; new in species, character, or mode, Mt. 26:28, 29; Mk. 14:24, 25; Lk. 22:20; Jn. 13:34; 2 Cor. 5:17; Gal. 6:15; Eph. 2:15; 4:24; 1 Jn. 2:7; Rev. 3:12; novel, strange, Mk. 1:27; Acts 17:19; new to the possessor, Mk. 16:17; unheard of, unusual, Mk. 1:27; Acts 17:19; met. renovated, better, of higher excellence, 2 Cor. 5:17; Rev. 5:9

καιρος.definition: pr. fitness, proportion, suitableness; a fitting situation, suitable place, 1 Pet. 4:17; a limited period of time marked by a suitableness of circumstances, a fitting season, 1 Cor. 4:5; 1 Tim. 2:6; 6:15; Tit. 1:3; opportunity, Acts 24:25; Gal. 6:10; Heb. 11:15; a limited period of time marked by characteristic circumstances, a signal juncture, a marked season, Mt. 16:3; Lk. 12:56; 21:8; 1 Pet. 1:11; a destined time, Mt. 8:29; 26:18; Mk. 1:15; Lk. 21:24; 1 Thess. 5:1; a season in ordinary succession, equivalent to ὥρα, Mt. 13:30; Acts 14:17; in NT a limited time, a short season, Lk. 4:13; simply, a point of time, Mt. 11:25; Lk. 13:1

καισαρεια.definition: Caesarea (1) Caesarea Philippi, Mt. 16:13; Mk. 8:27; (2) Caesarea Augusta, Acts 8:40

καιτοι.definition: and yet, though, although, Acts 14:17; Heb. 4:3*

καιω.definition: to cause to burn, kindle, light, Mt. 5:15; pass. to be kindled, burn, flame, Lk. 12:35; met. to be kindled into emotion, Lk. 24:32; to consume with fire, Jn. 15:6; 1 Cor. 13:3

κακει.definition: crasis, and there, Mt. 5:23; 10:11; there also, Acts 17:13

κακειθεν.definition: crasis, and there, Mk. 10:1; Acts 7:4; 14:26; 20:15; 21:1; 27:4, 12; 28:15; and then, afterwards, Acts 13:21

κακεινος.definition: crasis, and he, she, it; and this, and that, Mt. 15:18; 23:23; he, she, it also; this also, that also, Mt. 20:4

κακια.definition: malice, malignity, Rom. 1:29; Eph. 4:31; wickedness, depravity, Acts 8:22; 1 Cor. 5:8; in NT evil, trouble, calamity, misfortune, Mt. 6:34

κακοηθεια.definition: disposition for mischief, misfortune, malignity, Rom. 1:29*

κακολογεω.definition: to speak evil of, revile, abuse, insult, Mk. 9:39; Acts 19:9; to address with offensive language, to treat with disrespect, Matt, 15:4; Mk. 7:10*

κακοπαθεια.definition: a state of suffering, affliction, trouble, in NT endurance in affliction, perseverance, Jas. 5:10*

κακοπαθεω.definition: to suffer evil or afflictions, 2 Tim. 2:9; to be afflicted, troubled, dejected, Jas. 5:13; in NT to show endurance in trials and afflictions, 2 Tim. 4:5*

κακοποιεω.definition: to cause evil, injure, do harm, Mk. 3:4; Lk. 6:9; to do evil, commit sin, 1 Pet. 3:17; 3 Jn. 11*

κακος.definition: bad, of a bad quality or disposition, worthless, corrupt, depraved, Mt. 21:41; 24:48; Mk. 7:21; wicked, criminal, morally bad; τὸ κακόν, evil, wickedness, crime, Mt. 27:23; Acts 23:9; deceitful, 1 Pet. 3:10; mischievous, harmful, destructive; τὸ κακόν, evil mischief, harm, injury, Tit. 1:12; afflictive; τὸ κακόν, evil, misery, affliction, suffering, Lk. 16;25

κακουργος.definition: an evil-doer, malefactor, criminal, Lk. 23:32, 33, 39; 2 Tim. 2:9*

κακουχεω.definition: to torment, afflict, harass; pass. to be afflicted, be oppressed with evils, Heb. 11:37 13:3*

κακοω.definition: to harm, mistreat, cause evil to, oppress, Acts 7:6, 19; 12:1; 18:10; 1 Pet. 3:13; in NT to make angry, embitter, Acts 14:2*

κακως.definition: ill, badly; physically ill, sick, Mt. 4:24; 8:16; grievously, vehemently, Mt. 15:22; wretchedly, miserably, Mt. 21:41; wickedly, reproachfully, Acts 23:5; wrongly, criminally, Jn. 18:23; amiss, Jas. 4:3

κακωσις.definition: ill treatment, affliction, oppression, misery, Acts 7:34*

καλαμη.definition: the stalk of grain, straw, stubble, 1 Cor. 3:12*

καλαμος.definition: a reed, cane, Mt. 11:7; 12:20; Lk. 7:24; a reed in its various appliances, as, a wand, a staff, Mt. 27:29, 30, 48; Mk. 15:19, 36; a measuring-rod, Rev. 11:1; 21:15f.; a writer’s reed, 3 Jn. 13*

καλεω.definition: to call, call to, Jn. 10:3; to call into one’s presence, send for a person, Mt. 2:7; to summon, Mt. 2:15; 25:14; to invite, Mt. 22:9; to call to the performance of a certain thing, Mt. 9:13; Heb. 11:8; to call to a participation in the privileges of the Gospel, Rom. 8:30; 9:24; 1 Cor. 1:9; 7:18; to call to an office or dignity, Heb. 5:4; to name, style, Mt. 1:21; pass. to be styled, regarded, Mt. 5:9, 19

καλλιελαιος.definition: pr. adj. productive of good oil; as subst. a cultivated olive tree, Rom. 11:24*

καλοδιδασκαλος.definition: teaching what is good; a teacher of good, Tit. 2:3*

καλοποιεω.definition: to do well, do good, do what is right, 2 Thess. 3:13*

g2570.definition: pr. beautiful; good, of good quality or disposition; fertile, rich, Mt. 13:8, 23; useful, profitable, Lk. 14:34; καλόν ἐστι[ν], it is profitable, it is well, Mt. 18:8, 9; excellent, choice, select, goodly, Mt. 7:17, 19; καλόν ἐστι[ν], it is pleasant, delightful, Mt. 17:4; just, full measure, Lk. 6:38; honorable, distinguished, Jas. 2:7; good, possessing moral excellence, worthy, upright, virtuous, Jn. 10:11, 14; 1 Tim. 4:6; τὸ καλόν, and τὸ καλόν ἔργον, what is good and right, a good deed, rectitude, virtue, Mt. 5:16; Rom. 7:18, 21; right, duty, propriety, Mt. 15:26; benefit, favor, Jn. 10:32, 33

καλυμμα.definition: a covering; a veil, 2 Cor. 3:13; met. a veil, a blind to spiritual vision, 2 Cor. 3:14, 15, 16*

καλυπτω.definition: to cover, Mt. 8:24; Lk. 8:16; 23:30; to hide, conceal, Mt. 10:26; 2 Cor. 4:3; met. to cover, throw a veil of oblivion over, Jas. 5:20; 1 Pet. 4:8

καλως.definition: well, rightly, suitable, with propriety, becomingly, 1 Cor. 7:37; 14:17; Gal. 4:17; 5:7; truly, justly, correctly, Mk. 12:32; Lk. 20:39; Jn. 4:17; appositely, Mt. 15:7; Mk. 7:6; becomingly, honorably, Jas. 2:3; well, effectually, Mk. 7:9, 37; καλῶς εἰπεῖν, to speak well, praise, applaud, Lk. 6:26; καλῶς ἔχειν, to be convalescent, Mk. 16:18; καλῶς ποιεῖν, to do good, confer benefits, Mt. 5:44; 12:12; to do well, act virtuously, Phil. 4:14

καμινος.definition: a furnace, oven, kiln, Mt. 13:42, 50; Rev. 1:15; 9:2*

καμμυω.definition: to shut, close the eyes, Mt. 13:15; Acts 28:27*

καμνω.definition: to tire with exertion, labor to weariness; to be wearied, tired out, exhausted, be discouraged, Heb. 12:3; to labor under disease, be sick, Jas. 5:15*

καμπτω.definition: trans. to bend, inflect the knee, Rom. 11:4; Eph. 3:14 intrans. to bend, bow, Rom. 14:11; Phil. 2:10*

καν.definition: crasis, and if, Mk. 16:18; also if, Mt. 21:21; even if, if even, although, Jn. 10:38; if so much as, Heb. 12:20; also in NT simply equivalent to καί, as a particle of emphasis, by a pleonasm of ἄν, at least, at all events, Mk. 6:56; Acts 5:15; 2 Cor. 11:16

κανα.definition: indecl. Cana, a town in Galilee, Jn. 2:1, 11; 4:46; 21:2*. See PhotoGuide.

κανων.definition: a measure, rule; in NT prescribed range of action or duty, 2 Cor. 10:13, 15, 16; met. rule of conduct or doctrine, Gal. 6:16*

καπηλευω.definition: pr. to be κάπηλος, a retailer; to peddle with; to corrupt, adulterate, 2 Cor. 2:17*

καππαδοκια.definition: Cappadocia, a district of Asia Minor, Acts 2:9; 1 Pet. 1:1*

καρδια.definition: the heart, regarded as the seat of feeling, impulse, affection, desire, Mt. 6:21; 22:37; Phil. 1:7; the heart, as the seat of intellect, Mt. 13:15; Rom. 1:21; the heart, as the inner and mental frame, Mt. 5:8; Lk. 16:15; 1 Pet. 3:4; the conscience, 1 Jn. 3:20, 21; the heart, the inner part, middle, center, Mt. 12:40

καρπος.definition: fruit, Mt. 3:10; 21:19, 34; from the Hebrew, καρπὸς κοιλίας, fruit of the womb, offspring, Lk. 1:42; καρπὸς ὀσφύος, fruit of the loins, offspring, posterity, Acts 2:30; καρπὸς χειλέων, fruit of the lips, praise, Heb. 13:15; met. conduct, actions, Mt. 3:8; 7:16; Rom. 6:22; benefit, profit, Rom. 1:13; 6:21; reward, Phil. 4:17

καρποφορεω.definition: to bear fruit, yield, Mk. 4:28; met, to bring forth the fruit of action or conduct, Mt. 13:23; Rom. 7:5; mid. to expand by fruitfulness, to develop itself by success, Col. 1:6, 10

καρποφορος.definition: fruitful, adapted to bring forth fruit, Acts 14:17*

καρτερεω.definition: to be stout; to endure patiently, persevere, bear up with fortitude, Heb. 11:27*

καρφος.definition: any small dry thing, as chaff, stubble, splinter; Mt. 7:3, 4, 5; Lk. 6:41, 42*

κατα.definition: down from, Mt. 8:32; down upon, upon, Mk. 14:3; Acts 27:14; down into; κατὰ βάθους, profound, deepest, 2 Cor. 8:2; down over, throughout a space, Lk. 4:14; 23:5; concerning, in cases of pointed allegation, 1 Cor. 15:15; against, Mt. 12:30; by, in oaths, Mt. 26:63; with an acc. of place, in the quarter of, about, near, at, Lk. 10;32; Acts 2:10; throughout, Lk. 8:39; in, Rom. 16:5; among, Acts 21:21; in the presence of, Lk. 2:31; in the direction of, towards, Acts 8:26; Phil. 3:14; of time, within the range of; during, in the course of, at, about, Acts 12:1; 27:27; distributively, κατ’ οἶκον, by houses, from house to house, Acts 2:46; kata; duvo, two and two, 1 Cor. 14:27; καθ’ ἡμέραν, daily, Mt. 26:55; trop., according to, conformable to, in proportion to, Mt. 9:29; 25:15; after the fashion or likeness of. Heb. 5:6; in virtue of, Mt. 19:3; as respects, Rom. 11:3; Acts 25;14; Heb. 9:9

καταβαινω.definition: to come or go down, descend, Mt. 8:1; 17:9; to lead down, Acts 8:26; to come down, fall, Mt. 7:25, 27; to be let down, Acts 10:11; 11:5

καταβαλλω.definition: to cast down, 2 Cor. 4:9; mid. to lay down, lay a foundation, Heb. 6:1*

καταβαρεω.definition: pr. to weigh down, met. to burden, be burdensome to, 2 Cor. 12:16*

καταβαρυνω.definition: to weigh down, depress, pass., be heavy, Mk. 14:40*

καταβασις.definition: the act of descending; a way down, descent, Lk. 19:37*

καταβολη.definition: pr. a casting down; laying the foundation, foundation; beginning, commencement, Mt. 13:35; 25:34; conception in the womb, Heb. 11:11

καταβραβευω.definition: pr. to give an unfavorable decision as respects a prize; hence, to decide against, Col. 2:18*

καταγγελευς.definition: one who announces anything, a proclaimer, publisher, Acts 17:18*

καταγγελλω.definition: to announce, proclaim, Acts 13:38; in NT to laud, celebrate, Rom. 1:8

καταγελαω.definition: to deride, laugh at, jeer, Mt. 9:24; Mk. 5:40; Lk. 8:53*

καταγινωσκω.definition: to determine against, condemn, blame, reprehend, Gal. 2:11; 1 Jn. 3:20, 21

καταγνυμι.definition: to break in pieces, crush, break in two, Mt. 12:20; Jn. 19:31, 32, 33*

καταγραφω.definition: to trace, draw in outline, write, Jn. 8:6*

καταγω.definition: to lead, bring, or conduct down, Acts 9:30; 22:30; 23:15, 20, 28; to bring a ship to land; pass. κατάγομαι, aor. κατήχθην, to come to land, land, touch, Lk. 5:11

καταγωνιζομαι.definition: to subdue, vanquish, overcome, conquer, Heb. 11:33*

καταδεω.definition: to bind up; to bandage a wound, Lk. 10:34*

καταδικαζω.definition: to give judgment against, condemn, Mt. 12:7, 37; Lk. 6:37; Jas. 5:6*

καταδιωκω.definition: to follow hard upon; to track, search for, follow perseveringly, Mk. 1:36*

καταδουλοω.definition: to reduce to absolute servitude, make a slave of, 2 Cor. 11:20; Gal. 2:4*

καταδυναστευω.definition: to tyrannize over, oppress, exploit, Acts 10:38; Jas. 2:6*

καταθεμα.definition: an execration, curse; by meton. what is worthy of cursing or condemnation, Rev. 22:3*

καταισχυνω.definition: to humiliate, shame, put to shame, 1 Cor. 1:27; pass. to be ashamed, be put to shame, Lk. 13:17; to dishonor, disgrace, 1 Cor. 11:4, 5; from the Hebrew, to frustrate, disappoint, Rom. 5:5; 9:33; 1 Pet. 2:6

κατακαιω.definition: to burn up, consume with fire, Mt. 3:12; 13:30, 40

κατακαλυπτω.definition: to veil; mid. to veil one’s self, be veiled or covered, 1 Cor. 11:6, 7. In the pres act ind., 2nd sg, the personal ending σαι does not simplify as normal, κατακαυχᾶσαι*

κατακαυχαομαι.definition: to boast, glory over, assume superiority over, Rom. 11:18 (2x); Jas. 2:13; 3:14*

κατακειμαι.definition: to lie, be in a recumbent position, be laid down, Mk. 1:30; 2:4; Lk. 5:25; Jn. 5:3, 6; Acts 9:33; 28:8; to recline at table, Mk. 2:15; 14:3; Lk. 5:29; 7:37; 1 Cor. 8:10*

κατακλαω.definition: to break, break in pieces, Mk. 6:41; Lk. 9:16*

κατακλειω.definition: to close, shut fast; to shut up, confine, Lk. 3:20; Acts 26:10*

κατακλινω.definition: to cause to lie down, cause to recline at table, Lk. 9:14, 15; mid. to lie down, recline, Lk. 7:36; 14:8; 24:30*

κατακολουθεω.definition: to follow closely or earnestly, Lk. 23:55; Acts 16:17*

κατακοπτω.definition: to cut or dash in pieces; to mangle, wound, Mk. 5:5*

κατακρινω.definition: to give judgment against, condemn, Mt. 27:3; Jn. 8:10, 11; to condemn, to place in a guilty light by contrast, Mt. 12:41, 42; Lk. 11:31, 32; Heb. 11:7

κατακυριευω.definition: to get into one’s power; in NT to bring under, master, overcome, Acts 19:16; to domineer over, Mt. 20:25; Mk. 10:42; 1 Pet. 5:3*

καταλαλεω.definition: to blab out; to speak against, slander, Jas. 4:11; 1 Pet. 2:12; 3:16*

καταλαλια.definition: evil-speaking, detraction, backbiting, slandering, 2 Cor. 12:20; 1 Pet. 2:1*

καταλαμβανω.definition: to lay hold of, grasp; to obtain, attain, Rom. 9:30; 1 Cor. 9:24; Phil. 3:12, 13; to seize, to take possession of, Mk. 9:18; to come suddenly upon; overtake, surprise, Jn. 12:35; 1 Thess. 5:4; to detect in the act, seize, Jn. 8:3, 4; met. to comprehend, apprehend, Jn. 1:5; mid. to understand, perceive, Acts 4:13; 10:34; 25:25; Eph. 3:18*

καταλεγω.definition: to select, enter in a list or catalog, enroll, 1 Tim. 5:9*

καταλειπω.definition: to leave behind; to leave behind at death, Mk. 12:19; to relinquish, let remain, Mk. 14:52; to quit, depart from, forsake, Mt. 4:13; 16:4; to neglect, Acts 6:2; to leave alone, or without assistance, Lk. 10:40; to reserve, Rom. 11:4

καταλιθαζω.definition: to stone, kill by stoning, Lk. 20:6*

καταλλαγη.definition: pr. an exchange; reconciliation, restoration to favor, Rom. 5:11; 11:15; 2 Cor. 5:18, 19*

καταλλασσω.definition: to change, exchange; to reconcile; pass. to be reconciled, Rom. 5:10 (2x); 1 Cor. 7:11; 2 Cor. 5:18, 19, 20*

καταλοιπος.definition: remaining; οἱ κατάλοιποι, the rest, Acts 15:17*

καταλυμα.definition: lodging, inn, Lk. 2:7; a guest-chamber, Mk. 14:14; Lk. 22:11*

καταλυω.definition: to dissolve; to destroy, demolish, overthrow, throw down, Mt. 24:2; 26:61; met. to nullify, abrogate, Mt. 5:17; Acts 5:38, 39; absol. to unloose harness, etc., to halt, to stop for the night, lodge, Lk. 9:12

καταμανθανω.definition: to learn or observe thoroughly; to consider accurately and diligently, contemplate, Mt. 6:28*

καταμαρτυρεω.definition: to witness or testify against, Mt. 26:62; 27:13; Mk. 14:60*

καταμενω.definition: to remain; to abide, dwell, Acts 1:13*

καταναρκαω.definition: in NT to be burdensome to the disadvantage of any one, to be a dead weight upon; by impl. to be troublesome, burdensome to, in respect of maintenance, 2 Cor. 11:9; 12:13, 14*

κατανευω.definition: pr. to nod, signify assent by a nod; genr. to make signs, beckon, Lk. 5:7*

κατανοεω.definition: to perceive, understand, apprehend, Lk. 20:23; to observe, consider, contemplate, Lk. 12:24, 27; to discern, detect, Mt. 7:3; to have regard to, make account of, Rom. 4:19

κατανταω.definition: to come to, arrive at, Acts 16:1; 20:15; of an epoch, to come upon, 1 Cor. 10:11; met. to reach, attain to, Acts 26:7

κατανυξις.definition: in NT deep sleep, stupor, dullness, Rom. 11:8*

κατανυσσομαι.definition: to pierce through; to pierce with compunction and pain of heart, Acts 2:37*

καταξιοω.definition: to consider worthy of, Lk. 20:35; Acts 5:41; 2 Thess. 1:5*

καταπατεω.definition: to trample upon, tread down or under feet, Mt. 5:13; 7:6; Lk. 8:5; 12:1; met. to trample on by indignity, spurn, Heb. 10:29*

καταπαυσις.definition: pr. the act of giving rest; a state of settled or final rest, Heb. 3:11, 18; 4:1, 3, 4, 5, 11; a place of rest, place of abode, dwelling, habitation, Acts 7:49*

καταπαυω.definition: to cause to cease, restrain, Acts 14:18; to cause to rest, give final rest to, settle finally, Heb. 4:8; intrans. to rest, desist from, Heb. 4:4, 10*

καταπινω.definition: to drink, swallow, gulp down, Mt. 23:24; to swallow up, absorb, Rev. 12:16; 2 Cor. 5:4; to engulf, submerge, overwhelm, Heb. 11:29; to swallow greedily, devour, 1 Pet. 5:8; to destroy, annihilate, 1 Cor. 15:54; 2 Cor. 2:7*

καταπιπτω.definition: to fall down, fall prostrate, Lk. 8:6; Acts 26:14; 28:6*

καταπλεω.definition: to sail towards land, to come to land, Lk. 8:26*

καταπονεω.definition: to exhaust by labor or suffering; to wear out, 2 Pet. 2:7; to overpower, oppress, Acts 7:24*

καταποντιζω.definition: to sink in the sea; pass. to sink, Mt. 14:30; to be plunged, submerged, drowned, Mt. 18:6*

καταρα.definition: a cursing, execration, imprecation, Jas. 3:10; from the Hebrew, condemnation, doom, Gal. 3:10; Heb. 6:8; 2 Pet. 2:14; meton., a doomed one, one on whom condemnation falls, Gal. 3:13*

καταραομαι.definition: to curse, to wish evil to, imprecate evil upon, Mk. 11:21; Lk. 6:28; Rom. 12:14; Jas. 3:9; in NT pass. to be cursed, Mt. 25:41*

καταργεω.definition: to render useless or unproductive, occupy unprofitable, Lk. 13:7; to render powerless, Rom. 6:6; to make empty and unmeaning, Rom. 4:14; to render null, to abrogate, cancel, Rom. 3:3, 31; Eph. 2:15; to bring to an end, 1 Cor. 2:6; 13:8; 15:24, 26; 2 Cor. 3:7; to destroy, annihilate, 2 Thess. 2:8; Heb. 2:14; to free from, dissever from, Rom. 7:2, 6; Gal. 5:4

καταριθμεω.definition: to enumerate, number with, count with, Acts 1:17*

καταρτιζω.definition: to adjust thoroughly; to knit together, unite completely, 1 Cor. 1:10; to frame, Heb. 11:3; to prepare, provide, Mt. 21:16; Heb. 10:5; to qualify fully, to complete in character, Lk. 6:40; Heb. 13:21; 1 Pet. 5:10; perf. pass. κατηρτισμένα, fit, ripe, Rom. 9:22; to repair, refit, Mt. 4:21; Mk. 1:19; to supply, make good, 1 Thess. 3:10; to restore to a forfeited condition, to reinstate, Gal. 6:1; 2 Cor. 13:11*

καταρτισις.definition: pr. a complete adjustment; completeness of character, perfection, 2 Cor. 13:9*

καταρτισμος.definition: a perfectly adjusted adaptation; complete qualification for a specific purpose, Eph. 4:12*

κατασειω.definition: to shake down or violently, Acts 19:33; τὴν χεῖρα, or τῇ χειρι, to wave the hand, beckon; to signal silence by waving the hand, Acts 12:17; 13:16; 21:40*

κατασκαπτω.definition: pr. to dig down under, undermine; by impl. to overthrow; demolish, raze, Rom. 11:3; τὰ κατεσκαμμένα, ruins, Acts 15:16*

κατασκευαζω.definition: to prepare, put in readiness, Mt. 11:10; Mk. 1:2; Lk. 1:17; 7:27; to construct, form, build, Heb. 3:3, 4; 9:2, 6; 11:7; 1 Pet. 3:20*

κατασκηνοω.definition: to pitch one’s tent; in NT to rest in a place, settle, abide, Acts 2:26; to haunt, roost, Mt. 13:32; Mk. 4:32; Lk. 13:19*

κατασκηνωσις.definition: pr. the pitching a tent; a tent; in NT a dwelling place, Mt. 8:20; Lk. 9:58*

κατασκοπεω.definition: to view closely and accurately; to spy out, Gal. 2:4*

κατασοφιζομαι.definition: to exercise cleverness to the detriment of any one, to outwit; to make a victim of subtlety, to practice on the insidious dealing, Acts 7:19*

καταστελλω.definition: to arrange, dispose in regular order; to appease, quiet, pacify, Acts 19:35, 36*

καταστημα.definition: determinate state, behavior, condition; personal appearance, Tit. 2:3*

καταστολη.definition: pr. an arranging in order; adjustment of dress; in NT apparel, dress, 1 Tim. 2:9*

καταστρεφω.definition: to invert; to overturn, upset, overthrow, throw down, Mt. 21:12; Mk. 11:15*

καταστρηνιαω.definition: to be headstrong or wanton towards, 1 Tim. 5:11*

καταστροφη.definition: an overthrow, destruction, 2 Pet. 2:6; met. overthrow of right principle or faith, utter detriment, perversion, 2 Tim. 2:14*

καταστρωννυμι.definition: to lay flat; pass. to be laid prostrate in death, 1 Cor. 10:5*

κατασυρω.definition: to drag down, to drag away by force, Lk. 12:58*

κατασφαζω.definition: also spelled κατασφάττω, to slaughter, slay, Lk. 19:27*

κατατιθημι.definition: mid. to ay up for one’s self; χάριν, or χάριτας, to lay up a store of favor for one’s self, earn a title to favor at the hands of a person, to curry favor with, Acts 24:27; 25:9*

καταφερω.definition: to bear down; to overpower, as sleep, Acts 20:9; καταφέρειν ψῆφον, to give a vote or verdict, Acts 26:10; to bring charges, Acts 25:7*

καταφευγω.definition: to flee to for refuge, Acts 14:6; Heb. 6:18*

καταφιλεω.definition: to kiss affectionately or with a semblance of affection, to kiss with earnest gesture, Mt. 26:49; Mk. 14:45; Lk. 7:38, 45; 15:20; Acts 20:37*

καταφρονεω.definition: pr. to look down on; to scorn, despise, Mt. 18:10; Rom. 2:4; to slight, Mt. 6:24; Lk. 16:13; 1 Cor. 11:22; 1 Tim. 4:12; 6:2; 2 Pet. 2:10; to disregard, Heb. 12:2*

καταχεω.definition: to pour out or down upon, Mt. 26:7; Mk. 14:3*

καταχθονιος.definition: under the earth, subterranean, infernal, Phil. 2:10*

καταχραομαι.definition: to use downright; to use up, consume; to make an unrestrained use of, use eagerly, 1 Cor. 7:31; to use to the full, stretch to the utmost, exploit, 1 Cor. 9:18*

κατειδωλος.definition: rife with idols, sunk in idolatry, grossly idolatrous, Acts 17:16*

κατεναντι.definition: can function as an improper prep., over against, opposite to, Mk. 11:2; 12:41; 13:3; ὁ, ἡ, τό, κατέναντι, opposite, Lk. 19:30; before, in the presence of, in the sight of, Rom. 4:17

κατενωπιον.definition: can function as an improper prep., in the presence of, in the sight of, before; Eph. 1:4; Col. 1:22; Jude 24*

κατεξουσιαζω.definition: to exercise lordship or authority over, domineer over, Mt. 20:25; Mk. 10:42*

κατεργαζομαι.definition: to work out; to effect, produce, bring out as a result, Rom. 4:15; 5:3; 7:13; 2 Cor. 4:17; 7:10; Phil. 2:12; 1 Pet. 4:3; Jas. 1:3; to work, practice, realize in practice, Rom. 1:27; 2:9; to work or mould into fitness, 2 Cor. 5:5, despatch, Eph. 6:13

κατερχομαι.definition: to come or go down, Lk. 4:31; 9:37; Acts 8:5; 9:32; to land at, touch at, Acts 18:22; 27:5

κατεσθιω.definition: also spelled κατέσθω, to eat up, devour, Mt. 13:4; to consume, Rev. 11:5, to expend, squander, Lk. 15:30; met. to make a prey of, plunder, Mt. 23:13; Mk. 12:40; Lk. 20:47; 2 Cor. 11:20; to annoy, injure, Gal. 5:15

κατευθυνω.definition: optative, κατευθύναι (3rd sg), to make straight; to direct, guide aright, Lk. 1:79; 1 Thess. 3:11; 2 Thess. 3:5*

κατεφισταμαι.definition: to come upon suddenly, rush upon, assault, Acts 18:12*

κατεχω.definition: (1) transitive, to hold down; to detain, retain, Lk. 4:42; Rom. 1:18; Phlm. 13; to hinder, restrain, 2 Thess. 2:6, 7; to hold downright, hold in a firm grasp, to have in full and secure possession, 1 Cor. 7:30; 2 Cor. 6:10; to come into full possession of, seize upon; to keep, retain, 1 Thess. 5:21; to occupy, Lk. 14:9; met. to hold fast mentally, retain, Lk. 8:15; 1 Cor. 11:2; 15:2; to maintain, Heb. 3:6, 14; 10:23; (2) intransitive, a nautical term, to land, touch, Acts 27:40; pass. to be in the grasp of, to be bound by, Rom. 7:6*

κατηγορεω.definition: to speak against, accuse, Mt. 12:10; 27:12; Jn. 5:45

κατηγορια.definition: an accusation, crimination, Jn. 18:29; 1 Tim. 5:19; Tit. 1:6*

κατηγωρ.definition: an accuser, Rev. 12:10, a barbarous form for κατήγορος*

κατηχεω.definition: pr. to sound in the ears, make the ears ring; to instruct orally, to instruct, inform, 1 Cor. 14:19; pass. to be taught, be instructed, Lk. 1:4; Rom. 2:18; Gal. 6:6; to be made acquainted, Acts 18:25; to receive information, hear report, Acts 21:21, 24*

κατιοω.definition: to cover with rust; pass. to rust, become rusty or tarnished, Jas. 5:3*

κατισχυω.definition: to overpower, Mt. 16:18; absol. to predominate, get the upper hand, Lk. 21:36; 23:23*

κατοικεω.definition: trans. to inhabit, Acts 1:19; absol. to have an abode, dwell, Lk. 13:4; Acts 11:29; to take up or find an abode, Acts 7:2; to indwell, Eph. 3:17; Jas. 4:5

κατοικητηριον.definition: an abode, dwelling, habitation, the same as κατοίκησις, Eph. 2:22; Rev. 18:2*

κατοπτριζω.definition: to show in a mirror; to present a clear and correct image of a thing, mid. to have presented in a mirror, to have a clear image presented, or, to reflect, 2 Cor. 3:18*

κατω.definition: (1) down, downwards, Mt. 4:6; Lk. 4:9; Jn. 8:6; Acts 20:9; (2) beneath, below, under, Mt. 27:51; Mk. 14:66; 15:38; Acts 2:19; ὁ, ἡ, τό, κάτω, what is below, earthly, Jn. 8:23*

κατωτερω.definition: lower, farther down; of time, under, Mt. 2:16*

καυδα.definition: also spelled Κλαῦδα (G3084) and Κλαῦδη (G3085), Cauda, indecl. pr. name of an island, Acts 27:16*

καυμα.definition: heat, scorching or burning heat, Rev. 7:16; 16:9*

καυματιζω.definition: to scorch, burn, Mt. 13:6; Mk. 4:6; Rev. 16:8, 9*

καυσοω.definition: to be on fire, burn intensely, 2 Pet. 3:10, 12*

καυστηριαζω.definition: also spelled καυτηριάζω, to cauterize, brand; pass. met. to be branded with marks of guilt, or, to be seared into insensibility, 1 Tim. 4:2*

καυσων.definition: fervent scorching heat; the scorching of the sun, Mt. 20:12; hot weather, a hot time, Lk. 12:55; the scorching wind of the East, Eurus, Jas. 1:11*

καυχαομαι.definition: to glory, boast, Rom. 2:17, 23; ὑπέρ τινος, to boast of a person or thing, to undertake a complimentary testimony to, 2 Cor. 12:5; to rejoice, exult, Rom. 5:2, 3, 11

καυχημα.definition: a glorying, boasting, 1 Cor. 5:6; a ground or matter of glorying or boasting, Rom. 4:2; joy, exultation, Phil. 1:26; complimentary testimony, 1 Cor. 9:15, 16; 2 Cor. 9:3

καυχησις.definition: boasting, pride, a later equivalent to καύχημαι, Rom. 3:27; 2 Cor. 7:4, 14; 11:10

καφαρναουμ.definition: indecl. pr. name, Capernaum. See PhotoGuide.

κεγχρεαι.definition: Cenchreae, the port of Corinth on the Saronic Gulf; Acts 18:18; Rom. 16:1*

κεδρων.definition: indecl. pr. name, Kidron, a valley near Jerusalem, Jn. 18:1*

κειμαι.definition: to lie, to be laid; to recline, to be lying, to have been laid down, Mt. 28:6; Lk. 2:12; to have been laid, placed, set, Mt. 3:10; Lk. 3:9; Jn. 2:6; to be situated, as a city, Mt. 5:14; Rev. 21:16; to be in store, Lk. 12:19; met. to be constituted, established as a law, 1 Tim. 1:9; in NT of persons, to be specially set, solemnly appointed, destined, Lk. 2:34; Phil. 1:16; 1 Thess. 3:3; to lie under an influence, to be involved in, 1 Jn. 5:19

κειρια.definition: a bandage, swath, in NT pl. graveclothes, Jn. 11:44*

κειρω.definition: to cut off the hair, shear, shave, Acts 8:32; 18:18; 1 Cor. 11:6 (2x)*

κελευσμα.definition: a word of command; a mutual cheer; hence, in NT a loud shout, an arousing outcry, 1 Thess. 4:16*

κελευω.definition: to order, command, direct, bid, Mt. 8:18; 14:19, 28

κενος.definition: empty; having nothing, empty-handed, Mk. 12:3; met. vain, fruitless, void of effect, Acts 4:25; 1 Cor. 15:10; εἰς κενόν, in vain, to no purpose, 2 Cor. 6:1; hollow, fallacious, false, Eph. 5:6; Col. 2:8; inconsiderate, foolish, 1 Thess. 3:5; Jas. 2:20

κενοφωνια.definition: vain, empty babbling, vain disputation, fruitless discussion, 1 Tim. 6:20; 2 Tim. 2:16*

κενοω.definition: to empty, evacuate; ἑαυτόν, to divest one’s self of one’s prerogatives, abase one’s self, Phil. 2:7; to deprive a thing of its proper functions, Rom. 4:14; 1 Cor. 1:17; to show to be without foundation, falsify, 1 Cor. 9:15; 2 Cor. 9:3*

κεντρον.definition: a sharp point; a sting of an animal, Rev. 9:10; a prick, stimulus, goad, Acts 26:14; met. of death, destructive power, deadly venom, 1 Cor. 15:55, 56*

κεντυριων.definition: in its original signification, a commander of a hundred foot-soldiers, a centurion, Mk. 15:39, 44, 45*

κενως.definition: in vain, to no purpose, unmeaning, Jas. 4:5*

κεραια.definition: pr. a horn-like projection, a point, extremity; in NT an apex, or fine point; as of letters, used for the minutest part, a tittle, Mt. 5:18; Lk. 16:17*

κεραμικος.definition: made by a potter, earthen, Rev. 2:27*

κεραμιον.definition: an earthenware vessel, a pitcher, jar, Mk. 14:13; Lk. 22;10*

κεραμος.definition: potter’s clay; earthenware; a roof, tile, tiling, Lk. 5:19*

κεραννυμι.definition: to mix, mingle, drink; to prepare for drinking, Rev. 14:10; 18:6 (2x)*

κερας.definition: a horn, Rev. 5:6; 12:3; a horn-like projection at the corners of an altar, Rev. 9:13; from the Hebrew, a horn as a symbol of power, Lk. 1:69

κερατιον.definition: pr. a little horn; in NT a pod, the pod of the carob tree, or Ceratonia siliqua of Linnaeus, a common tree in the East and the south of Europe, growing to a considerable size, and producing long slender pods, with a pulp of a sweetish taste, and several brown shining seeds like beans, sometimes eaten by the poorer people in Syria and Palestine, and commonly used for fattening swine, Lk. 15:16*

κερδαινω.definition: to gain as a matter of profit, Mt. 25:17; to win, acquire possession of, Mt. 16:26; to profit in the avoidance of, to avoid, Acts 27:21; in NT Χριστόν, to win Christ, to become possessed of the privileges of the Gospel, Phil. 3:8; to win over from estrangement, Mt. 18:15; to win over to embrace the Gospel, 1 Cor. 9:19, 20, 21, 22; 1 Pet. 3:1; absol. to make gain, Jas. 4:13

κερμα.definition: something clipped small; small change, small pieces of money, coin, Jn. 2:15*

κεφαλαιον.definition: a sum total; a sum of money, capital, Acts 22:28; the crowning or ultimate point to preliminary matters, Heb. 8:1*

κεφαλη.definition: the head, Mt. 5:36; 6:17; the head, top; κεφαλὴ γωνίας, the head of the corner, the chief corner-stone, Mt. 21:42; Lk. 20:17; met. the head, superior, chief, principal, one to whom others are subordinate, 1 Cor. 11:3; Eph. 1:22

κεφαλις.definition: in NT a roll, volume, division of a book, Heb. 10:7*

κηνσος.definition: a census, assessment, enumeration of the people and a valuation of their property; in NT tribute, tax, Mt. 17:25; poll-tax, Mt. 22:17, 19; Mk. 12:14*

κηπος.definition: a garden, any place planted with trees and herbs, Lk. 13:19; Jn. 18:1, 26; 19:41*

κηρυγμα.definition: proclamation, proclaiming, public annunciation, Mt. 12:41; public inculcation, preaching, 1 Cor. 2:4; 15:14; meton. what is publicly inculcated, doctrine, Rom. 16:25; Tit. 1:3*

κηρυξ.definition: a herald, public messenger; in NT a proclaimer, publisher, preacher, 1 Tim. 2:7; 2 Tim. 1:11; 2 Pet. 2:5*

κηρυσσω.definition: to publish, proclaim, as a herald, 1 Cor. 9:27; to announce openly and publicly, Mk. 1:4; Lk. 4:18; to noise abroad, Mk. 1:45; 7:36; to announce as a matter of doctrine, inculcate, preach, Mt. 24:14; Mk. 1:38; 13:10; Acts 15:21; Rom. 2:21

κητος.definition: a large fish, sea monster, whale, Mt. 12:40*

κηφας.definition: Cephas, Rock, rendered into Greek by Πέτρος, Jn. 1:42; 1 Cor. 1:12; 3:22; 9:5; 15:5; Gal. 1:18; 2:9, 11, 14*

κιβωτος.definition: a chest, coffer; the ark of the covenant, Heb. 9:4; Rev. 11:19; the ark of Noah, Mt. 24:38; Lk. 17:27; Heb. 11:7; 1 Pet. 3:20*

κιθαριζω.definition: to play on a lyre or harp, 1 Cor. 14:7; Rev. 14:2*

κιθαρωδος.definition: one who plays on the lyre and accompanies it with his voice, Rev. 14:2; 18:22*

κιλικια.definition: Cilicia, a province of Asia Minor, Gal. 1:21

κινδυνευω.definition: to be in danger or peril, Lk. 8:23; Acts 19:27, 40; 1 Cor. 15:30*

κινεω.definition: to move, Mt. 23:4; to excite, agitate, Acts 21:30; 24:5; to remove, Rev. 2:5; 6:14; in NT κεφαλήν, to shake the head in derision, Mt. 27:39; Mk. 15:29; mid., to move, possess the faculty of motion, exercise the functions of life, Acts 17:28*

κις.definition: Kish, the father of Saul, pr. name, indecl., Acts 13:21*

κλαδος.definition: a bough, branch, shoot, Mt. 13:32; 21:8; met. a branch of a family stock, Rom. 11:16, 21

κλαιω.definition: intrans. to weep, shed tears, Mt. 26:75; Mk. 5:38, 39; Lk. 19:41; 23:28; trans. to weep for, bewail, Mt. 2:18

κλασις.definition: a breaking, the act of breaking, Lk. 24:35; Acts 2:42

κλασμα.definition: a piece broken off, fragment, Mt. 14:20; 15:37; Mk. 6:43; 8:8, 19, 20; Lk. 9:17; Jn. 6:12f.*

κλαυδιος.definition: Claudius, pr. name (1) The fourth Roman Emperor, Acts 11:28; 18:2. (2) Claudius Lysias, a Roman captain, Acts 23:26*

κλαω.definition: to break off; in NT to break bread, Mt. 14:19; with figurative reference to the violent death of Christ, 1 Cor. 11:24

κλεις.definition: a key, used in NT as the symbol of power, authority, etc. Mt. 16:19; Rev. 1:18; 3:7; 9:1; 20:1; met. the key of entrance into knowledge, Lk. 11:52*

κλειω.definition: to close, shut, Mt. 6:6; 25:10; to shut up a person, Rev. 20:3; met. of the heavens, Lk. 4:25; Rev. 11:6; κλεῖσαι τὰ σπλάγχνα, to shut one’s bowels, to be hard-hearted, void of compassion, 1 Jn. 3:17; κλείειν τὴν βασιλεία τῶν οὐρανῶν, to endeavor to prevent entrance into the kingdom of heaven, Mt. 23:13

κλεος.definition: pr. rumor, report; good report, praise, credit, 1 Pet. 2:20*

κλεπτης.definition: a thief, Mt. 6:19, 20; 24:43; trop. a thief by imposture, Jn. 10:8

κλεπτω.definition: to steal, Mt. 6:19, 20; 19:18; to take away stealthily, remove secretly, Mt. 27:64; 28:13

κλημα.definition: a branch, shoot, twig, esp. of the vine, Jn. 15:2, 4-6*

κλημης.definition: Clemens, Clement, pr. name, Latin, Phil. 4:3*

κληρονομεω.definition: pr. to acquire by lot; to inherit, obtain by inheritance; in NT to obtain, acquire, receive possession of, Mt. 5:5; 19:29; absol. to be heir, Gal. 4:30

κληρονομια.definition: an inheritance, patrimony, Mt. 21:38; Mk. 12:7; a possession, portion, property, Acts 7:5; 20:32; in NT a share, participation in privileges, Acts 20:32; Eph. 1:14; 5:5

κληρονομος.definition: an heir, Mt. 21:38; Gal. 4:1; a possessor, Rom. 4:13; Heb. 11:7; Jas. 2:5

κληρος.definition: a lot, die, a thing used in determining chances, Mt. 27:35; Mk. 15:24; Lk. 23:34; Jn. 19:24; Acts 1:26; assignment, investiture, Acts 1:17; allotment, destination, Col. 1:12; a part, portion, share, Acts 8:21; 26:18; a constituent portion of the Church, 1 Pet. 5:3*

κληροω.definition: to obtain by lot or assignment; to obtain a portion, receive a share, Eph. 1:11*

κλησις.definition: a call, calling, invitation; in NT the call or invitation to the privileges of the Gospel, Rom. 11:29; Eph. 1:18; the favor and privilege of the invitation, 2 Thess. 1:11; 2 Pet. 1:10; the temporal condition in which the call found a person, 1 Cor. 1:26; 7:20

κλητος.definition: called, invited, in NT called to privileges or function, Mt. 20:16; 22:14; Rom. 1:1, 6, 7; 8:28; 1 Cor. 1:1, 2, 24; Jude 1; Rev. 17:14

κλιμα.definition: pr. a slope; a portion of the ideal slope of the earth’s surface; a tract or region of country, Rom. 15:23; 2 Cor. 11:10; Gal. 1:21*

κλιναριον.definition: a small bed or couch, Acts 5:15*

κλινη.definition: a couch, bed, Mt. 9:2, 6; Mk. 4:21; Rev. 2:22

κλινιδιον.definition: a small couch or bed, Lk. 5:19, 24*

κλινω.definition: pr. trans. to cause to slope or bend; to bow down, Lk. 24:5; Jn. 19:30; to lay down to rest, Mt. 8:20; Lk. 9:58; to put to flight troops, Heb. 11:34; intrans. of the day, to decline, Lk. 9:12; 24:29*

κλισια.definition: pr. a place for reclining; a tent, seat, couch; in NT a group of persons reclining at a meal. Lk. 9:14*

κλυδων.definition: a wave, billow, surge, Lk. 8:24; Jas. 1:6*

κλυδωνιζομαι.definition: to be tossed by waves; met. to fluctuate in opinion, be agitated, tossed to and fro, Eph. 4:14*

κνηθω.definition: to scratch; to tickle, cause titillation; in NT mid. met. to procure pleasurable excitement for, to indulge an itching, 2 Tim. 4:3*

κνιδος.definition: Cnidus, a city of Caria, in Asia Minor, Acts 27:7*

κοδραντης.definition: a Roman brass coin, equivalent to the fourth part of an as, or ἀσσάριον, or to δύο λεπτά, Mt. 5:26; Mk. 12:42*

κοιλια.definition: a cavity; the belly, Mt. 15:17; Mk. 7:19; the stomach, Mt. 12:40; Lk. 15:16; the womb, Mt. 19:12; Lk. 1:15; from the Hebrew, the inner self, Jn. 7:38

κοιμαω.definition: to lull to sleep; pass. to fall asleep, be asleep, Mt. 28:13; Lk. 22:45; met. to sleep in death, Acts 7:60; 13:36; 2 Pet. 3:4

κοινος.definition: common, belonging equally to several, Acts 2:44; 4:32; in NT common, profane, Heb. 10:29; Rev. 21:27; ceremonially unclean, Mk. 7:2; Acts 10:14

κοινοω.definition: to make common, in NT to profane, desecrate, Acts 21:28; to render ceremonially unclean, defile, pollute, Mt. 15:11, 18, 20; 7:15, 18, 20, 23; Heb. 9:13; to pronounce unclean ceremonially, Acts 10:15; 11:9*

κοινωνεω.definition: to have in common, share, Heb. 2:14; to be associated in, to become a sharer in, Rom. 15:27; 1 Pet. 4:13; to become implicated in, be a party to, 1 Tim. 5:22; 2 Jn. 11; to associate one’s self with by sympathy and assistance, to communicate with in the way of aid and relief, Rom. 12:13; Gal. 6:6; Phil. 4:15*

κοινωνια.definition: fellowship, partnership, Acts 2:42; 2 Cor. 6:14; 13:13; Gal. 2:9; Phil. 3:10; 1 Jn. 1:3; participation, communion, 1 Cor. 10:16; aid, relief, Heb. 13:16; contribution in aid, Rom. 15:26

κοινωνικος.definition: social; in NT generous, liberal, beneficent, 1 Tim. 6:18*

κοινωνος.definition: a fellow, partner, companion, Mt. 23:30; Lk. 5:10; 1 Cor. 10:18, 20; 2 Cor. 8:23; Phlm. 17; Heb. 10:33; a sharer, partaker, 2 Cor. 1:7; 1 Pet. 5:1; 2 Pet. 1:4*

κοιτη.definition: a bed, Lk. 11:7; the conjugal bed, Heb. 13:4; meton. sexual intercourse, concubitus; hence, lewdness, whoredom, chambering, Rom. 13:13; in NT conception, Rom. 9:10*

κοκκινος.definition: dyed with coccus, crimson, scarlet, Mt. 27:28; Heb. 9:19; Rev. 17:3, 4; 18:12, 16*

κολαζω.definition: pr. to curtail, to coerce; to chastise, punish, Acts 4:21; 2 Pet. 2:9*

κολασις.definition: chastisement, punishment, Mt. 25:46; painful disquietude, torment, 1 Jn. 4:18*

κολαφιζω.definition: to beat with the fist, buffet, Mt. 26:67; Mk. 14:65; met. to maltreat, treat with excessive force, 1 Cor. 4:11; to punish, 1 Pet. 2:20; to buffet, fret, afflict, 2 Cor. 12:7*

κολλαω.definition: to glue or weld together; mid. to adhere to, Lk. 10:11; met. to attach one’s self to, unite with, associate with, Lk. 15:15; Acts 5:13; Rev. 18:5

κολλουριον.definition: also spelled κολλύριον, collyrium, eye-salve, Rev. 3:18*

κολοβοω.definition: in NT of time, to cut short, shorten, Mt. 24:22; Mk. 13:20*

κολοσσαι.definition: also spelled Κολασσαεύς, Colossae, a city of Phrygia, Col. 1:2*. See PhotoGuide.

κολπος.definition: the bosom, Lk. 16:22, 23; Jn. 1:18; 13:23; the bosom of a garment, Lk. 6:38; a bay, creek, inlet, Acts 27:39*

κολυμβαω.definition: to dive; in NT to swim, Acts 27:43*

κολυμβηθρα.definition: a place where any one may swim; a pond, pool, Jn. 5:2, 4, 7; 9:7*

κομαω.definition: to have long hair, wear the hair long, 1 Cor. 11:14, 15*

κομη.definition: the hair; a head of long hair, 1 Cor. 11:15*

κομιζω.definition: pr. to take into kindly keeping, to provide for; to convey, bring, Lk. 7:37; mid. to bring for one’s self; to receive, obtain, 2 Cor. 5:10; Eph. 6:8; to receive again, recover, Mt. 25:27; Heb. 11:19

κομψοτερον.definition: in NT in better health, Jn. 4:52*

κονιαω.definition: to whitewash, or, plaster, Mt. 23:27; Acts 23:3*

κοπαζω.definition: pr. to grow weary, suffer exhaustion; to abate, be stilled, Mt. 14:32; Mk. 4:39; 6:51*

κοπετος.definition: pr. a beating of the breast, etc., in token of grief; a wailing, lamentation, Acts 8:2*

κοπη.definition: a stroke, smiting; in NT slaughter, Heb. 7:1*

κοπιαω.definition: to be wearied or spent with labor, faint from weariness, Mt. 11:28; Jn. 4:6; in NT to labor hard, to toil, Lk. 5:5; Jn. 4:38

κοπος.definition: trouble, difficulty, uneasiness, Mt. 26:10; Mk. 14:6; labor, wearisome labor, travail, toil, 1 Cor. 3:8; 15:58; meton. the fruit or consequence of labor, Jn. 4:38; 2 Cor. 10:15

κοπτω.definition: to smite, cut; to cut off or down, Mt. 21:8; Mk. 11:8; mid. to beat one’s self in mourning, lament, bewail, Mt. 11:17; 24:30; Lk. 8:52; 23:27; Rev. 1:7; 18:9*

κορβαν.definition: corban, a gift, offering, oblation, anything consecrated to God, Mk. 7:11*

κορβανας.definition: temple treasury, the sacred treasury, Mt. 27:6*

κορινθιος.definition: Corinthian; an inhabitant of Κόρινθος, Corinth, Acts 18:8; 2 Cor. 6:11*

κορινθος.definition: Corinth, a celebrated city of Greece, Acts 18:1; 19:1; 1 Cor. 1:2; 2 Cor. 1:1, 23; 2 Tim. 4:20*

κορνηλιος.definition: Cornelius, a Latin pr. name, Acts 10:1, 3, 17, 22, 24f., 30f.*

κορος.definition: a cor, the largest Jewish measure for things dry, equal to the homer, and about fifteen bushels English, according to Josephus, Lk. 16:7*

κοσμεω.definition: pluperfect, ἐκεκόσμητο (3 sg), to arrange, set in order; to adorn, decorate, embellish, Mt. 12:44; 23:29; to prepare, put in readiness, trim, Mt. 25:7; met. to honor, dignify, Tit. 2:10

κοσμικος.definition: pr. belonging to the universe, in NT accommodated to the present state of things, adapted to this world, worldly, Tit. 2:12; τὸ κοσμικόν, as a subst. the apparatus for the service of the tabernacle, Heb. 9:1*

κοσμοκρατωρ.definition: pr. monarch of the world; in NT a worldly prince, a power paramount in the world of the unbelieving and ungodly, Eph. 6:12*

κοσμος.definition: (1) pr. order, regular disposition; ornament, decoration, embellishment, 1 Pet. 3:3; (2) the world, the material universe, Mt. 13:35; the world, the aggregate of sensitive existence, 1 Cor. 4:9; the lower world, the earth, Mk. 16:15; the world, the aggregate of mankind, Mt. 5:14; the world, the public, Jn. 7:4; in NT the present order of things, the secular world, Jn. 18:36; the human race external to the Jewish nation, the heathen world, Rom. 11:12, 15; the world external to the Christian body, 1 Jn. 3:1, 13; the world or material system of the Mosaic covenant, Gal. 4:3; Col. 2:8, 20

κουαρτος.definition: Quartus, a Latin pr. name, Rom. 16:23*

κουμ.definition: an Aramaic imperative, also spelled κοῦμι, stand up, Mk. 5:41*

κουφιζω.definition: to lighten, make light or less heavy, Acts 27:38*

κραβαττος.definition: also spelled κράββατος, mattress, pallet, bed, Mk. 2:4, 9, 11f.; 6:55; Jn. 5:8-11; Acts 5:15; 9:33*

κραζω.definition: to utter a cry, Mt. 14:26; to exclaim, cry out, Mt. 9:27; Jn. 1:15; to cry for vengeance, Jas. 5:4; to cry in supplication, Rom. 8:15; Gal. 4:6

κραιπαλη.definition: also spelled κρεπάλη, drunken dissipation, Lk. 21:34*

κρασπεδον.definition: a margin, border, edge, in NT a fringe, tuft, tassel, Mt. 9:20; 14:36; 23:5; Mk. 6:56; Lk. 8:44*

κραταιοω.definition: to strengthen, render strong, corroborate, confirm; pass. to grow strong, acquire strength, Lk. 1:80; 2:40; Eph. 3:16; to be firm, resolute, 1 Cor. 16:13*

κρατεω.definition: pr. to be strong; to be superior to any one, subdue, vanquish, Acts 2:24; to get into one’s power, lay hold of, seize, apprehend, Mt. 14:3; 18:28; 21:46; to gain, compass, attain, Acts 27:13; in NT to lay hold of, grasp, clasp, Mt. 9:25; Mk. 1:31; 5:41; to retain, keep under reserve, Mk. 9:10; met, to hold fast, observe, Mk. 7:3, 8; 2 Thess. 2:15; to hold to, adhere to, Acts 3:11; Col. 2:19; to restrain, hinder, repress, Lk. 24:16; Rev. 7:1; to retain, not to remit, sins, Jn. 20:23

κρατιστος.definition: strongest; in NT κράτιστε, a term of respect, most excellent, noble, or illustrious, Lk. 1:3; Acts 23:26; 24:3; 26:25*

κρατος.definition: strength, power, might, force, Acts 19:20; Eph. 1:19; meton. a display of might, Lk. 1:51; power, sway, dominion, Heb. 2:14; 1 Pet. 4:11; 5:11

κραυγαζω.definition: to cry out, exclaim, shout, Mt. 12:19; Acts 22:23

κραυγη.definition: a cry, outcry, clamor, shouting, Mt. 25:6; Lk. 1:42; Acts 23:9; Eph. 4:31; a cry of sorrow, wailing, lamentation, Rev. 21:4; a cry for help, earnest supplication, Heb. 5:7*

κρεας.definition: flesh, meat, a later form of κρέατος, Rom. 14:21; 1 Cor. 8:13*

g2909.definition: can also be spelled κρείσσων, better, more useful or profitable, more conducive to good, 1 Cor. 7:8, 38; superior, more excellent, of a higher nature, more valuable, Heb. 1:4; 6:9; 7:7, 19, 22

κρεμαννυμι.definition: also spelled κρέμαμαι and κρεμάζω, to hang, suspend, Acts 5:30; 10:39; pass. to be hung, suspended, Mt. 18:6; Lk. 23:39; mid. κρέμαμαι, to hang, be suspended, Acts 28:4; Gal. 3:13; met. κρέμαμαι ἐν, to hang upon, to be referable to as an ultimate principle, Mt. 22:40

κρημνος.definition: a hanging steep, precipice, a steep bank, Mt. 8:32; Mk. 5:13; Lk. 8:33*

κρης.definition: a Cretan, an inhabitant of Κρήτη, Acts 2:11; Tit. 1:12*

κρησκης.definition: Crescens, a Latin pr. name, 2 Tim. 4:10*

κρητη.definition: Crete, a large island in the eastern part of the Mediterranean, Acts 27:7, 12f., 21, Tit. 1:5*

κριμα.definition: judgment; a sentence, award, Mt. 7:2; a judicial sentence, Lk. 23:40; 24:20; Rom. 2:2; 5:16; an adverse sentence, Mt. 23:14; Rom. 13:2; 1 Tim. 5:12; Jas. 3:1; judgment, administration of justice, Jn. 9:39; Acts 24:25; execution of justice, 1 Pet. 4:17; a lawsuit; 1 Cor. 6:7; in NT judicial visitation, 1 Cor. 11:29; 2 Pet. 2:3; an administrative decree, Rom. 11:33

κρινω.definition: pluperfect, κεκρίκει (3 sg), pr. to separate; to make a distinction between; to exercise judgment upon; to estimate, Rom. 14:5; to judge, to assume censorial power over, to call to account, Mt. 7:1; Lk. 6:37; Rom. 2:1, 3; 14:3, 4, 10, 13; Col. 2:16; Jas. 4:11, 12; to bring under question, Rom. 14:22; to judge judicially, to try as a judge, Jn. 18:31; to bring to trial, Acts 13:27; to sentence, Lk. 19:22; Jn. 7:51; to resolve on, decree, Acts 16:4; Rev. 16:5; absol. to decide, determine, resolve, Acts 3:13; 15:19; 27:1; to deem, Acts 13:46; to form a judgment, pass judgment, Jn. 8:15; pass. to be brought to trial, Acts 25:10, 20; Rom. 3:4; to be brought to account, to incur arraignment, be arraigned, 1 Cor. 10:29; mid. to go to law, litigate, Mt. 5:40; in NT to judge, to visit judicially, Acts 7:7; 1 Cor. 11:31, 32; 1 Pet. 4:6; to judge, to right, to vindicate, Heb. 10:30; to administer government over, to govern, Mt. 19:28; Lk. 22:30

κρισις.definition: pr. distinction; discrimination; judgment, decision, award, Jn. 5:30; 7:24; 8:16; a judicial sentence, Jn. 3:19; Jas. 2:13; an adverse sentence, Mt. 23:33; Mk. 3:29; judgment, judicial process, trial, Mt. 10:15; Jn. 5:24; 12:31; 16:8; judgment, administration of justice, Jn. 5:22, 27; in NT a court of justice, tribunal, Mt. 5:21, 22; an impeachment, 2 Pet. 2:11; Jude 9; from the Hebrew, justice, equity, Mt. 12:18, 20; 23:23; Lk. 11:42

κρισπος.definition: Crispus, a Latin pr. name, Acts 18:8; 1 Cor. 1:14*

κριτηριον.definition: pr. a standard or means by which to judge, criterion; a court of justice, tribunal, Jas. 2:6; a cause, controversy, 1 Cor. 6:2, 4*

κριτης.definition: a judge, Mt. 5:25; from the Hebrew, a magistrate, ruler, Acts 13:20; 24:10

κριτικος.definition: able or quick to discern or judge, Heb. 4:12*

κρυπτη.definition: a vault or closet, a cell for storage, dark secret place, Lk. 11:33*

κρυπτος.definition: hidden, concealed, secret, clandestine, Mt. 6:4, 6; τὰ κρυπτά, secrets, Rom. 2:16; 1 Cor. 14:25

κρυπτω.definition: to hide, conceal, Mt. 5:14; in NT to lay up in store, Col. 3:3; Rev. 2:17; κεκρυμμέμος, concealed, secret, Jn. 19:38

κρυσταλλιζω.definition: to be clear, brilliant like crystal, Rev. 21:11*

κρυφη.definition: in secret, secretly, not openly, Eph. 5:12*

κταομαι.definition: to get, procure, provide, Mt. 10:9; to make gain, gain, Lk. 18:12; to purchase, Acts 8:20; 22:28; to be the cause or occasion of purchasing, Acts 1:18; to preserve, save, Lk. 21:19; to get under control, to be winning the mastery over, 1 Thess. 4:4; perf. κέκτημαι, to possess*

κτημα.definition: a possession, property, field, Mt. 19:22; Mk. 10:22; Acts 2:45; 5:1*

κτηνος.definition: pr. property, generally used in the plural, τὰ κτήνη; property in animals; a beast of burden, domesticated animal, Lk. 10:34; Acts 23:24; beasts, cattle, 1 Cor. 15:39; Rev. 18:13*

κτιζω.definition: pr. to reduce from a state of disorder and wildness; in NT to call into being, to create, Mk. 13:19; to call into individual existence, to frame, Eph. 2:15; to create spiritually, to invest with a spiritual frame, Eph. 2:10; 4:24

κτισις.definition: (1) pr. a framing, founding; (2) in NT creation, the act of creating, Rom. 1:20; creation, the material universe, Mk. 10:6; 13:19; Heb. 9:11; 2 Pet. 3:4; a created thing, a creature, Rom. 1:25; 8:39; Col. 1:15; Heb. 4:13; the human creation, Mk. 16:15; Rom. 8:19, 20, 21, 22; Col. 1:23; a spiritual creation, 2 Cor. 5:17; Gal. 6:15; (3) an institution, ordinance, 1 Pet. 2:13

κτισμα.definition: pr. a thing founded; in NT a created being, creature, 1 Tim. 4:4; Jas. 1:18; Rev. 5:13; 8:9*

κτιστης.definition: a founder; in NT a creator, 1 Pet. 4:19*

κυβεια.definition: also spelled κυβία, pr. dice playing; met. craftiness, trickery, Eph. 4:14*

κυβερνησις.definition: government, office of a governor or director; meton. a director, 1 Cor. 12:28*

κυκλοω.definition: to encircle, surround, encompass, come around. Jn. 10:24; Acts 14:20; spc. to lay siege to, Lk. 21:20; to march round, Heb. 11:30*

κυκλω.definition: from κύκλος, functions in the NT only as an improper prep., a circle; in NT κύκλῳ functions adverbially, round, round about, around, Mk. 3:34; 6:6, 36

κυλισμος.definition: also spelled κύλισμα, a rolling, wallowing, 2 Pet. 2:22*

κυλιω.definition: to roll; mid. to roll one’s self, to wallow, Mk. 9:20

κυλλος.definition: pr. crooked, bent, maimed, lame, crippled, Mt. 18:8; Mk. 9:43, used as a noun meaning cripple, Mt. 15:30ff.*

κυμα.definition: a wave, surge, billow, Mt. 8:24; 14:24; Mk. 4:37; Acts 27:41; Jude 13*

κυμινον.definition: cumin, cuminum salivum of Linnaeus, a plant, a native of Egypt and Syria, whose seeds are of an aromatic, warm, bitterish taste, with a strong but not disagreeable smell, and used by the ancients as a condiment, Mt. 23:23*

κυναριον.definition: a little or worthless dog, Mt. 15:26, 27; Mk. 7:27, 28*

κυπριος.definition: a Cypriot, an inhabitant of Cyprus, Acts 4:36; 11:20; 21:16*

κυπρος.definition: Cyprus, an island in the eastern part of the Mediterranean, Acts 11:19; 13:4; 15:39; 21:3; 27:4*

κυπτω.definition: to bend forwards, stoop down, Mk. 1:7; Jn. 8:6*

κυρηναιος.definition: a Cyrenian, an inhabitant of Cyrene, Mt. 27:32; Mk. 15:21; Lk. 23:26; Acts 6:9; 11:20; 13:1*

κυρηνη.definition: Cyrene, a city founded by a colony of Greeks, in Northern Africa, Acts 2:10*

κυρηνιος.definition: Cyrenius (perhaps Quirinus) pr. name, the governor of Syria, Lk. 2:2*

κυριακος.definition: pertaining to the Lord Jesus Christ, the Lord’s, 1 Cor. 11:20; Rev. 1:10*

κυριευω.definition: to be lord over, to be possessed of, mastery over, Rom. 6:9, 14; 7:1; 14:9; 2 Cor. 1:24; 1 Tim. 6:15; to exercise control over, Lk. 22:25*

κυριος.definition: a lord, master, Mt. 12:8; an owner, possessor, Mt. 20:8; a potentate, sovereign, Acts 25:26; a power, deity, 1 Cor. 8:5; the Lord, Jehovah, Mt. 1:22; the Lord Jesus Christ, Mt. 24:42; Mk. 16:19; Lk. 10:1; Jn. 4:1; 1 Cor. 4:5; freq.; κύριε, a term of respect of various force, Sir, Lord, Mt. 13:27; Acts 9:6, et al. freq.

κυριοτης.definition: lordship; constituted authority, Eph. 1:21; 2 Pet. 2:10; Jude 8; pl. authorities, potentates, Col. 1:16. The Ephesian and Colossian passage could also be speaking about angelic powers.*

κυροω.definition: to confirm, ratify, Gal. 3:15; to reaffirm, assure, 2 Cor. 2:8*

κυων.definition: a dog, Mt. 7:6; Lk. 16:21; 2 Pet. 2:22; met. a dog, a religious corrupter, Phil. 3:2; miscreant, Rev. 22:15*

κωλον.definition: lit., a member or limb of the body, fig., dead body, corpse, Heb. 3:17*

κωλυω.definition: to hinder, restrain, prevent, Mt. 19:14; Acts 8:36; Rom. 1:13

κωμη.definition: a village, a country town, Mt. 9:35; 10:11; Lk. 8:1

κωμοπολις.definition: a large village, market town, Mk. 1:38*

κωμος.definition: pr. a festive procession, a merry-making; in NT a revel, lewd, immoral feasting, Rom. 13:13; Gal. 5:21; 1 Pet. 4:3*

κωνωψ.definition: a gnat, mosquito, which is found in wine when becoming sour, Mt. 23:24*

κωφος.definition: pr. blunt, dull, as a weapon; dull of hearing, deaf, Mt. 11:5; Mk. 7:32, 37; 9:25; Lk. 7:22; dumb, mute, Mt. 9:32, 33; 12:22; 15:30, 31; Lk. 1:22; meton. making dumb, causing dumbness, Lk. 11:14*

λαγχανω.definition: to have assigned to one, to obtain, receive, Acts 1:17; 2 Pet. 1:1; to have fall to one by lot, Lk. 1:9; absol. to cast lots, Jn. 19:24*

λαιλαψ.definition: a squall of wind, a hurricane, Mk. 4:37; Lk. 8:23; 2 Pet. 2:17*

λαλεω.definition: to make vocal utterance; to babble, to talk; in NT absol. to exercise the faculty of speech, Mt. 9:33; to speak, Mt. 10:20; to hold converse with, to talk with, Mt. 12:46; Mk. 6:50; Rev. 1:12; to discourse, to make an address, Lk. 11:37; Acts 11:20; 21:39; to make announcement, to make a declaration, Lk. 1:55; to make mention, Jn. 12:41; Acts 2:31; Heb. 4:8; 2 Pet. 3:16; trans. to speak, address, preach, Mt. 9:18; Jn. 3:11; Tit. 2:1; to give utterance to, utter, Mk. 2:7; Jn. 3:34; to declare, announce, reveal, Lk. 24:25 et al.; to disclose, 2 Cor. 12:4

λαλια.definition: talk, speech; in NT matter of discourse, Jn. 4:42; 8:43; language, dialect, Mt. 26:73*

λαμβανω.definition: to take, take up, take in the hand, Mt. 10:38; 13:31, 33; to take on one’s self, sustain, Mt. 8:17; to take, seize, seize upon, Mt. 5:40; 21:34; Lk. 5:26; 1 Cor. 10:13; to catch, Lk. 5:5; 2 Cor. 12:16; to assume, put on, Phil. 2:7; to make a rightful or successful assumption of, Jn. 3:27; to conceive, Acts 28:15; to take by way of provision, Mt. 16:5; to get, get together, Mt. 16:9; to receive as payment, Mt. 17:24; Heb. 7:8; to take to wife, Mk. 12:19; to admit, give reception to, Jn. 6:21; 2 Jn. 10; met. to give mental reception to, Jn. 3:11; to be simply recipient of, to receive, Mt. 7:8; Jn. 7:23, 39; 19:30; Acts 10:43; in NT λαμβάνειν πεῖραν, to make encounter of a matter of difficulty or trial, Heb. 11:29, 36; λαμβάνειν ἀρχήν, to begin, Heb. 2:3; λαμβάνειν συμβούλιον, to take counsel, consult, Mt. 12:14; λαμβάνειν λήθην, to forget, 2 Pet. 1:9; λαμβάνειν ὑπόμνησιν, to recollect, call to mind, 2 Tim. 1:5; λαμβάνειν περιτομήν, to receive circumcision, be circumcised, Jn. 7:23; λαμβάνειν καταλλαγήν, to be reconciled, Rom. 5:11; λαμβάνειν κρίμα, to receive condemnation or punishment, be punished, Mk. 12:40; from the Hebrew, πρόσωπον λαμβάνειν, to accept the person of any one, show partiality towards, Lk. 20:21

λαμπας.definition: a light, Acts 20:8; a lamp, Rev. 4:5; 8:10, a portable lamp, lantern, torch, Mt. 25:1, 3, 4, 7, 8; Jn. 18:3*

λαμπρος.definition: bright, resplendent, shining, Rev. 22:16; clear, transparent, Rev. 22:1; white, glistening, Acts 10:30; Rev. 15:6; Rev. 19:8; of a bright color, gaudy, Lk. 23:11; by impl. splendid, magnificent, sumptuous, Jas. 2:2, 3; Rev. 18:14*

λαμπω.definition: to shine, give light, Mt. 5:15, 16; 17:2; to flash, shine, Lk. 17:24; Acts 12:7; 2 Cor. 4:6*

λανθανω.definition: to be unnoticed; to escape the knowledge or observation of a person, Acts 26:26; 2 Pet. 3:5, 8; absol. to be concealed or hidden, escape detection, Mk. 7:24; Lk. 8:47; with a participle of another verb, to be unconscious of an action while being the subject or object of it, Heb. 13:2*

λαξευτος.definition: cut in stone, hewn out of stone or rock, Lk. 23:53*

λαοδικεια.definition: Laodicea, a city of Phrygia in Asia Minor, Rev. 3:14*. See PhotoGuide.

λαοδικευς.definition: a Laodicean, an inhabitant of Laodicea, Col. 4:16*

λαος.definition: a body of people; a concourse of people, a multitude, Mt. 27:25; Lk. 8:47; the common people, Mt. 26:5; a people, nation, Mt. 2:4; Lk. 2:32; Tit. 2:14; ὁ λαός, the people of Israel, Lk. 2:10

λασαια.definition: Lasaea, also spelled Λασέα, a maritime town in Crete, Acts 27:8. See PhotoGuide.

λατομεω.definition: to hew stones; to cut out of stone, hew from stone, Mt. 27:60; Mk. 15:46; Lk. 23:53*

λατρεια.definition: service, servitude; religious service, worship, Jn. 16:2; Rom. 9:4; 12:1; Heb. 9:1, 6*
