λατρευω.definition: to be a servant, to serve, Acts 27:23; to render religious service and homage, worship, Mt. 4:10; Lk. 1:74; spc. to offer sacrifices, present offerings, Heb. 8:5; 9:9

λαχανον.definition: a garden herb, vegetable, Mt. 13:32; Mk. 4:32; Lk. 11:42; Rom. 14:2*

λεγιων.definition: also spelled λεγεών, a Roman legion; in NT used indefinitely for a great number, Mt. 26:53; Mk. 5:9, 15, Lk. 8:30*

g2046,.definition: to lay, to arrange, to gather; to say, Mt. 1:20; to speak, make an address or speech, Acts 26:1; to say mentally, in thought, Mt. 3:9; Lk. 3:8; to say in written language, Mk. 15:28; Lk. 1:63; Jn. 19:37; to say, as distinguished from acting, Mt. 23:3; to mention, speak of, Mk. 14:71; Lk. 9:31; Jn. 8:27; to tell, declare, narrate, Mt. 21:27; Mk. 10:32; to express, Heb. 5:11; to put forth, propound, Lk. 5:36; 13:6; Jn. 16:29; to mean, to intend to signify, 1 Cor. 1:12; 10:29; to say, declare, affirm, maintain, Mt. 3:9; 5:18; Mk. 12:18; Acts 17:7; 26:22; 1 Cor. 1:10; to enjoin, Acts 15:24; 21:21; Rom. 2:22; to term, designate, cull, Mt. 19:17; Mk. 12:37; Lk. 20:37; 23:2; 1 Cor. 8:5; to call by a name, Mt. 2:23; pass. to be further named, to be surnamed, Mt. 1:16; to be explained, interpreted, Jn. 4:25; 20:16, 24; in NT σὺ λέγεις, you say, a form of affirmative answer to a question Mt. 27:11; Mk. 15:2; Jn. 18:37

λειμμα.definition: pr. a remnant; in NT a small residue, Rom. 11:5*

λειπω.definition: trans. to leave, forsake; pass. to be left, deserted; by impl. to be destitute of, deficient in, Jas. 1:4, 5; 2:15; intrans. to fail, be wanting, be deficient, Lk. 18:22; Tit. 1:5; 3:13*

λειτουργεω.definition: pr. to perform some public service at one’s own expense; in NT to officiate as a priest, Heb. 10:11; to minister in the Christian Church, Acts 13:2; to minister to, assist, succor, Rom. 15:27*

λειτουργια.definition: pr. a public service discharged by a citizen at his own expense; in NT a sacred ministration, Lk. 1:23; Phil. 2:17; Heb. 8:6; 9:21; a kind office, aid, relief, 2 Cor. 9:12; Phil. 2:30*

λειτουργικος.definition: ministering; engaged in holy service, Heb. 1:14*

λειτουργος.definition: pr. a person of property who performed a public duty or service to the state at his own expense; in NT a minister or servant, Rom. 13:6; 15:16; Heb. 1:7; 8:2; one who ministers relief, Phil. 2:25*

λεμα.definition: Aramaic for Why? Wherefore? Mt. 27:46; Mk. 15:34*

λεντιον.definition: a coarse cloth, with which servants were girded, a towel, napkin, apron, Jn. 13:4, 5*

λεπις.definition: a scale, shell, rind, crust, incrustation, Acts 9:18*

λευι.definition: Levi, also spelled Λευίς (G3323), pr. name. When the NT refers to the Λευί of the OT, the word is indecl. (n-3g[2]); when it refers to a NT person, it is partially declined (n-3g[1]): Λευίς (nom); Λευίν (acc). (1) Levi, son of Jacob, Heb. 7:5, 9; Rev. 7:7. (2) Levi, son of Symeon, Lk. 3:29 (3) Levi, son of Melchi, Lk. 3:24

λευιτης.definition: a Levite, one of the posterity of Levi, Jn. 1:19; Lk. 10:32; Acts 4:36*

λευιτικος.definition: Levitical, pertaining to the Levites, Heb. 7:11*

λευκαινω.definition: to brighten, to make white, Mk. 9:3; Rev. 7:14*

λευκος.definition: pr. light, bright; white, Mt. 5:36; 17:2; whitening, growing white, Jn. 4:35

λεων.definition: a lion, Heb. 11:33; 1 Pet. 5:8; Rev. 4:7; 9:8, 17; 10:3; 13:2; met. a lion, cruel adversary, tyrant, 2 Tim. 4:17; a lion, a hero, deliverer, Rev. 5:5*

λημψις.definition: also spelled λῆψις, taking, receiving, Phil. 4:15*

ληνος.definition: pr. a tub, trough; a wine-press, into which grapes were cast and trodden, Rev. 14:19, 20; 19:15; a wine-vat, i.q. ὑπολήνιον, the lower vat into which the juice of the trodden grapes flowed, Mt. 21:33*

ληρος.definition: idle talk; an empty tale, nonsense, Lk. 24:11*

ληστης.definition: a plunderer, robber, highwayman, Mt. 21:13; 26:55; Mk. 11:17; Lk. 10:30; 2 Cor. 11:26; a bandit, brigand, Mt. 27:38, 44; Mk. 15:27; Jn. 18:40; trop. a robber, rapacious imposter, Jn. 10:1, 8

λιβανος.definition: arbor thurifera, the tree producing frankincense, growing in Arabia and Mount Lebanon; in NT frankincense, the transparent gum that distils from incisions in the tree, Mt. 2:11; Rev. 18:13*

λιβανωτος.definition: frankincense; in NT a censer, Rev. 8:3, 5*

λιβερτινος.definition: a freedman, one who having been a slave has obtained his freedom, or whose father was a freed-man; in NT the λιβερτῖνοι probably denote Jews who had been carried captive to Rome, and subsequently manumitted, Acts 6:9*

λιβυη.definition: Libya, a part of Africa, bordering on the west of Egypt, Acts 2:10*

λιθαζω.definition: to stone, pelt or kill with stones, Jn. 8:5; 10:31, 32, 33; 11:8; Acts 5:26; 14:19; 2 Cor. 11:25; Heb. 11:37*

λιθινος.definition: made of stone, Jn. 2:6; 2 Cor. 3:3; Rev. 9:20*

λιθοβολεω.definition: to stone, pelt with stones, in order to kill, Mt. 21:35; 23:37

λιθος.definition: a stone, Mt. 3:9; 4:3, 6; used figuratively, of Christ, Eph. 2:20; 1 Pet. 2:6; of believers, 1 Pet. 2:5; meton. a tablet of stone, 2 Cor. 3:7; a precious stone, Rev. 4:3

λιθοστρωτος.definition: a pavement made of blocks of stone, Jn. 19:13*

λικμαω.definition: pr. to winnow grain; in NT to scatter like chaff, crush, Mt. 21:44; Lk. 20:18*

λιμην.definition: a port, haven, harbor, Καλὰ Λιμένες, Acts 27:8, 12*

λιμνη.definition: a tract of standing water; a lake, Lk. 5:1; Rev. 20:14

λιμος.definition: famine, scarcity of food, want of grain, Mt. 24:7; famine, hunger, famishment, Lk. 15:17; Rom. 8:35

λινον.definition: flax; by meton. a flaxen wick, Mt. 12:20; linen, Rev. 15:6*

λινος.definition: some accent as Λῖνος, Linus, pr. name, 2 Tim. 4:21*

λιπαρος.definition: lit., fat; fig., rich, sumptuous, Rev. 18:14*

λιτρα.definition: a pound, libra, equivalent to about twelve ounces (American), Jn. 12:3; 19:39*

λιψ.definition: pr. the south-west wind; meton. the south-west quarter of the heavens, Acts 27:12*

λογιζομαι.definition: (1) pr. to count, calculate; to count, enumerate, Mk. 15:28; Lk. 22:37; to set down as a matter of account, 1 Cor. 13:5; 2 Cor. 3:5; 12:6; to impute, Rom. 4:3; 2 Cor. 5:19; 2 Tim. 4:16; to account, Rom. 2:26; 8:36; εἰς οὐδὲν λογισθῆναι, to be set at nought, despised, Acts 19:27; to regard, deem, consider, Rom. 6:11; 14:14; 1 Cor. 4:1; 2 Cor. 10:2; Phil. 3:13; (2) to infer, conclude, presume, Rom. 2:3; 3:28; 8:18; 2 Cor. 10:2, 7, 11; Heb. 11:19; 1 Pet. 5:12; (3) to think upon, ponder, Phil. 4:8; absol. to reason, Mk. 11:31; 1 Cor. 13:11

λογικος.definition: pertaining to speech; pertaining to reason; in NT rational, spiritual, pertaining to the mind and soul, Rom. 12:1; 1 Pet. 2:2*

λογιον.definition: an oracle, a divine communication or revelation, Acts 7:38; Rom. 3:2; Heb. 5:12; 1 Pet. 4:11*

λογιος.definition: gifted with learning or eloquence, Acts 18:24*

λογισμος.definition: pr. a computation, act of computing; a thought, cogitation, Rom. 2:15; a conception, device, 2 Cor. 10:4*

λογομαχεω.definition: to contend about words; by impl. to dispute about trivial things, 2 Tim. 2:14*

λογομαχια.definition: contention or strife about words; by impl. a dispute about trivial things, unprofitable controversy, 1 Tim. 6:4*

λογος.definition: a word, a thing uttered, Mt. 12:32, 37; 1 Cor. 14:19; speech, language, talk, Mt. 22:15; Lk. 20:20; 2 Cor. 10:10; Jas. 3:2; converse, Lk. 24:17; mere talk, wordy show, 1 Cor. 4:19, 20; Col. 2:23; 1 Jn. 3:18; language, mode of discourse, style of speaking, Mt. 5:37; 1 Cor. 1:17; 1 Thess. 2:5; a saying, a speech, Mk. 7:29; Eph. 4:29; an expression, form of words, formula, Mt. 26:44; Rom. 13:9; Gal. 5:14; a saying, a thing propounded in discourse, Mt. 7:24; 19:11; Jn. 4:37; 6:60; 1 Tim. 1:15; a message, announcement, 2 Cor. 5:19; a prophetic announcement, Jn. 12:38; an account, statement, 1 Pet. 3:15; a story, report, Mt. 28:15; Jn. 4:39; 21:23; 2 Thess. 2:2; a written narrative, a treatise, Acts 1:1; a set discourse, Acts 20:7; doctrine, Jn. 8:31, 37; 2 Tim. 2:17; subject-matter, Acts 15:6; reckoning, account, Mt. 12:36; 18:23; 25:19; Lk. 16:2; Acts 19:40; 20:24; Rom. 9:28; Phil. 4:15, 17; Heb. 4:13; a plea, Mt. 5:32; Acts 19:38; a motive, Acts 10:29; reason, Acts 18:14; ὁ λόγος, the word of God, especially in the Gospel, Mt. 13:21, 22; Mk. 16:20; Lk. 1:2; Acts 6:4; ὁ λόγος, the divine WORD, or Logos, Jn. 1:1

λογχη.definition: pr. the head of a javelin; a spear, lance, Jn. 19:34*

λοιδορεω.definition: to revile, rail at, abuse, Jn. 9:28; Acts 23:4; 1 Cor. 4:12; 1 Pet. 2:23*

λοιδορια.definition: reviling, railing, verbal abuse, 1 Tim. 5:14; 1 Pet. 3:9*

λοιδορος.definition: reviling, railing; as a subst. a reviler, railer, 1 Cor. 5:11; 6:10*

λοιμος.definition: a pestilence, plague, Lk. 21:11; met. a pest, pestilent fellow, Acts 24:5*

g3063,.definition: remaining; the rest, remainder, Mt. 22:6; as an adv., οῦ λοιποῦ, henceforth, Gal. 6:17; τὸ λοιπόν, or λοιπόν, henceforward, Mt. 26:45; 2 Tim. 4:8; Acts 27:20; as to the rest, besides, 1 Cor. 1:16; finally, Eph. 6:10; ὁ δὲ λοιπόν, but, now, furthermore, 1 Cor. 4:2

λουκιος.definition: Lucius, pr. name, (1) a person from Cyrene of Antioch, Acts 13:1. (2) a person who sends his greeting with Paul, Rom. 16:21*

λουτρον.definition: a bath, water for bathing; a bathing, washing, ablution, Eph. 5:26; Tit. 3:5*

λουω.definition: pr. to bathe the body, as distinguished from washing only the extremities, Jn. 13:10; to bathe, wash, Acts 9:37; 16:33; Heb. 10:22; 2 Pet. 2:22*

λυδδα.definition: Lydda, a town in Palestine, Acts 9:32, 35, 38*. See PhotoGuide.

λυδια.definition: Lydia, pr. name of a woman, Acts 16:14, 40*

λυκαονια.definition: Lycaonia, a province of Asia Minor, Acts 14:6*

λυκαονιστι.definition: in the dialect of Lycaonia, Acts 14:11*

λυκια.definition: Lycia, a province of Asia Minor, Acts 27:5*

λυκος.definition: a wolf, Mt. 10:16; Lk. 10:3; Jn. 10:12; met. a person of wolf-like character, Mt. 7:15; Acts 20:29*

λυμαινω.definition: some list as a deponent, λυμαίνομαι, to outrage, harm, violently maltreat; in NT to make havoc of, ruin, Acts 8:3*

λυπεω.definition: to occasion grief or sorrow to, to distress, 2 Cor. 2:2, 5; 7:8; pass. to be grieved, pained, distressed, sorrowful, Mt. 17:23; 19:22; to aggrieve, cross, vex, Eph. 4:30; pass. to feel pained, Rom. 14:15

λυπη.definition: pain, distress, Jn. 16:21; grief, sorrow, Jn. 16:6, 20, 22; meton. cause of grief, trouble, affliction, 1 Pet. 2:19

λυσις.definition: a loosing; in NT a release from the marriage bond, a divorce, 1 Cor. 7:27*

λυσιτελεω.definition: pr. to compensate for incurred expense; by impl. to be advantageous to, to profit, advantage; impers. Lk. 17:2*

λυστρα.definition: Lystra, a city of Lycaonia, in Asia Minor, Acts 14:6, 8, 21; 16:1f.; 2 Tim. 3:11*. See PhotoGuide.

λυτρον.definition: pr. price paid; a ransom, Mt. 20:28; Mk. 10:45*

λυτροω.definition: to release for a ransom; mid, to ransom, redeem, deliver, liberate, Lk. 24:21; Tit. 2:14; 1 Pet. 1:18*

λυχνια.definition: a candlestick, lampstand, Mt. 5:15; met. a candlestick, as a figure of a Christian church, Rev. 1:12, 13, 20; of a teacher or prophet, Rev. 11:4

λυχνος.definition: a light, lamp, candle, etc., Mt. 5:15; Mk. 4:21; met. a lamp, as a figure of a distinguished teacher, Jn. 5:35

λυω.definition: to loosen, unbind, unfasten, Mk. 1:7; to loose, untie, Mt. 21:2; Jn. 11:44; to disengage, 1 Cor. 7:27; to set free, set at liberty, deliver, Lk. 13:16; to break, Acts 27:41; Rev. 5:2, 5; to break up, dismiss, Acts 13:43; to destroy, demolish, Jn. 2:19; Eph. 2:14; met to infringe, Mt. 5:19; Jn. 5:18; 7:23; to make void, nullify, Jn. 10:35; in NT to declare free, of privileges, or, in respect of lawfulness, Mt. 16:19

λωις.definition: Lois, pr. name of a woman, 2 Tim. 1:5*

λωτ.definition: Lot, pr. name, indecl., Lk. 17:28, 29, 32; 2 Pet. 2:7*

μαγεια.definition: pr. the system of the magians; magic, Acts 8:11*

μαγευω.definition: to be a magician; to use magical arts, practise magic, sorcery, Acts 8:9*

μαγος.definition: (1) a magus, sage of the magician religion, magician, astrologer, wise man, Mt. 2:1, 7, 16; (2) a magician, sorcerer, Acts 13:6, 8*

μαδιαμ.definition: Madian, a district of Arabia Petra, Acts 7:29*

μαθητευω.definition: intrans. to be a disciple, follow as a disciple, Mt. 27:57; in NT trans. to make a disciple of, to train in discipleship, Mt. 28:19; Acts 14:21; pass. to be trained, disciplined, instructed, Mt. 13:52*

μαθητρια.definition: a female disciple; a female Christian, Acts 9:36*

μαθθατ.definition: also spelled Ματθάτ, Mathat, pr. name, indecl., Lk. 3:24, 29*

μαθθιας.definition: also spelled Ματθίας, BDAG 611, suggest it is a shortened form of Ματταθίας, Matthias, pr. name, Acts 1:23, 26*

μαινομαι.definition: to be disordered in mind, mad, Jn. 10:20; Acts 12:15; 26:24, 25; 1 Cor. 14:23*

μακαριζω.definition: to pronounce happy, fortunate, Lk. 1:48; Jas. 5:11*

μακαριος.definition: happy, blessed, as a noun it can depict someone who receives divine favor, Mt. 5:3, 4, 5, 7; Lk. 1: 45

μακαρισμος.definition: a happy calling, the act of pronouncing happy, Rom. 4:6, 9; self-congratulation, Gal. 4:15*

μακεδονια.definition: Macedonia, Acts 16:9; Rom. 15:26; 1 Cor. 16:5; 1 Thess. 1:7; 1 Tim. 1:3

μακεδων.definition: a native of Macedonia, Acts 16:9; 19:29; 27:2; 2 Cor. 9:2, 4*

μακελλον.definition: meat market, marketplace, slaughter house, 1 Cor. 10:25*

μακραν.definition: far, far off, at a distance, far distant, Mt. 8:30; Mk. 12:34; met. οἱ μακράν, remote, alien, Eph. 2:13, 17; so οἱ εἰς μακράν, Acts 2:39

μακροθεν.definition: far off, at a distance, from afar, from a distance, Mk. 8:3; 11:13; preceded by ἀπό, in the same sense, Mt. 26:58

μακροθυμεω.definition: to be slow towards, be long-enduring; to exercise patience, be long-suffering, clement, or indulgent, to forbear, Mt. 18:26, 29; 1 Cor. 13:4; 1 Thess. 5:14; 2 Pet. 3:9; to have patience, endure patiently, wait with patient expectation, Heb. 6:15; Jas. 5:7, 8; to bear long with entreaties for deliverance and avengement, Lk. 18:7*

μακροθυμια.definition: patience; patient enduring of evil, fortitude, Col. 1:11; Col. 3:12; 1 Tim. 1:16; 1 Pet. 3:20; slowness of avenging injuries, long-suffering, forbearance, clemency, Rom. 2:4; 9:22; 2 Cor. 6:6; Gal. 5:22; Eph. 4:2; 2 Tim. 4:2; Jas. 5:10; patient expectation, 2 Tim. 3:10; Heb. 6:12; 2 Pet. 3:15*

μακρος.definition: long; of space, far, distant, remote, Lk. 15:13; 19:12; of time, of long duration, Mk. 12:40; Lk. 20:47*

μαλακια.definition: softness; listlessness, indisposition, weakness, infirmity of body, Mt. 4:23; 9:35; 10:1*

μαλακος.definition: soft; soft to the touch, delicate, Mt. 11:8; Lk. 7:25; met. an instrument of unnatural lust, effeminate, 1 Cor. 6:9*

μαλιστα.definition: most, most of all, chiefly, especially, Acts 20:38; 25:26

μαλλον.definition: more, to a greater extent, in a higher degree, Mt. 18:13; 27:24; Jn. 5:18; 1 Cor. 14:18; rather, in preference, Mt. 10:6; Eph. 4:28; used in a periphrasis for the comparative, Acts 20:35; as an intensive with a comparative term, Mt. 6:26; Mk. 7:36; 2 Cor. 7:13; Phil. 1:23; μᾶλλον δέ, yea rather, or, more properly speaking, Rom. 8:34; Gal. 4:9; Eph. 5:11

μαμμη.definition: a mother; later, a grandmother, 2 Tim. 1:5*

μαμωνας.definition: wealth, riches, Lk. 16:9, 11; personified, like the Greek Πλοῦτος, Mammon, Mt. 6:24; Lk. 16:13*

μανασσης.definition: Manasses, pr. name (1) the tribe of Manasseh, Rev. 7:6 (2) Manasseh, king of Judah, Mt. 1:10*

μανθανω.definition: to learn, be taught, Mt. 9:13; 11:29; 24:32; to learn by practice or experience, acquire a custom or habit, Phil. 4:11; 1 Tim. 5:4, 13; to ascertain, be informed, Acts 23:27; to understand, comprehend, Rev. 14:3

μαννα.definition: manna, the miraculous food of the Israelites while in the desert, Jn. 6:31, 49; Heb. 9:4; Rev. 2:17*

μαντευομαι.definition: to speak oracles, to divine, Acts 16:16*

μαραινω.definition: to quench, cause to decay, fade, or wither; pass. to wither, waste away, met. to fade away, disappear, perish, Jas. 1:11*

μαρια.definition: Mary, pr. name (1) The mother of Jesus, Mt. 1:16; Acts 1:14. (2) Mary, wife of Clopas, mother of James, Mk. 15:40; Lk. 24:10; Jn. 19:25. (3) Mary Magdalene, Mt. 27:56; Lk. 20:18. (4) Sister of Martha and Lazarus, Lk. 10:39; Jn. 11:1; 12:3. (5) Mother of Jn. surnamed Mark, Acts 12:12 (6) A Christian at Rome, Rom. 16:6

μαρμαρος.definition: a white glistening stone; marble, Rev. 18:12*

μαρτυρεω.definition: trans. to testify, depose, Jn. 3:11, 32; 1 Jn. 1:2; Rev. 1:2; 22:20; absol. to give evidence, Jn. 18:23; to bear testimony, testify, Lk. 4:22; Jn. 1:7, 8; to bear testimony in confirmation, Acts 14:3; to declare distinctly and formally, Jn. 4:44; pass. to be the subject of testimony, to obtain attestation to character, Acts 6:3; 10:22; 1 Tim. 5:10; Heb. 11:2, 4; mid. equivalent to μαρτύρομαι, to make a solemn appeal, Acts 26:22; 1 Thess. 2:12

μαρτυρια.definition: judicial evidence, Mk. 14:55, 56, 59; Lk. 22:71; testimony in general, Tit. 1:13; 1 Jn. 5:9 testimony, declaration in a matter of fact or doctrine, Jn. 1:19; 3:11; Acts 22:18; attestation to character, Jn. 5:34, 36; reputation, 1 Tim. 3:7

μαρτυριον.definition: testimony, evidence, Acts 4:33; 2 Cor. 1:12; Jas. 5:3; in NT testimony, mode of solemn declaration, Mt. 8:4; Lk. 9:5; testimony, matter of solemn declaration, 1 Cor. 1:6; 2:1; 1 Tim. 2:6; σκηνὴ τοῦ μαρτυρίου, a title of the Mosaic tabernacle, Acts 7:44; Rev. 15:5

μαρτυρομαι.definition: to call to witness; intrans. to make a solemn affirmation or declaration, Acts 20:26; 26:22; Gal. 5:3; to make a solemn appeal, Eph. 4:17; 1 Thess. 2:12*

μαρτυς.definition: (1) a judicial witness, deponent, Mt. 18:16; Heb. 10:28; (2) generally, a witness to a circumstance, Lk. 24:48; Acts 10:41; in NT a witness, a testifier, of a doctrine, Rev. 1:5; 3:14; 11:3; (3) a martyr, Acts 22:20; Rev. 2:13

μασαομαι.definition: to chew, masticate, in NT to gnaw, Rev. 16:10*

μαστιγοω.definition: to scourge, whip, Mt. 10:17; 20:19; 23:34; Mk. 10:34; Lk. 18:33; Jn. 19:1; met. to chastise, Heb. 12:6*

μαστιξ.definition: a scourge, whip, Acts 22:24; Heb. 11:36; met. a scourge of disease, Mk. 3:10; 5:29, 34; Lk. 7:21*

ματαιολογος.definition: a vain talker, given to vain talking or trivial disputation, Tit. 1:10*

ματαιος.definition: idle, ineffective, worthless, 1 Cor. 3:20; groundless, deceptive, fallacious, 1 Cor. 15:17; useless, fruitless, unprofitable, Tit. 3:9; Jas. 1:26; from the Hebrew, erroneous in principle, corrupt, perverted, 1 Pet. 1:18; τὰ μάταια, superstition, idolatry, Acts 14:15*

ματαιοτης.definition: vanity, folly, futility, from the Hebrew, religious error, Eph. 4:17; 2 Pet. 2:18; false religion, Rom. 8:20*

ματαιοω.definition: to make vain; from the Hebrew, pass. to fall into religious error, to be perverted, Rom. 1:21*

ματην.definition: in vain, fruitlessly, without profit, Mt. 15:9; Mk. 7:7*

ματταθιας.definition: see also Μαθθίας, Mattathias, pr. name, Lk. 3:25, 26*

μαχαιρα.definition: a large knife, dagger; a sword, Mt. 26:47, 51; the sword of the executioner, Acts 12:2; Rom. 8:35; Heb. 11:37; hence, φορεῖν μάχαιραν, to bear the sword, to have the power of life and death, Rom. 13:4; meton. war, Mt. 10:34

μαχη.definition: a fight, battle, conflict; in NT contention, dispute, strife, controversy, 2 Cor. 7:5; 2 Tim. 2:23; Tit. 3:9; Jas. 4:1*

μαχομαι.definition: to fight; to quarrel, Acts 7:26; 2 Tim. 2:24; to contend, dispute, Jn. 6:52; Jas. 4:2*

μεγαλειος.definition: magnificent, splendid; τὰ μεγαλεῖα, great things, wonderful works, Acts 2:11*

μεγαλειοτης.definition: majesty, magnificence, glory, Lk. 9:43; Acts 19:27; 2 Pet. 1:16*

μεγαλοπρεπης.definition: pr. becoming a great man; magnificent, glorious, most splendid, 2 Pet. 1:17*

μεγαλυνω.definition: lit., to enlarge, amplify, Mt. 23:5; 2 Cor. 10:15; to manifest in an extraordinary degree, Lk. 1:58; fig., to magnify, exalt, extol, Lk. 1:46; Acts 5:13; Acts 10:46; 19:17; Phil. 1:20*

μεγαλωσυνη.definition: greatness, majesty, Heb. 1:3; 8:1; ascribed majesty, Jude 25*

μεγας.definition: great, large in size, Mt. 27:60; Mk. 4:32; great, much, numerous, Mk. 5:11; Heb. 11:26; great, grown up, adult, Heb. 11:24; great, vehement, intense, Mt. 2:10; 28:8; great, sumptuous, Lk. 5:29; great, important, weighty, of high importance, 1 Cor. 9:11; 13:13; great, splendid, magnificent, Rev. 15:3; extraordinary, wonderful, 2 Cor. 11:15; great, solemn, Jn. 7:37; 19:31; great in rank, noble, Rev. 11:18; 13:16; great in dignity, distinguished, eminent, illustrious, powerful, Mt. 5:19; 18:1, 4; great, arrogant, boastful, Rev. 13:5

μεγισταν.definition: great men, lords, chiefs, nobles, princes, Mk. 6:21; Rev. 6:15; 18:23*

μεθερμηνευω.definition: to translate, interpret, Mt. 1:23; Mk. 5:41; 15:22, 34; Jn. 1:38, 41; Acts 4:36; 13:8*

μεθη.definition: strong drink; drunkenness, Lk. 21:34; an indulgence in drinking, Rom. 13:13; Gal. 5:21*

μεθιστημι.definition: to cause a change of position; to remove, transport, 1 Cor. 13:2; to transfer, Col. 1:13; met. to cause to change sides; by impl. to pervert, mislead, Acts 19:26; to remove from office, dismiss, discard, Lk. 16:4; Acts 13:22*

μεθυσκω.definition: to inebriate, make drunk; pass. to be intoxicated, to be drunk, Lk. 12:45; Eph. 5:18; 1 Thess. 5:7; Rev. 17:2; to drink freely, Jn. 2:10*

μεθυω.definition: to be intoxicated, be drunk, Mt. 24:49; Acts 2:15; 1 Cor. 11:21; 1 Thess. 5:7; Rev. 17:6*

g3189.definition: black, Mt. 5:36; Rev. 6:5, 12, the form μέλαν means ink, 2 Cor. 3:3; 2 Jn. 12; 3 Jn. 13

μελει.definition: there is a care, it concerns, Mt. 22:16; Acts 18:17; 1 Cor. 7:21; 9:9

μελεταω.definition: to care for; to bestow careful thought upon, to give painful attention to, be earnest in, 1 Tim. 4:15; to devise, Acts 4:25*

μελιτη.definition: also spelled Μελιτήνη, Malta, an island in the Mediterranean, Acts 28:1*

μελλω.definition: to be about to, be on the point of, Mt. 2:13; Jn. 4:47; it serves to express in general a settled futurity, Mt. 11:14; Lk. 9:31; Jn. 11:51; to intend, Lk. 10:1; participle μέλλων, μέλλουσα, μέλλον, future as distinguished from past and present, Mt. 12:32; Lk. 13:9; to be always, as it were, about to do, to delay, linger, Acts 22:16

μελος.definition: a member, limb, any part of the body, Mt. 5:29, 30; Rom. 12:4; 1 Cor. 6:15; 12:12

μεμφομαι.definition: to find fault with, blame, censure; to intimate dissatisfaction with, Heb. 8:8; absol. to find fault, Rom. 9:19*

μεμψιμοιρος.definition: finding fault or being discontented with one’s lot, querulous; a discontented, querulous person, a complainer, Jude 16*

μεν.definition: a particle serving to indicate that the term or clause with which it is used stands distinguished from another, usually in the sequel, and then mostly with δέ correspondent, Mt. 3:11; 9:39; Acts 1:1; ὁ μὲν ... ὁ δέ, this ... that, the one ... the other, Phil. 1:16, 17; one ... another, οἱ μὲν ... οἱ δέ, some ... others, Matt 22:5; ὅλλος μὲν ... ὅλλος δέ, one ... another, pl. some ... others, Matt 13:8; 21:35; ὅλλος μὲν ... ὅλλος δέ, one ... another, 1 Cor. 15:39; ὡδε μὲν ... ἐκεῖ δέ, here ... there, Heb. 7:8; τοῦτο μὲν ... τοῦτο δέ, partly ... partly, Heb. 10:33

μενουνγε.definition: also spelled as two words, μενοῦν γε (Lk. 11:28), a combination of particles serving to take up what has just preceded, with either emphasize or to correct; indeed, really, truly, rather, Rom. 9:20; 10:18; Phil. 3:8*

μενω.definition: pluperfect, μεμενήκειν, to stay, Mt. 26:38; Acts 27:31; to continue; 1 Cor. 7:11; 2 Tim. 2:13; to dwell, lodge, sojourn, Jn. 1:39; Acts 9:43; to remain, Jn. 9:41; to rest, settle, Jn. 1:32, 33; 3:36; to last, endure, Mt. 11:23; Jn. 6:27; 1 Cor. 3:14; to survive, 1 Cor. 15:6; to be existent, 1 Cor. 13:13; to continue unchanged, Rom. 9:11; to be permanent, Jn. 15:16; 2 Cor. 3:11; Heb. 10:34; 13:14; 1 Pet. 1:23; to persevere, be constant, be steadfast, 1 Tim. 2:15; 2 Tim. 3:14; to abide, to be in close and settled union, Jn. 6:56; 14:10; 15:4; to indwell, Jn. 5:38; 1 Jn. 2:14; trans. to wait for, Acts 20:5, 23 See abide; await; remain; stay; wait for.

μεριζω.definition: to divide; to divide out, distribute, Mk. 6:41; to assign, bestow, Rom. 12:3; 1 Cor. 7:17; 2 Cor. 10:13; Heb. 7:2; mid. to share, Lk. 12:13; pass. to be subdivided, to admit distinctions, Mk. 3:24-26; 1 Cor. 1:13; to be severed by discord, be at variance, Mt. 12:25, 26; to differ, 1 Cor. 7:34*

μεριμνα.definition: care, Mt. 13:22; Mk. 4:19; Lk. 8:14; 21:34; anxiety, anxious interest, 2 Cor. 11:28; 1 Pet. 5:7*

μεριμναω.definition: to be anxious, or solicitous, Phil. 4:6; to expend careful thought, Mt. 6:27, 28, 31, 34a; 10:19; Lk. 10:41; 12:11, 22, 25, 26; to concern one’s self, Mt. 6:25; 1 Cor. 12:25; to have the thoughts occupied with, 1 Cor. 7:32, 33, 34; to feel an interest in, Phil. 2:20*

μερις.definition: a part; a division of a country, district, region, tract, Acts 16:12; a portion, Lk. 10:42; an allotted portion, Col. 1:12; a portion in common, share, Acts 8:21; 2 Cor. 6:15*

μερισμος.definition: a dividing, act of dividing, Heb. 4:12; distribution, gifts distributed, Heb. 2:4*

μερος.definition: a part, portion, division, of a whole, Lk. 11:36; 15:12; Acts 5:2; Eph. 4:16; a piece, fragment, Lk. 24:42; Jn. 19:23; a party, faction, Acts 23:9; allotted portion, lot, destiny, Mt. 24:51; Lk. 12:46; a calling, craft, Acts 19:27; a partner’s portion, partnership, fellowship, Jn. 13:8; pl. μέρη, a local quarter, district, region, Mt. 2:22; 16:13; Acts 19:1; Eph. 4:9; side of a ship, Jn. 21:6; ἐν μέρει, in respect, 2 Cor. 3:10; 9:3; Col. 2:16; 1 Pet. 4:16; μέρος τι, partly, in some part, 1 Cor. 11:18; ἀνὰ μέρος, alternately, one after another, 1 Cor. 14:27; ἀπὸ μέρους, partly, in some part or measure, 2 Cor. 1:14; ἐκ μέρους, individually, 1 Cor. 12:27; partly, imperfectly, 1 Cor. 13:9; κατὰ μέρος, particularly, in detail, Heb. 9:5

μεσημβρια.definition: mid-day, noon, Acts 22:6; meton. the south, Acts 8:26*

μεσιτευω.definition: to perform offices between two parties; to intervene, interpose, Heb. 6:17*

μεσιτης.definition: one that acts between two parties; a mediator, one who interposes to reconcile two adverse parties, 1 Tim. 2:5; an arbitrator, one who is the medium of communication between two parties, a mid-party, Gal. 3:19, 20; Heb. 8:6; 9:15; 12:24*

μεσοποταμια.definition: Mesopotamia, the country lying between the rivers Tigris and Euphrates, Acts 2:9; 7:2*

μεσος.definition: mid, middle, Mt. 25:6; Acts 26:13; ἀνὰ μέσον, in the midst; from the Hebrew, in, among, Mt. 13:25; between, 1 Cor. 6:5; διὰ μέσου, through the midst of, Lk. 4:30; εἰς τὸ μέσον, into, or in the midst, Mk. 3:3; Lk. 6:8; ἐκ μέσου, from the midst, out of the way, Col. 2:14; 2 Thess. 2:7; from the Hebrew, from, from among, Mt. 13:49; ἐν τῷ μέσῳ, in the midst, Mt. 10:16; in the midst, in public, publicly, Mt. 14:6 ἐν μέσῳ, in the midst of; among, Mt. 18:20; κατὰ μέσον τῆς νυκτός, about midnight, Acts 27:27

μεσοτοιχον.definition: a middle wall; a partition wall, a barrier, Eph. 2:14*

μεσοω.definition: to be in the middle or midst; to be advanced midway, Jn. 7:14*

μεσσιας.definition: the Messiah, the Anointed One, i.q. ὁ Χριστός, Jn. 1:42, 4:25*

μεστος.definition: full, full of, filled with, Jn. 19:29; 21:11; replete, Mt. 23:28; Rom. 1:29; 15:14; Jas. 3:8, 17; 2 Pet. 2:14*

μεστοω.definition: to fill; pass. to be filled, be full, Acts 2:13*

μετα.definition: (1) gen., with, together with, Mt. 16:27; 12:41; 26:55; with, on the same side or party with, in aid of, Mt. 12:30; 20:20; with, by means of, Acts 13:17; with, of conflict, Rev. 11:7; with, among, Lk. 24:5; with, to, towards, Lk. 1:58, 72; (2) acc., after, of place, behind, Heb. 9:3; of time, after, Mt. 17:1; 24:29; followed by an infin. with the neut. article, after, after that, Mt. 26:32; Lk. 22:20

μεταβαινω.definition: to go or pass from one place to another, Jn. 5:24; to pass away, be removed, Mt. 17:20; to go away, depart, Mt. 8:34

μεταβαλλω.definition: to change; mid. to change one’s mind, Acts 28:6*

μεταγω.definition: to lead or move from one place to another; to change direction, turn about, Jas. 3:3, 4*

μεταδιδωμι.definition: to give a part, to share, Lk. 3:11; to impart, bestow, Rom. 1:11; 12:8; Eph. 4:28; 1 Thess. 2:8*

μεταθεσις.definition: a removal, translation, Heb. 11:5; 12:27; a transmutation, change by the abolition of one thing, and the substitution of another, Heb. 7:12*

μεταιρω.definition: to remove, transfer; in NT intrans. to go away, depart, Mt. 13:53; 19:1*

μετακαλεω.definition: to call from one place into another; mid. to call or send for, invite to come to oneself, Acts 7:14; 10:32; 20:17; 24:25*

μετακινεω.definition: to move away, remove; pass. met. to stir away from, to swerve, Col. 1:23*

μεταλαμβανω.definition: to partake of, share in, Acts 2:46; 27:33f.; 2 Tim. 2:6; Heb. 6:7; 12:10; to get, obtain, find, Acts 24:25*

μεταλημψις.definition: a partaking of, a being partaken of, 1 Tim. 4:3*

μεταλλασσω.definition: to exchange, change for or into, transmute, Rom. 1:25, 26*

μεταμελομαι.definition: to change one’s judgment on past points of conduct; to change one’s mind and purpose, Heb. 7:21; to repent, regret, Mt. 21:29, 32; 27:3; 2 Cor. 7:8*

μεταμορφοω.definition: to change the external form, transfigure; mid. to change one’s form, be transfigured, Mt. 17:2; Mk. 9:2; to undergo a spiritual transformation Rom. 12:2; 2 Cor. 3:18*

μετανοεω.definition: to undergo a change in frame of mind and feeling, to repent, Lk. 17:3, 4; to make a change of principle and practice, to reform, Mt. 3:2

μετανοια.definition: a change of mode of thought and feeling, repentance, Mt. 3:8; Acts 20:21; 2 Tim. 2:25; practical reformation, Lk. 15:7; reversal of the past, Heb. 12:17

μεταξυ.definition: can function as an improper prep., between, Mt. 23:35; Lk. 11:51; 16:26; Acts 15:9; ἐν τῷ μεταξύ, i.e. χρόνῷ, in the meantime, meanwhile, Jn. 4:31; in NT ὁ μεταξύ, following, succeeding, Acts 13:42

μεταπεμπω.definition: to send after; mid. to send after or for any one, invite to come to one’s self, Acts 10:5, 22, 29; 11:13; 20:1; 24:24, 26; 25:3*

μεταστρεφω.definition: to turn about; convert into something else, change, Acts 2:20; by impl. to pervert, Gal. 1:7*

μετασχηματιζω.definition: to remodel, transfigure, Phil. 3:21; mid. to transform one’s self, 2 Cor. 11:13, 14, 15; to transfer an imagination, 1 Cor. 4:6*

μετατιθημι.definition: to transport, Acts 7:16; to transfer, Heb. 7:12; to translate out of the world, Heb. 11:5; met. to transfer to other purposes, to pervert, Jude 4; mid. to transfer one’s self, to change over, Gal. 1:6*

μετατρεπω.definition: to turn around, change, alter, Jas. 4:9*

μετεχω.definition: to share in, partake, 1 Cor. 9:10, 12; 10:17, 21; 1 Cor. 10:30; Heb. 2:14; 5:13; to be a member of, Heb. 7:13*

μετεωριζομαι.definition: to raise aloft; met. to unsettle in mind; pass. to be excited with anxiety, be in anxious suspense, Lk. 12:29*

μετοικεσια.definition: change of abode or country, migration, Mt. 1:11, 12, 17*

μετοικιζω.definition: to cause to change abode, cause to emigrate, Acts 7:4, 43*

μετοχη.definition: a sharing, partaking; communion, fellowship, 2 Cor. 6:14*

μετοχος.definition: a partaker, Heb. 3:1, 14; 6:4; 12:8; an associate, partner, fellow, Lk. 5:7; Heb. 1:9*

μετρεω.definition: to allot, measure, Mt. 7:2; Mk. 4:24; Lk. 6:38; Rev. 11:1, 2; 21:15-17; met. to estimate, 2 Cor. 10:12*

μετρητης.definition: pr. a measurer; also, metretes, Latin metreta, equivalent to the Attic ἀμφορεύς, i.e., three-fourths of the Attic μέδιμνος, and therefore equal to about nine gallons, Jn. 2:6*

μετριοπαθεω.definition: to moderate one’s passions; to be gentle, compassionate, Heb. 5:2*

μετριως.definition: moderately; slightly; οὐ μετρίως no little, not a little, much, greatly, Acts 20:12*

μετρον.definition: measure, Mt. 7:2; Mk. 4:24; Lk. 6:38; Rev. 21:17; measure, standard, Eph. 4:13; extent, compass, 2 Cor. 10:13; allotted measure, specific portion, Rom. 12:3; Eph. 4:7, 16; ἐκ μέτρον, by measure, with definite limitation, Jn. 3:34

μεχρι.definition: improper prep. and a conj (until), can also spelled μέχρις, unto, even to, Rom. 15:19; of time, until, till, Mt. 11:23; Mk. 13:30

μη.definition: a negative particle, can function as a conj, not, for the particulars of its usage, especially as distinguished from that of οὐ, consult a grammar; as a conj., lest, that not, Mt. 5:29, 30; 18:10; 24:6; Mk. 13:36; μή, or μήτι, or μήποτε, when prefixed to an interrogative clause, it expresses an intimation either of the reality of the matters respecting which the question is asked, Mt. 12:23; or the contrary, Jn. 4:12

μηδε.definition: negative disjunctive particle, can function as an adverb and a conj, neither, and repeated, neither-nor, Mt. 6:25; 7:6; 10:9, 10; not even, not so much as, Mk. 2:2

μηδεις.definition: not one, none, no one, Mt. 8:4

μηδεποτε.definition: not at any time, never, 2 Tim. 3:7*

μηδεπω.definition: not yet, not as yet, Heb. 11:7*

μηδος.definition: a Mede, a native of Media in Asia, Acts 2:9*

μηκυνω.definition: to lengthen, prolong; mid. to grow up, as plants, Mk. 4:27*

μην.definition: a month, Lk. 1:24, 26, 36, 56; in NT the new moon, the day of the new moon, Gal. 4:10

μηνυω.definition: to disclose what is secret, Jn. 11:57; Acts 23:30; 1 Cor. 10:28; to declare, indicate, Lk. 20:37*

μηποτε.definition: can function as an adverb, BDAG 648, lists it as a negative part., conj., and interrogative part., same signif. and usage as μή, Mt. 4:6; 13:15; Heb. 9:17; also, whether, Lk. 3:15

μηπω.definition: not yet, not as yet, Rom. 9:11; Heb. 9:8*

μητε.definition: neither; μήτε ... μήτε, or μὴ ... μήτε, or μηδὲ ... μητέ, neither ... nor, Mt. 5:34, 35, 36; Acts 23:8; 2 Thess. 2:2; in NT also equivalent to μηδέ, not even, not so much as, Mk. 3:20

μητηρ.definition: a mother, Mt. 1:18; 12:49, 50, et al. freq.; a parent city, Gal. 4:26; Rev. 17:5

g3387.definition: interrogative particle, used in questions expecting a negative answer; has the same use as μή in the form εἰ μήτε, Lk. 9:3; also when prefixed to an interrogative clause, Mt. 7:16; Jn. 4:29

μητρολωας.definition: one who murders or strikes his mother, matricide, 1 Tim. 1:9*

μιαινω.definition: pr. to tinge, dye, stain; to pollute, defile, ceremonially, Jn. 18:28; to corrupt, deprave, Tit. 1:15 (2x); Heb. 12:15; Jude 8*

μιγνυμι.definition: also spelled μείγνυμι, to mix, mingle, Mt. 27:34; Lk. 13:1; Rev. 8:7

g3398.definition: little, small in size quantity, etc. Mt. 13:32; Lk. 12:32; Rev. 3:8; small, little in age, young, not adult, Mk. 15:40; little, short in time, Jn. 7:33; μικρόν, i.e. χρόνον, a little while, a short time, Jn. 13:33; μετὰ μικρόν, after a little while, a little while afterwards, Mt. 26:73; little in number, Lk. 12:32; small, little in dignity, low, humble, Mt. 10:42; 11:11; μικρόν, as an adv., little, a little, Mt. 26:39

μιλητος.definition: Miletus, a seaport city of Caria, on the west coast of Asia Minor, Acts 20:15, 17; 2 Tim. 4:20*

μιλιον.definition: a Roman mile, which contained mille passuum, 1000 paces, or 8 stadia, 4,854 feet, Mt. 5:41*

μιμεομαι.definition: to imitate, follow as an example, strive to resemble, 2 Thess. 3:7, 9; Heb. 13:7; 3 Jn. 11*

μιμητης.definition: an imitator, follower, 1 Cor. 4:16; 11:1; Eph. 5:1; 1 Thess. 1:6; 2:14; Heb. 6:12*

μιμνησκομαι.definition: to remember, recollect, call to mind, Mt. 26:75; Lk. 1:54, 72; 16:25; in NT, in a passive sense, to be called to mind, be borne in mind, Acts 10:31; Rev. 16:19

μισεω.definition: to hate, regard with ill-will, Mt. 5:43, 44; 10:22; to detest, abhor, Jn. 3:20; Rom. 7:15; in NT to regard with less affection, love less, esteem less, Mt. 6:24; Lk. 14:26

μισθαποδοσια.definition: pr. the discharge of wages; requital; reward, Heb. 10:35; 11:26; punishment, Heb. 2:2*

μισθαποδοτης.definition: a bestower of remuneration; recompenser, rewarder, Heb. 11:6*

μισθιος.definition: hired; as a subst., a hired servant, hireling, Lk. 15:17, 19*

μισθος.definition: hire, wages, Mt. 20:8; Jas. 5:4; reward, Mt. 5:12, 46; 6:1, 2, 5, 16; punishment, 2 Pet. 2:13

μισθοω.definition: to hire out, let out to hire; mid. to hire, Mt. 20:1, 7*

μισθωμα.definition: hire, rent; in NT a hired dwelling, Acts 28:30*

μιτυληνη.definition: Mitylene, the capital city of Lesbos, in the Aegean sea, Acts 20:14*

μιχαηλ.definition: Michael, the archangel, indecl., Jude 9; Rev. 12:7*

μνα.definition: Latin mina; a weight, equivalent to 100 drachmas; also a sum, equivalent to 100 drachmas and the sixtieth part of a talent, Lk. 19:13, 16, 18, 20, 24f.*

μνεια.definition: remembrance, recollection, Phil. 1:3; 1 Thess. 3:6; 2 Tim. 1:3; mention; μνείαν ποιεῖσθαι, to make mention, Rom. 1:9; Eph. 1:16; 1 Thess. 1:2; Phlm. 4*

μνημα.definition: pr. a memorial, monument; a tomb, sepulchre, Mk. 5:3, 5; Lk. 8:27; 23:53; 24:1; Acts 2:29; 7:16; Rev. 11:9*

μνημειον.definition: monument, memorial, Lk. 11:47; grave, tomb, Mt. 23:39; Mk. 5:2; Lk. 11:44; Jn. 11:17, 31, 38; Acts 13:29

μνημη.definition: remembrance, recollection, memory; μνήμην ποιεῖσθαι, to make mention, 2 Pet. 1:15*

μνημονευω.definition: to remember, recollect, call to mind, Mt. 16:9; Lk. 17:32; Acts 20:31; to be mindful of, to fix the thoughts upon, Heb. 11:15; to make mention, mention, speak of, Heb. 11:22

μνημοσυνον.definition: a record, memorial, Acts 10:4; honorable remembrance, Mt. 26:13; Mk. 14:9*

μνηστευω.definition: to ask in marriage; to betroth; pass. to be betrothed, engaged, Mt. 1:18; Lk. 1:27; 2:5*

μογιλαλος.definition: having an impediment in one’s speech, speaking with difficulty, a stammerer, Mk. 7:32*

μοδιος.definition: a modius, a Roman measure for things dry, containing 16 sextarii, and equivalent to about a peck (8.75 liters); in NT a corn measure, Mt. 5:15; Mk. 4:21; Lk. 11:33*

μοιχαλις.definition: an adulteress, Rom. 7:3; Jas. 4:4; by meton., an adulterous appearance, lustful significance, 2 Pet. 2:14; from the Hebrew, spiritually adulterous, faithless, ungodly, Mt. 12:39; 16:4; Mk. 8:38*

μοιχαω.definition: act., to cause to commit adultery, pass., to commit or be guilty of adultery, Mt. 5:32; 19:9; Mk. 10:11f.*

μοιχευω.definition: trans. to commit adultery with, debauch, Mt. 5:28; absol. and mid. to commit adultery, Mt. 5:27; Jn. 8:4; to commit spiritual adultery, be guilty of idolatry, Rev. 2:22

μολις.definition: with difficulty, scarcely, hardly, Acts 14:18; 27:7, 8, 16; Rom. 5:7; 1 Pet. 4:18*

μολυνω.definition: pr. to stain, sully; to defile, contaminate morally, 1 Cor. 8:7; Rev. 14:4; to soil, Rev. 3:4*

μομφη.definition: a complaint, cause or ground of complaint, Col. 3:13*

μονη.definition: a stay in any place; an abode, dwelling, mansion, Jn. 14:2, 23*

μονογενης.definition: only-begotten, only-born, Lk. 7:12; 8:42; 9:38; Heb. 11:17; only-begotten in respect of peculiar generation, unique, Jn. 1:14, 18; 3:16, 18; 1 Jn. 4:9*

μονον.definition: the accusative singular form of monos (G3668) used as an adverb meaning only, alone

μονος.definition: without accompaniment, alone, Mt. 14:23; 18:15; Lk. 10:40; singly existent, sole, only, Jn. 17:3; lone solitary, Jn. 8:29; 16:32; alone in respect of restriction, only, Mt. 4:4; 12:4; alone in respect of circumstances, only, Lk. 24:18; not multiplied by reproduction, lone, barren, Jn. 12:24

μονοφθαλμος.definition: one-eyed; deprived of an eye, Mt. 18:9; Mk. 9:47*

μονοω.definition: to leave alone; pass. to be left alone, be lone, 1 Tim. 5:5*

μορφοω.definition: to give shape to, mold, fashion, Gal. 4:19*

μορφωσις.definition: pr. a shaping, moulding; in NT external form, appearance, 2 Tim. 3:5; a settled form. prescribed system, Rom. 2:20*

μοσχοποιεω.definition: to form an image of a calf, Acts 7:41*

μοσχος.definition: pr. a tender branch, shoot; a young animal; a calf, young bull, Lk. 15:23, 27, 30; Heb. 12:19; Rev. 4:7*

μουσικος.definition: pr. devoted to the arts of the Muses; a musician; in NT, perhaps, a singer, Rev. 18:22*

μοχθος.definition: wearisome labor, toil, travail, 2 Cor. 11:27; 1 Thess. 2:9; 2 Thess. 3:8*

μυεω.definition: to initiate, instruct in the sacred mysteries; in NT pass. to be disciplined in a practical lesson, to learn a lesson, Phil. 4:12*

μυθος.definition: a word, speech, a tale; a fable, figment, 1 Tim. 1:4; 4:7; 2 Tim. 4:4; Tit. 1:14; 2 Pet. 1:16*

μυκαομαι.definition: to low, bellow, as a bull; also, to roar, as a lion, Rev. 10:3*

μυκτηριζω.definition: to contract the nose in contempt and derision, toss up the nose; to mock, deride, Gal. 6:7*

μυλικος.definition: of a mill, belonging to a mill, Lk. 17:2*

μυρα.definition: neuter plural, Myra, a city of Lycia, Acts 27:5*

μυριας.definition: a myriad, ten thousand, Acts 19:19; indefinitely, a vast multitude, Lk. 12:1; Acts 21:20; Heb. 12:22; Jude 14; Rev. 5:11; 9:16*

μυριοι.definition: indefinitely, a great number; specifically, μύριοι, a myriad, ten thousand, Mt. 18:24*

μυρον.definition: pr. aromatic juice which distills from trees; ointment, unguent, usually perfumed, Mt. 26:7, 12; Mk. 14:3, 4

μυσια.definition: Mysia, a province of Asia Minor, Acts 16:7f.*

μυστηριον.definition: a matter to the knowledge of which initiation is necessary; a secret which would remain such but for revelation, Mt. 3:11; Rom. 11:25; Col. 1:26; a concealed power or principle, 2 Thess. 2:7; a hidden meaning of a symbol, Rev. 1:20; 17:7

μυωπαζω.definition: pr. to close the eyes, contract the eyelids, wink; to be nearsighted, partially blinded, slow to understand, 2 Pet. 1:9*

μωλωψ.definition: the mark of a blow; a stripe, a wound, 1 Pet. 2:24*

μωμαομαι.definition: to find fault with, censure, blame, 2 Cor. 8:20; passively, 2 Cor. 6:3*

μωμος.definition: blame, ridicule; a disgrace to society, a stain, 2 Pet. 2:13*

μωραινω.definition: to be foolish, to play the fool; in NT trans. to make foolish, convict of folly, 1 Cor. 1:20; pass. to be convicted of folly, to incur the character of folly, Rom. 1:22; to be rendered insipid, Mt. 5:13; Lk. 14:34*

μωρος.definition: pr. dull; foolish, Mt. 7:26; 23:17; 25:2f., 8; 1 Cor. 1:25, 27; 3:18; 4:10; 2 Tim. 2:23; Tit. 3:9; from the Hebrew, a fool in senseless wickedness, Mt. 5:22*

μωυσης.definition: also spelled Μωσῆς, Moses, pr. name, Mt. 8:4; Jn. 1:17; Rom. 5:14

ναασσων.definition: Naasson, pr. name, indecl., Mt. 1:4; Lk. 3:32*

ναγγαι.definition: Naggai, Nagge, pr. name, indecl., Lk. 3:25*

ναζαρα.definition: see Ναζαρέθ, Mt. 4:13; Lk. 4:16*. See PhotoGuide.

ναζαρεθ.definition: an indecl. form, Nazareth, is spelled Ναζαρέτ (4x) and Ναζαρά (2x). See PhotoGuide.

ναζαρετ.definition: see Ναζαρέθ, Mt. 2:23; Mk. 1:9; Jn. 1:45, 46*. See PhotoGuide.

ναζαρηνος.definition: an inhabitant of Nazareth, Mk. 1:24; 10:47; 4:67; 16:6; Lk. 4:34; 24:19*

ναζωραιος.definition: also spelled Ναζαρηνός, a Nazarite; an inhabitant of Nazareth, Mt. 2:23; 26:71; Lk. 18:37; Jn. 18:5, 7; 19:19; Acts 2:22; 3:6; 4:10; 6:14; 22:8; 24:5; 26:9*

ναθαμ.definition: also spelled Ναθάν, Nathan, pr. name, indecl., Lk. 3:31*

ναι.definition: a particle, used to strengthen an affirmation, certainly, Rev. 22:20; to make an affirmation, or express an assent, yea, yes, Mt. 5:37; Acts 5:8

ναιμαν.definition: also spelled Νεεμάν, Naaman, pr. name, indecl., Lk. 4:27*

ναιν.definition: Nain, a town of Palestine, indecl., Lk. 7:11*. See PhotoGuide.

ναος.definition: pr. a dwelling; the dwelling of a deity, a temple, Mt. 26:61; Acts 7:48; used figuratively of individuals, Jn. 2:19; 1 Cor. 3:16; spc. the cell of a temple; hence, the Holy Place of the Temple of Jerusalem, Mt. 23:35; Lk. 1:9; a model of a temple, a shrine, Acts 19:24

ναρδος.definition: spikenard, a species of aromatic plant with grassy leaves and a fibrous root, of which the best and strongest grows in India; in NT oil of spikenard, an oil extracted from the plant, which was highly prized and used as an ointment either pure or mixed with other substances, Mk. 14:3; Jn. 12:3*

ναυαγεω.definition: to make shipwreck, be shipwrecked, 2 Cor. 11:25; 1 Tim. 1:19*

ναυκληρος.definition: the master or owner of a ship, Acts 27:11*

νεανιας.definition: a young man, youth, Acts 20:9; 23:17; used of one who is in the prime of life, Acts 7:58*

νεανισκος.definition: a young man, youth, Mk. 14:51; 16:5; used of one in the prime of life, Mt. 19:20, 22; νεανίσκοι, soldiers, Mk. 14:51

νεα.definition: Neapolis, a city of Thrace on the Strymonic gulf, Acts 16:11*. See PhotoGuide.

νεκρος.definition: dead, without life, Mt. 11:5; 22:31; met. νεκρός τινι, dead to a thing, no longer devoted to, or under the influence of a thing, Rom. 6:11; dead in respect of fruitlessness, Jas. 2:17, 20, 26; morally or spiritually dead, Rom. 6:13; Eph. 5:14; dead in alienation from God, Eph. 2:1, 5; Col. 2:13; subject to death, mortal, Rom. 8:10; causing death and misery, fatal, having a destructive power, Heb. 6:1; 9:14

νεκροω.definition: pr. to put to death, kill; in NT met. to deaden, mortify, Col. 3:5; pass. to be rendered impotent, Rom. 4:19; Heb. 11:12*

νεκρωσις.definition: pr. a putting to death; dying, abandonment to death, 2 Cor. 4:10; deadness, impotency, Rom. 4:19*

νεομηνια.definition: new moon, first of the month, Col. 2:16*

νεος.definition: recent, new, fresh, Mt. 9:17; 1 Cor. 5:7; Col. 3:10; Heb. 12:24; young, youthful, Tit. 2:4. In Acts 16:11 is used in the name Νέαν πόλις, which some lexicons list as its own lexical form. This occurrence is not included in the word’s frequency count.

νεοφυτος.definition: newly or recently planted met. a neophyte, one newly implanted into the Christian Church, a new convert, 1 Tim. 3:6*

νευω.definition: to nod; to intimate by a nod or significant gesture, Jn. 13:24; Acts 24:10*

νεφθαλιμ.definition: Nephthalim, pr. name, indecl., Mt. 4:13, 15; Rev. 5:6*

νεφος.definition: a cloud; trop. a cloud, a throng of persons, Heb. 12:1*

νεφρος.definition: a kidney; pl. νεφροί, the kidneys, reins; from the Hebrew the reins regarded as a seat of desire and affection, Rev. 2:23*

νεωκορος.definition: pr. one who sweeps or cleanses a temple; generally, one who has the charge of a temple; in NT a devotee city, as having specially dedicated a temple to some deity, Acts 19:35*

νεωτερικος.definition: juvenile, natural to youth, youthful, 2 Tim. 2:22*

νη.definition: by, BDAG 690, calls it a “particle of strong affirmation,” and is followed by the person or thing (in the acc) by which the person swears, 1 Cor. 15:31*

νηπιος.definition: pr. not speaking, Latin infans; an infant, babe, child, Mt. 21:16; 1 Cor. 13:11; one below the age of manhood, a minor, Gal. 4:1; met. a babe in knowledge, unlearned, simple, Mt. 11:25; Rom. 2:20

νηστεια.definition: fasting, want of food, 2 Cor. 6:5; 11:27; a fast, religious abstinence from food, Mt. 17:21; Lk. 2:37; spc. the annual public fast of the Jews, the great day of atonement, occurring in the month Tisri, corresponding to the new moon of October, Acts 27:9*

νηστις.definition: can also be masc. with a gen. in ιδος (n-3c[2]), fasting, hungry, Mt. 15:32; Mk. 8:3*

νηφαλιος.definition: somber, temperate, abstinent in respect to wine, etc.; in NT met., vigilant, circumspect, self-controlled, 1 Tim. 3:2, 11; Tit. 2:2*

νηφω.definition: to be sober, not intoxicated; in NT met., to be vigilant, circumspect, 1 Thess. 5:6, 8

νιγερ.definition: Niger, pr. name, probably not declined, Acts 13:1*

νικαω.definition: to conquer, overcome, vanquish, subdue, Lk. 1:22; Jn. 16:33; absol. to overcome, prevail, Rev. 5:5; to come off superior in a judicial cause, Rom. 3:4

νικη.definition: victory; meton. a victorious principle, 1 Jn. 5:4*

νικολαιτης.definition: a Nicolaitan, or follower of Nicolaus, a heresy of the Apostolic age, Rev. 2:6, 15*

νικοπολις.definition: Nicopolis, a city of Macedonia, Tit. 3:12*. See PhotoGuide.

νινευιτης.definition: a Ninevite, an inhabitant of Nineveh, Mt. 12:41; Lk. 11:30, 32*

νιπτηρ.definition: a basin for washing some part of the person, Jn. 13:5*

νιπτω.definition: to wash; spc. to wash some part of the person, as distinguished from λούω, Mt. 6:17; Jn. 13:8

νοεω.definition: to perceive, observe; to mark attentively, Mt. 24:15; Mk. 13:14; 2 Tim. 2:7; to understand, comprehend, Mt. 15:17; to conceive, Eph. 3:20

νοημα.definition: the mind, the understanding, intellect, 2 Cor. 3:14; 4:4; Phil. 4:7; the heart, soul, affections, feelings, disposition, 2 Cor. 11:3; a conception of the mind, thought, purpose, device, 2 Cor. 2:11; 10:5*

νομη.definition: pasture, pasturage, Jn. 10:9; ἔχειν νομήν, to eat its way, spread corrosion, 2 Tim. 2:17*

νομιζω.definition: to own as settled and established; to deem, 1 Cor. 7:26; 1 Tim. 6:5; to suppose, presume, Mt. 5:17; 20:10; Lk. 2:44; to be usual, customary, Acts 16:13

νομικος.definition: pertaining to law; relating to the Mosaic law, Tit. 3:9; as a subst., one skilled in law, a jurist, lawyer, Tit. 3:13; spc. an interpreter and teacher of the Mosaic law, Mt. 22:35

νομιμως.definition: lawfully, agreeably to law or custom, rightfully, 1 Tim. 1:8; 2 Tim. 2:5*

νομισμα.definition: pr. a thing sanctioned by law or custom; lawful money, coin, Mt. 22:19*

νομοδιδασκαλος.definition: a teacher and interpreter of the Mosaic law, Lk. 5:17; Acts 5:34; 1 Tim. 1:7

νομοθεσια.definition: legislation; ἡ νομοθεσία, the gift of the Divine law, or the Mosaic law itself, Rom. 9:4*

νομοθετεω.definition: to impose a law, give laws; in NT pass., to have a law imposed on one’s self, receive a law, Heb. 7:11; to be enacted, constituted, Heb. 8:6*

νομος.definition: a law, Rom. 4:15; 1 Tim. 1:9; the Mosaic law, Mt. 5:17, et al. freq.; the Old Testament Scripture, Jn. 10:34; a legal tie, Rom. 7:2, 3; a law, a rule, standard, Rom. 3:27; a rule of life and conduct, Gal. 6:2, Jas. 1:25

νοσεω.definition: to be sick; met. to have a diseased appetite or craving for a thing, have an excessive and vicious fondness for a thing, 1 Tim. 6:4*

νοσσια.definition: a brood of young birds, Lk. 13:34*

νοσσιον.definition: the young of birds, a chick; pl. a brood of young birds, Mt. 23:37*

νοσσος.definition: also spelled νεοσσός, the young of birds, a young bird, chick, Lk. 2:24*

νοσφιζω.definition: to deprive, rob; mid. to misappropriate; to make secret reservation, Acts 5:2, 3; to purloin, Tit. 2:10*

νοτος.definition: the south wind, Lk. 12:55; Acts 27:13; 28:13; meton. the south, the southern quarter of the heavens, Mt. 12:42; Lk. 11:31; 13:29; Rev. 21:13*

νουθετεω.definition: pr. to put in mind; to admonish, warn, Acts 20:31; Rom. 15:14

νους.definition: the mind, intellect, 1 Cor. 14:15, 19; understanding, intelligent faculty, Lk. 24:45; intellect, judgment, Rom. 7:23, 25; opinion, sentiment, Rom. 14:5; 1 Cor. 1:10; mind, thought, conception, Rom. 11:34; 1 Cor. 2:16; Phil. 4:7; settled state of mind, 2 Thess. 2:2; frame of mind, Rom. 1:28; 12:2; Col. 2:18; Eph. 4:23; 1 Tim. 6:5; 2 Tim. 3:8; Tit. 1:15

νυμφη.definition: a bride, Jn. 3:29; Rev. 18:23; 21:2, 9; 22:17; opposed to πενθερά, a daughter-in-law, Mt. 10:35; Lk. 12:53*

νυμφων.definition: a bridal-chamber; in NT υἱοὶ τοῦ νυμφῶνος, sons of the bridal-chamber, the bridegroom’s attendant friends, groomsmen, Mt. 9:15; Mk. 2:19; Lk. 5:34*

νυν.definition: now, at the present time, Mk. 10:30; Lk. 6:21, et al. freq.; just now, Jn. 11:8; forthwith, Jn. 12:31; καὶ νῦν, even now, as matters stand, Jn. 11:22; now, expressive of a marked tone of address, Acts 7:34; 13:11; Jas. 4:13; 5:1; τὸ νῦν, the present time, Lk. 1:48; τανῦν, or τὰ νῦν, now, Acts 4:29

νυνι.definition: of time, now, at this very moment, an emphatic form of νῦν although it now carries the same meaning

νυξ.definition: night, Mt. 2:14; 28:13; Jn. 3:2; met. spiritual night, moral darkness, Rom. 13:12; 1 Thess. 5:5

νυσταζω.definition: to nod; to nod in sleep; to sink into a sleep, Mt. 25:5; to slumber in inactivity, 2 Pet. 2:3*

νυχθημερον.definition: a day and night, twenty-four hours, 2 Cor. 11:25*

νωε.definition: Noah, pr. name, indecl., Mt. 24:37ff; Lk. 3:36; 17:26f.; Heb. 11:7; 1 Pet. 3:20; 2 Pet. 2:25*

νωτος.definition: the back of men or animals, Rom. 11:10*

χενια.definition: pr. state of being a guest; then, the reception of a guest or stranger, hospitality, in NT a lodging, Acts 28:23; Phlm. 22*

χενιζω.definition: to receive as a guest, entertain, Acts 10:23; 28:7; Heb. 13:2; pass. to be entertained as a guest, to lodge or reside with, Acts 10:6, 18, 32; 21:16; to strike with a feeling of strangeness, to surprise; pass. or mid. to be struck with surprise, be staggered, be amazed, 1 Pet. 4:4, 12; intrans. to be strange; χενίζοντα, strange matters, novelties, Acts 17:20*

χενοδοχεω.definition: to receive and entertain strangers, exercise hospitality, 1 Tim. 5:10*

χενος.definition: strange, foreign, alien, Eph. 2:12, 19; strange, unexpected, surprising, 1 Pet. 4:12; novel, Heb. 13:9; subst. a stranger, Mt. 25:35, et al.; a host, Rom. 16:23

χεστης.definition: a sextarius, a Roman measure, containing about one pint English; in NT used for a small vessel, cup, pot, Mk. 7:4*

χηραινω.definition: to dry up, parch, Jas. 1:11; pass. to be parched, Mt. 13:6, et al.; to be ripened as corn, Rev. 14:15; to be withered, to wither, Mk. 11:20; of parts of the body, to be withered, Mk. 3:1, 3; to pine, Mk. 9:18

χηρος.definition: dry, withered, Lk. 23:31; ἡ χηρά, i.e. γῆ, the dry land, land, Mt. 23:15; Heb. 11:29; of parts of the body, withered, Mt. 12:10

χυλινος.definition: wooden, of wood, made of wood, 2 Tim. 2:20; Rev. 9:20*

χυλον.definition: wood, timber, 1 Cor. 3:12; Rev. 18:12; stocks, Acts 16:24; a club, Mt. 26:47, 55; a post, cross, gibbet, Acts 5:30; 10:29; 13:29; a tree, Lk. 23:31; Rev. 2:7

χυραω.definition: to cut off the hair, shear, shave, Acts 21:24; 1 Cor. 11:5, 6*

g5120.definition: the prepositive article, answering, to a considerable extent, to the English definite article; but, for the principle and facts of its usage, consult a grammar; ὁ μὲν ... ὁ δέ, the one ... the other, Phil. 1:16, 17; Heb. 7:5, 6, 20, 21, 23, 24; pl. some ... others, Mt. 13:23; 22:5, 6; ὁ δέ, but he, Mt. 4:4; 12:48; οἱ δέ, but others, Mt. 28:17; used, in a poetic quotation, for a personal pronoun, Acts 17:28

ογδοος.definition: the eighth, Lk. 1:59; Acts 7:8; 2 Pet. 2:5; Rev. 17:11; 21:20*

ογκος.definition: pr. bulk, weight; a burden, impediment, Heb. 12:1*

οδε.definition: this, that, he, she, it, Lk. 10:39; 16:25; Acts 15:23

οδηγεω.definition: to lead, guide, Mt. 15:14; Lk. 6:39; Rev. 7:17; met. to instruct, teach, Jn. 16:13; Acts 8:31*

οδηγος.definition: a guide, leader, Acts 1:16; met. an instructor, teacher, Mt. 15:14; 23:16, 24; Rom. 2:19*

οδοιπορια.definition: to journey, journeying, travel, Jn. 4:6; 2 Cor. 11:26*

οδος.definition: a way, road, Mt. 2:12; 7:13, 14; 8:28; 22:9, 10; means of access, approach, entrance, Jn. 14:6; Heb. 9:8; direction, quarter, region, Mt. 4:15; 10:5 the act of journeying, a journey, way, course, Mt. 10:10; Mk. 2:23; 1 Thess. 3:11; a journey, as regards extent, Acts 1:12; met. a way, systematic course of pursuit, Lk. 1:79; Acts 2:28; 16:17; a way, systematic course of action or conduct, Mt. 21:32; Rom. 11:33; 1 Cor. 4:17; a way, system of doctrine, Acts 18:26; ἡ ὁδός, the way of the Christian faith, Acts 19:9, 23, 24:22

οδυναω.definition: to pain either bodily or mentally; pass. to be in an agony, be tormented, Lk. 2:48; 16:24, 25; to be distressed, grieved, Acts 20:38*

οδυνη.definition: pain of body of mind; sorrow, grief, Rom. 9:2; 1 Tim. 6:10*

οδυρμος.definition: bitter lamentation, wailing, Mt. 2:18; meton. sorrow, mourning, 2 Cor. 7:7*

οζω.definition: to smell, emit an odor; to have an offensive smell, stink, Jn. 11:39*

οθεν.definition: whence, Mt. 12:44; Acts 14:26; from the place where, Mt. 25:24, 26; whence, from which circumstance, 1 Jn. 2:18; wherefore, whereupon, Mt. 14:7

οθονη.definition: pr. fine linen; a linen cloth; a sheet, Acts 10:11; 11:5*

οθονιον.definition: a linen cloth; in NT a swath, bandage for a corpse, Lk. 24:12

οιδα.definition: to know, Mt. 6:8; to know how, Mt. 7:11; from the Hebrew, to regard with favor, 1 Thess. 5:12. οἶδα is actually a perfect form functioning as a present, and ᾔδειν is actually a pluperfect form functioning as an aorist.

οικειος.definition: belonging to a house, domestic; pl. members of a family, immediate kin, 1 Tim. 5:8; members of a spiritual family, Eph. 2:19; members of a spiritual brotherhood, Gal. 6:10*

οικετεια.definition: the members, of a household, Mt. 24:45*

οικετης.definition: pr. an inmate of a house; a domestic servant, household slave, Lk. 16:13; Acts 10:7; Rom. 14:4; 1 Pet. 2:18*

οικεω.definition: to dwell in, inhabit, 1 Tim. 6:16; intrans. to dwell, live; to cohabit, 1 Cor. 7:12, 13; to be indwelling, indwell, Rom. 7:17, 18, 20; 8:9, 11; 1 Cor. 3:16*

οικημα.definition: a dwelling; used in various conventional senses, and among them, a prison, cell, Acts 12:7*

οικητηριον.definition: a habitation, dwelling, an abode, Jude 6; trop. the personal abode of the soul, 2 Cor. 5:2*

οικια.definition: a house, dwelling, an abode, Mt. 2:11; 7:24, 27; trop. the bodily abode of the soul, 2 Cor. 5:1; meton. a household, family, Mt. 10:13; 12:25; meton. goods, property, means, Mt. 23:13

οικιακος.definition: belonging to a house; pl. the members of a household or family, kindred, Mt. 10:25, 36*

οικοδεσποτεω.definition: pr. to be master of a household; to occupy one’s self in the management of a household, 1 Tim. 5:14*

οικοδεσποτης.definition: the master or head of a house or family, Mt. 10:25; 13:27, 52

οικοδομεω.definition: pluperfect, ὧκοδόμητο (3 sg), to build a house; to build, Mt. 7:24; to repair, embellish, and amplify a building, Mt. 23:29; to construct, establish, Mt. 16:18; met. to contribute to advancement in religious knowledge, to edify, 1 Cor. 14:4, 17; to advance a person’s spiritual condition, to edify, 1 Cor. 8:1; pass. to make spiritual advancement, be edified, Acts 9:31; to advance in presumption, 1 Cor. 8:10

οικοδομη.definition: pr. the act of building; a building, structure, Mt. 24:1; in NT a spiritual structure, as instanced in the Christian body, 1 Cor. 3:9; Eph. 2:21; religious advancement, edification, Rom. 14:19; 1 Cor. 14:3

οικονομεω.definition: to manage a household; to manage the affairs of any one, be steward, Lk. 16:2*

οικονομια.definition: pr. the management of a household; a stewardship, Lk. 16:2, 3, 4; in NT an apostolic stewardship, a ministerial commission in the publication and furtherance of the Gospel, 1 Cor. 9:17; 3:2; Col. 1:25; or, an arranged plan, a scheme, Eph. 1:10; a due discharge of a commission, 1 Tim. 1:4, Eph. 3:9*

οικονομος.definition: the manager of a household; a steward, Lk. 12:42; 16:1, 3, 8; 1 Cor. 4:2; a manager, trustee, Gal. 4:2; a public steward, treasurer, Rom. 16:23; a spiritual steward, the holder of a commission in the service of the Gospel, 1 Cor. 4:1; Tit. 1:7; 1 Pet. 4:10*

οικος.definition: a house, dwelling, Mt. 9:6, 7; Mk. 2:1, 11; 3:20; place of abode, seat, site, Mt. 23:38; Lk. 13:35; met. a spiritual house or structure, 1 Pet. 2:5; meton. a household, family, Lk. 10:5; 11:17; a spiritual household, 1 Tim. 3:15; Heb. 3:6; family, lineage, Lk. 1:27, 69; 2:4; from the Hebrew, a people, nation, Mt. 10:6; 15:24

οικουμενη.definition: some list as a participle, the habitable earth, world, Matt. 24:14; Rom. 10:18; Heb. 1:6; used, however, with various restrictions of meaning, according to the context, Lk. 2:1; Acts 17:6; meton. the inhabitants of the earth, the whole human race, mankind, Acts 17:31; 19:27; Rev. 3:10. Some view this word as a participial form of οἰκέω.

οικουργος.definition: one who is occupied in domestic affairs, Tit. 2:5*

οικτιρμος.definition: compassion; kindness, in relieving sorrow and want, Phil. 2:1; Col. 3:12; Heb. 10:28; favor, grace, mercy, Rom. 12:1; 2 Cor. 1:3*

οικτιρω.definition: also spelled οἰκτείρω, to have compassion on, exercise grace or favor towards, Rom. 9:15*

οινοποτης.definition: wine-drinking; in a bad sense, a wine-bibber, tippler, Mt. 11:19; Lk. 7:34*

οινος.definition: wine, Mt. 9:17; Mk. 2:22; meton. the vine and its clusters, Rev. 6:6 met. οἶνος, a potion, οἶνος τοῦ θυμοῦ, a furious potion, Rev. 14:8, 10; 16:19; 17:2, 18:3

οιομαι.definition: to think, suppose, imagine, presume, Jn. 21:25; Phil. 1:17. οἰέσθω in Jas. 1:7 formed from the contracted form οἶμαι*

οιος.definition: what, of what kind or sort, as, Mt. 24:21; Mk. 9:3; οὐχ οἶον, not so as, not as implying, Rom. 9:6

οκνεω.definition: to be slow; to delay, hesitate, Acts 9:38*

οκνηρος.definition: slow; slothful, indolent, idle, Mt. 25:26; Rom. 12:11; tedious, troublesome, Phil. 3:1*

ολεθρος.definition: perdition, destruction, 1 Cor. 5:5, 1 Thess. 5:3; 2 Thess. 1:9; 1 Tim. 6:9*

ολιγοπιστια.definition: littleness or imperfectness of faith, Mt. 17:20*

ολιγοπιστος.definition: scant of faith, of little faith, one whose faith is small and weak, Mt. 6:30; 8:26; 14:31; 16:18; Lk. 12:28*

ολιγος.definition: little, small, in number, etc.; pl. few, Mt. 7:14; 9:37; 20:16; Lk. 13:23; δι’ ὀλίγων, i.e. λόγων, in a few words, briefly, 1 Pet. 5:12; little in time, short, brief, Acts 14:28; Rev. 12:12; πρὸς ὀλίγον, i.e. χρόνον, for a short time, for a little while, Jas. 4:14; little, small, light, etc., in magnitude, amount, etc., Lk. 7:47; Acts 12:18; 15:2; ἐν ὀλίγῳ, concisely, briefly, Eph. 3:3; almost, Acts 26:28, 29

ολιγωρεω.definition: to neglect, regard slightly, make light of, despise, Heb. 12:5*

ολοθρευω.definition: also spelled ὀλεθρεύω, to destroy, cause to perish, Heb. 11:28*

ολοκαυτωμα.definition: a holocaust, whole burnt-offering, Mk. 12:33; Heb. 10:6, 8*

ολοκληρος.definition: whole, having all its parts, sound, perfect, complete in every part; in NT the whole, 1 Thess. 5:23; morally, perfect, faultless, blameless, Jas. 1:4*

ολολυζω.definition: pr. to cry aloud in invocation; to howl, utter cries of distress, lament, bewail, Jas. 5:1*

ολυνθος.definition: an unripe or unseasonable fig, such as, shaded by the foliage, does not ripen at the usual season, but hangs on the trees during winter, Rev. 6:13*

ολως.definition: wholly, altogether; actually, really, 1 Cor. 5:1; 6:7; 15:29; with a negative, at all, Mt. 5:34*

ομβρος.definition: rain, a storm of rain, Lk. 12:54*

ομειρομαι.definition: also spelled ἱμείρομαι, to desire earnestly, have a strong affection for, 1 Thess. 2:8*

ομιλεω.definition: to be in company with, associate with; to converse with, talk with, Lk. 24:14, 15; Acts 20:11; 24:26*

ομιχλη.definition: a mist, fog, a cloud, 2 Pet. 2:17*

ομνυω.definition: to swear, Mt. 5:34; to promise with an oath, Mk. 6:23; Acts 2:30; 7:17

ομοθυμαδον.definition: with one mind, with one accord, unanimously, Acts 1:14; Rom. 15:6; together, at once, at the same time, Acts 2:1, 46; 4:24

ομοιοπαθης.definition: being affected in the same way as another, subject to the same incidents, of like infirmities, subject to the same frailties and evils, Acts 14:15; Jas. 5:17*

ομοιος.definition: like, similar, resembling, Mt. 11:16; 13:31, 33, 44, 45, 47, 52; Jn. 8:55, et al. freq.; like, of similar drift and force, Mt. 22:39

ομοιοω.definition: to make like, cause to be like or resemble, assimilate; pass. to be made like, become like, resemble, Mt. 6:8; 13:24; 18:23; to liken, compare, Mt. 7:24, 26; 11:16

ομοιωμα.definition: pr. that which is conformed or assimilated; form, shape, figure, Rev. 9:7; likeness, resemblance, similitude, Rom. 1:23; 5:14; 6:5; 8:3; Phil. 2:7*

ομοιως.definition: likewise, in a similar manner, Mt. 22:26; 27:41

ομολογεω.definition: to speak in accordance, adopt the same terms of language; to engage, promise, Mt. 14:7; to admit, avow frankly, Jn. 1:20; Acts 24:14; to confess, 1 Jn. 1:9; to profess, confess, Jn. 9:22; 12:42; Acts 23:8; to avouch, declare openly and solemnly, Mt. 7:23; in NT ὁμολογεῖν ἐν, to accord belief, Mt. 10:32; Lk. 12:8; to accord approbation, Lk. 12:8; from the Hebrew, to accord praise, Heb. 13:15

ομολογια.definition: assent, consent; profession, 2 Cor. 9:13; 1 Tim. 6:12, 13; Heb. 3:1; 4:14; 10:23*

ομοτεχνος.definition: to the same trade or occupation, Acts 18:3*

ομου.definition: together; in the same place, Jn. 21:2; together at the same time, Jn. 4:36; 20:4; Acts 2:1*

ομοφρων.definition: of like mind, of the same mind, like-minded, 1 Pet. 3:8*

ομως.definition: yet, nevertheless; with μέντοι, but nevertheless, but for all that, Jn. 12:42; even, though it be but, 1 Cor. 14:7; Gal. 3:15*

οναριον.definition: a young donkey, a donkey’s colt, Jn. 12:14*

ονειδιζω.definition: to censure, inveigh against, Mt. 11:20; Mk. 16:14; to reproach or revile, Jas. 1:5; to revile, insult with insulting language, Mt. 5:11

ονειδος.definition: pr. fame, report, character; usually, reproach, disgrace, Lk. 1:25*

ονικος.definition: pertaining to a donkey; μύλος ὀνικός, a millstone turned by a donkey, a large or an upper millstone, Mt. 18:6; Mk. 9:42*

ονινημι.definition: optative, ὀναίμην, to receive profit, pleasure, etc.; with a gen., to have joy of, Phlm. 20*

ονομα.definition: a name; the proper name of a person, etc., Mt. 1:23, 25; 10:2; 27:32; a mere name or reputation, Rev. 3:1; in NT a name as the representative of a person, Mt. 6:9; Lk. 6:22; 11:2; the name of the author of a commission, delegated authority, or religious profession, Mt. 7:22; 10:22; 12:21; 18:5, 20; 19:29; 21:9; 28:19; Acts 3:16; 4:7, 12; εἰς ὄνομα, ἐν ὀνόματι, on the score of being possessor of a certain character, Mt. 10:41, 42; Mk. 9:41

ονομαζω.definition: to name, Lk. 6:14; to style, entitle, Lk. 6:13; 1 Cor. 5:11; to make mention of, Eph. 5:3; to make known, Rom. 15:20; to pronounce in exorcism, Acts 19:13; in NT to profess, 2 Tim. 2:19

ονος.definition: donkey, ass, male or female, Mt. 21:2, 5, 7

οντως.definition: really, in truth, truly, Mk. 11:32; Lk. 23:47.

οξος.definition: vinegar; a wine of sharp flavor, posca, which was an ordinary beverage, and was often mixed with bitter herbs, etc., and this given to the condemned criminals in order to stupefy them, and lessen their sufferings, Mt. 27:48; Mk. 15:36; Lk. 23:36; Jn. 19:29, 30

οξυς.definition: sharp, keen, Rev. 1:16; 2:12; 14:14, 17, 18; 19:15; swift, nimble, Rom. 3:15*

οπη.definition: a hole; a hole, vent, opening, Jas. 3:11; a hole, cavern, Heb. 11:38*

οπισθεν.definition: can function as an improper prep., from behind, behind, after, at the back of, Mt. 9:20; 15:23

οπισω.definition: can function as an improper prep., behind, after, at one’s back, Mt. 4:10; Lk. 7:38; Rev. 1:10; τὰ ὀπίσω, the things which are behind, Phil. 3:13; ὀπίσω and εἰς τὰ ὀπίσω, back, backwards, Mt. 24:18; Mk. 13:16; Lk. 9:62, when an improper prep., takes the gen.

οπλιζω.definition: to arm, equip; mid. to arm one’s self, equip one’s self, 1 Pet. 4:1*

οπλον.definition: an implement, Rom. 6:13; pl. τὰ ὅπλα, arms, armor, weapons, whether offensive or defensive, Jn. 18:3; Rom. 13:12; 2 Cor. 6:7; 10:4*

οποιος.definition: what, of what sort or manner, 1 Cor. 3:13; Gal. 2:6; 1 Thess. 1:9; Jas. 1:24; after τοιοῦτος, as, Acts 26:29*

οπου.definition: where, in which place, in what place, Mt. 6:19, 20, 21; Rev. 2:13; whither, to what place, Jn. 8:21; 14:4; ὅπου ἄν, or ἐάν, wherever, in whatever place, Mt. 24:28; whithersoever, Mt. 8:19; Jas. 3:4; met. where, in which thing, state, etc., Col. 3:11; whereas, 1 Cor. 3:3; 2 Pet. 2:11

οπτασια.definition: a vision, apparition, Lk. 1:22; 24:23; Acts 26:19; 2 Cor. 12:1*

οπτος.definition: dressed by fire, roasted, broiled, etc., Lk. 24:42*

οπωρα.definition: autumn; the fruit season; meton. fruits, Rev. 18:14*

οπως.definition: can function as a conj., how, in what way or manner, by what means, Mt. 22:5; Lk. 24:20; conj. that, in order that, and ὅπως μή, that not, lest, Mt. 6:2, 4, 5, 16, 18; Acts 9:2, et al. freq.

οραμα.definition: a thing seen, sight, appearance, Acts 7:31; a vision, Mt. 17:9; Acts 9:10, 12

ορασις.definition: seeing, sight; appearance, aspect, a vision, Acts 2:17; Rev. 9:17; 4:3*

οραω.definition: pluperfect, ἑωράκειν, some list εἶδον as the second aorist of ὁράω, to see, behold, Mt. 2:2, et al. freq.; to look, Jn. 19:37; to visit, Jn. 16:22; Heb. 13:23; to mark, observe, Acts 8:23; Jas. 2:24; to be admitted to witness, Lk. 17:22; Jn. 3:36; Col. 2:18; with θεόν, to be admitted into the more immediate presence of God, Mt. 5:8; Heb. 12:14; to attain to a true knowledge of God, 3 Jn. 11; to see to a thing, Mt. 27:4; Acts 18:15; ὅρα, see, take care, Mt. 8:4; Heb. 8:5; pass. to appear, Lk. 1:11; Acts 2:3; to reveal one’s self, Acts 26:16; to present one’s self, Acts 7:26

οργη.definition: pr. mental bent, impulse; anger, indignation, wrath, Eph. 4:31; Col. 3:8; μετ’ ὀργῆς, indignantly, Mk. 3:5; vengeance, punishment, Mt. 3:7; Lk. 3:7; 21:23; Rom. 13:4, 5

οργιζω.definition: some list as deponent, ὀργίζομαι, to provoke to anger, irritate; pass. to be angry, indignant, enraged, Mt. 5:22; 18:34

οργιλος.definition: prone to anger, irascible, passionate, Tit. 1:7*

οργυια.definition: the space measured by the arms outstretched; a fathom, Acts 27:28 (2x)*

ορεγω.definition: to extend, stretch out; mid. to stretch one’s self out, to reach forward to, met. to desire earnestly, long after, 1 Tim. 3:1; Heb. 11:16; by impl. to indulge in, be devoted to, 1 Tim. 6:10*

ορθοποδεω.definition: to walk in a straight course; to be straightforward in moral conduct, Gal. 2:14*

ορθος.definition: erect, upright, Acts 14:10; plain, level, straight, Heb. 12:13*

ορθοτομεω.definition: to cut straight; to set forth truthfully, without perversion or distortion, 2 Tim. 2:15*

ορθριζω.definition: to rise early in the morning; to come with the dawn, Lk. 21:38*

ορθρινος.definition: a later form of ὄρθριος, of or belonging to the morning, morning, Lk. 24:22*

ορθρος.definition: the dawn; the morning, Jn. 8:2; Acts 5:21; ὄρθος βαθύς, the first streak of dawn, the early dawn, Lk. 24:1*

οριζω.definition: to set bounds to, to bound; to restrict, Heb. 4:7; to settle, appoint definitively, Acts 17:26; to fix determinately, Acts 2:23; to decree, destine, Lk. 22:22; to constitute, appoint, Acts 10:42; 17:31; to characterize with precision, to set forth distinctively, Rom. 1:4; absol. to resolve, Acts 11:29*

οριον.definition: a limit, bound, border of a territory or country; pl. τὰ ὅρια, region, territory, district, Mt. 2:16; 4:13; 8:34

ορκιζω.definition: to put to an oath; to obtest, adjure, conjure, Mk. 5:7; Acts 19:13*

ορκος.definition: an oath, Mt. 14:7, 9; 26:72; meton. that which is solemnly promised, a vow, Mt. 5:33

ορκωμοσια.definition: the act of taking an oath; an oath, Heb. 7:20, 21, 28*

ορμαω.definition: pr. trans. to put in motion, incite; intrans. to rush, Mt. 8:32; Mk. 5:13; Lk. 8:33

ορμη.definition: impetus, impulse; assault, violent attempt, Acts 14:5; met. impulse of mind, purpose, will, Jas. 3:4

ορμημα.definition: violent or impetuous motion; violence, Rev. 18:21*

ορνις.definition: bird, fowl; domestic hen, Mt. 23:37; Lk. 13:34*

οροθεσια.definition: pr. the act of fixing boundaries; a bound set, certain bound, fixed limit, Acts 17:26*

ορφανος.definition: bereaved of parents, orphan, Jas. 1:27; bereaved, desolate, Jn. 14:18

ος.definition: who, which, what, that, Mt. 1:16, 23, 25; in NT interrog. ἐφ’ ὅ, wherefore, why, Mt. 26:50; in NT ὅς μὲν ... ὅς δέ, for ὁ μὲν ... ὁ δέ, Mt. 21:35; 2 Cor. 2:16

οσιος.definition: pr. sanctioned by the supreme law of God, and nature; pious, devout, Tit. 1:8; pure, 1 Tim. 2:8; supremely holy, Acts 2:27; 13:35; Heb. 7:26; Rev. 15:4; 16:5; τὰ ὅσια, pledged bounties, mercies, Acts 13:34*

οσιοτης.definition: piety, sacred observance of all duties towards God, holiness, Lk. 1:75; Eph. 4:24*

οσμη.definition: smell, odor; fragrant odor, Jn. 12:3; Eph. 5:2; Phil. 4:18; met. 2 Cor. 2:14, 16*

οσος.definition: as great, as much, Mk. 7:36; Jn. 6:11; Heb. 1:4; 8:6; 10:25; ἐφ’ ὅσον χρόνον, for how long a time, while, as long as, Rom. 7:1; so, ἐφ’ ὅσον, i.e. χρόνον, Mt. 9:15; ὅσον χρόνον, how long, Mk. 2:19; neut. ὅσον repeated, ὅσον ὅσον, used to give intensity to other qualifying words, e.g., μικρόν, the very least, a very little while, Heb. 10:37; ἐφ’ ὅσον, in as much as, Mt. 25:40, 45; καθ’ ὅσον, by how much, so far as, Heb. 3:3; or, in as much as, as, so, Heb. 7:20; 9:27; pl. ὅσα, so far as, as much as, Rev. 1:2; 18:7; how great, how much, how many, what, Mk. 3:8; 5:19, 20; how many, as many as, all who, 2 Cor. 1:20; Phil. 3:15; 1 Tim. 6:1; ὅσος ἄν, or ἐάν, whoever, whatsoever, Mt. 7:12; 18:18

οστεον.definition: contracted form, ὀστοῦν, οῦ, τό, a bone, Mt. 23:27; Lk. 24:39; Jn. 19:36; Heb. 11:22*

g3755.definition: whoever, whatever; whosoever, whatsoever, Mt. 5:39, 41; 13:12; 18:4; its use in place of the simple relative is also required in various cases, which may be learned from the grammars; ἕως ὅτου, i.e. χρόνου, until, Lk. 13:8; while, Mt. 5:25

οσφρησις.definition: smell, the sense of smelling, 1 Cor. 12:17*

οσφυς.definition: the loins, Mt. 3:4; Mk. 1:6. On the accent see BDF, 13.

οταν.definition: when, whenever, Mt. 5:11; 6:2; Mk. 3:11; Rev. 4:9, et al. freq.; in NT in case of, on occasion of, Jn. 9:5; 1 Cor. 15:27; Heb. 1:6

οτε.definition: when, at the time that, at what time, Mt. 7:28; 9:25; Lk. 13:35, et al. freq.

οτι.definition: originally was the neuter of ὅστις, that, Mt. 2:16, 22, 23; 6:5, 16; often used pleonastically in reciting another’s words, Mt. 9:18; Lk. 19:42; Acts 5:23; as a causal particle, for that, for, because, Mt. 2:18; 5:3, 4, 5; 13:13; because, seeing that, since, Lk. 23:40; Acts 1:17

ου.definition: negative adverb, originally the gen. of ὅς, spelled οὐκ if followed by a word beginning with a vowel and a smooth breathing, οὐχ if followed by a vowel and rough breathing, not, no, Mt. 5:37; 12:43; 23:37; for the peculiarities of its usage (especially as distinct from μή) consult a grammar

ουα.definition: expressive of insult and derision, Ah! Ah!, Mk. 15:29*

ουαι.definition: Wo! Alas! Mt. 11:21; 18:7; 23:13, 14, 15, 16; ἡ οὐαί, subst., a woe, calamity, Rev. 9:12; 11:14

ουδε.definition: negative conj., neither, nor, and not, also not, Mt. 5:15; 6:15, 20, 26, 28; when single, not even Mt. 6:29; 8:10

ουδεις.definition: latter form, οὐθείς (G4032), not one, no one, none, nothing, Mt. 5:13; 6:24; 19:17; met. οὐδέν, nothing, of no account, naught, Jn. 8:54; Acts 21:24

ουδεπω.definition: not yet, never yet, never, Jn. 7:39; 19:41; 20:9; Acts 8:16*

ουν.definition: then, now then, Mt. 13:18; Jn. 19:29; then, thereupon, Lk. 15:28; Jn. 6:14; therefore, consequently, Mt. 5:48: Mk. 10:9; it also serves to mark the resumption of discourse after an interruption by a parenthesis, 1 Cor. 8:4. Sometimes it is not translated.

ουρανος.definition: heaven, the heavens, the visible heavens and all their phenomena, Mt. 5:18; 16:1; 24:29, et al. freq.; the air, atmosphere, in which the clouds and tempests gather, the birds fly, etc., Mt. 6:26; 16:2, 3; heaven as the peculiar seat and abode of God, of angels, of glorified spirits, etc., Mt. 5:34, 45, 48; 6:1, 9, 10; 12:50; Jn. 3:13, 31; 6:32, 38, 41, 42, 50, 51, 58; in NT heaven as a term expressive of the Divine Being, His administration, etc., Mt. 19:14; 21:25; Lk. 20:4, 5; Jn. 3:27

ουριας.definition: Urias, Uriah, pr. name (2 Sam. 11; 12:24), Mt. 1:6*

ουτε.definition: neither, nor, Lk. 20:36; οὔτε ... οὔτε, or οὐτὲ ... οὔτε, neither ... nor, Lk. 20:35; Gal. 1:12; in NT also used singly in the sense of οὐδέ, not even, Mk. 5:3; Lk. 12:26; 1 Cor. 3:2

g5023,.definition: this, this person or thing, Mt. 3:3, 9, 17; 8:9; 10:2; 24:34, et al. freq.; used by way of contempt, this fellow, Mt. 13:55; 27:47; αὐτὸ τοῦτο, this very thing, this same thing, 2 Cor. 2:3; 7:11; εἰς αὐτὸ τοῦτο, and elliptically, αὐτὸ τοῦτο, for this same purpose, on this account, Eph. 6:18, 22; 2 Pet. 1:5; καὶ οὗτος, and moreover, Lk. 7:12; 16:1; 20:30; καὶ τοῦτο, and that too, 1 Cor. 6:6, 8; tοῦτο μὲν ... τοῦτο δέ, partly ... partly, Heb. 10:33

ουτως.definition: thus, in this way, Mt. 1:18; 2:5; 5:16; et al. freq.; ὁς μὲν οὕτως, ὁς δὲ οὕτως, one so, and another so, one in one way, and another in another, 1 Cor. 7:7; so, Mt. 7:12; 12:40; 24:27, 37, et al. freq.; thus, under such circumstances, Acts 20:11; in such a condition, viz., one previously mentioned, Acts 27:17; 1 Cor. 7:26, 40; and, perhaps, Jn. 4:6; in an ordinary way, at ease, like Latin sic, perhaps, Jn. 4:6

ουχι.definition: a strengthened form of οὐ, not, Jn. 13:10, 11; when followed by ἀλλά, nay, not so, by no means, Lk. 1:60; 12:51; used also in negative interrogations, Mt. 5:46, 47; 6:25

οφειλετης.definition: a debtor, one who owes, Mt. 18:24; met. one who is in any way bound, or under obligation to perform any duty, Rom. 1:14; 8:12; 15:27; Gal. 5:3; in NT one who fails in duty, a delinquent, offender, Mt. 6:12; a sinner, Lk. 13:4, cf. v. 2*

οφειλη.definition: a debt, Mt. 18:32; met. a duty, due, Rom. 13:7; 1 Cor. 7:3*

οφειλημα.definition: a debt; a due, Rom. 4:4, in NT a delinquency, offence, fault, sin, Mt. 6:12, cf. v. 14*

οφειλω.definition: to owe, be indebted, Mt. 18:28, 30, 34; to incur a bond, to be bound to make discharge, Mt. 23:16, 18; to be bound or obliged by what is due or fitting or consequently necessary, Lk. 17:10; Jn. 13:14; to incur desert, to deserve, Jn. 19:7; to be due or fitting, 1 Cor. 7:3, 36; from the Aramaic, to be delinquent, Lk. 11:4

οφελον.definition: originally a ptcp (aor act ptcp nom sg neut) from ὀφείλω, used in NT as an interj. to introduce a wish that cannot be attained, O that! Would that! 1 Cor. 4:8; 2 Cor. 11:1; Gal. 5:12; Rev. 3:15*

οφθαλμοδουλια.definition: also written ὀφθαλμοδουλεία, eye-service, service rendered only while under inspection, Eph. 6:6; Col. 3:22*

οφθαλμος.definition: an eye, Mt. 5:29, 38; 6:23; 7:3, 4, 5; ὀφθαλμὸς πονηρός, an evil eye, an envious eye, envy, Mt. 20:15; Mk. 7:22; met. the intellectual eye, Mt. 13:15; Mk. 8:18; Jn. 12:40; Acts 26:18

οφις.definition: a serpent, Mt. 7:10; 10:16; an artificial serpent, Jn. 3:14; used of the devil or Satan, Rev. 12:9, 14, 15; 20:2; met. a man of serpentine character, Mt. 23:33

οφρυς.definition: a brow, eye-brow; the brow of a mountain, edge of a precipice, Lk. 4:29*

οχλεω.definition: pr. to mob; to disturb, trouble, Acts 5:16*

οχλοποιεω.definition: to collect a mob, create a tumult, Acts 17:5*

οχλος.definition: a crowd, a confused multitude of people, Mt. 4:25; 5:1; 7:28; spc. the common people, Jn. 7:49; a multitude, great number, Lk. 5:29; 6:17; Acts 1:15; by impl. tumult, uproar, Lk. 22:6; Acts 24:18

οχυρωμα.definition: a stronghold; met. an opposing bulwark of error or vice, 2 Cor. 10:4*

οψε.definition: can function as an improper prep., late; put for the first watch, at evening, Mk. 11:19; 13:35; ὀψὲ σαββάτων, after the close of the Sabbath, Mt. 28:1

οψια.definition: evening, either before or after sundown

οψιμος.definition: late; latter, Jas. 5:7; poetic and later prose for ὄψιος*

οψις.definition: a sight; the face, countenance, Jn. 11:44; Rev. 1:16; external appearance, Jn. 7:24*

οψωνιον.definition: provisions; a stipend or pay of soldiers, Lk. 3:14; 1 Cor. 9:7; wages of any kind, 2 Cor. 11:8; due wages, a stated recompense, Rom. 6:23*

παγις.definition: a snare, trap, Lk. 21:35; met. device, wile, 1 Tim. 3:7; 6:9; 2 Tim. 2:26; met. a trap of ruin, Rom. 11:9*

παγος.definition: a hill, Ἄρειος πάγος, Areopagus, the hill of Mars, at Athens, Acts 17:19, 22. See PhotoGuide.

παθημα.definition: what is suffered; suffering, affliction, Rom. 8:18; 2 Cor. 1:5, 6, 7; Phil. 3:10; emotion, passion, Rom. 7:5; Gal. 5:24

παθητος.definition: passible, capable of suffering, liable to suffer; in NT destined to suffer, Acts 26:23*

παθος.definition: suffering; an affection, passion, especially sexual, Rom. 1:26
