προσκυνεω.definition: to do reverence or homage by kissing the hand; in NT to do reverence or homage by prostration, Mt. 2:2, 8, 11; 20:20; Lk. 4:7; 24:52; to pay divine homage, worship, adore, Mt. 4:10; Jn. 4:20, 21; Heb. 1:6; to bow one’s self in adoration, Heb. 11:21

προσλαλεω.definition: to speak to, converse with, Acts 13:43; 28:20*

προσλαμβανω.definition: to take to one’s self, assume, take as a companion or associate, Acts 17:5; 18:26; to take, as food, Acts 27:33, 36; to receive kindly or hospitably, admit to one’s society and friendship, treat with kindness, Acts 28:2; Rom. 14:1, 3; 15:7; Phlm. 17; to take or draw to one’s self as a preliminary to an address of admonition, Mt. 16:22; Mk. 8:32*

προσμενω.definition: to continue, remain, stay in a place, 1 Tim. 1:3; to remain or continue with any one, Mt. 15:32; Mk. 8:2; Acts 18:18; to adhere to, Acts 11:23; met. to remain constant in, persevere in, Acts 13:43; 1 Tim. 5:5*

προσορμιζω.definition: to bring a ship to its station or to land; mid. to come to the land, Mk. 6:53*

προσοφειλω.definition: to owe besides or in addition, Phlm. 19*

προσοχθιζω.definition: to be vexed or angry at, Heb. 3:10, 17*

προσπηγνυμι.definition: to fix to, affix to, Acts 2:23*

προσπιπτω.definition: to fall or impinge upon or against a thing; to fall down to any one, Mk. 3:11; 7:25; to rush violently upon, beat against, Mt. 7:25

προσποιεω.definition: to add or attach; mid. to attach to one’s self; to claim or arrogate to one’s self; to assume the appearance of, make a show of, pretend, Lk. 24:28*

προσπορευομαι.definition: to go or come to any one, Mk. 10:35*

προσρησσω.definition: also spelled προσρήγνυμι, to break or burst upon, dash against, Lk. 6:48, 49*

προστασσω.definition: pr. to place or station at or against; to enjoin, command, direct, Mt. 1:24; 8:4; Mk. 1:44; to assign, constitute, appoint, Acts 17:26

προστιθημι.definition: to put to or near; to lay with or by the side of, Acts 13:36; to add, adjoin, Mt. 6:27, 33; Lk. 3:20; Acts 2:41; from the Hebrew, denote continuation, or repetition, Lk. 19:11; 20:11, 12; Acts 12:3

προστρεχω.definition: to run to, or up, Mk. 9:15; 10:17; Acts 8:30*

προσφαγιον.definition: what is eaten besides; hence, genr. victuals, food, Jn. 21:5*

προσφατος.definition: pr. recently killed; hence, genr. recent, new, newly or lately made, Heb. 10:20*

προσφερω.definition: to bear or bring to, Mt. 4:24; 25:20; to bring to or before magistrates, Lk. 12:11; 23:14; to bring near to, apply to, Jn. 19:29; to offer, tender, proffer, as money, Acts 8:18; to offer, present, as gifts, oblations, etc., Mt. 2:11; 5:23; Heb. 5:7; to offer in sacrifice, Mk. 1:44; Lk. 5:14; to offer up any one as a sacrifice to God, Heb. 9:25, 28; 11:17; mid. to bear one’s self towards, behave or conduct one’s self towards, to deal with, treat any one, Heb. 12:7

προσφορα.definition: pr. a bringing to; in NT an offering, an act of offering up or sacrificing, Heb. 10:10, 14, 18; trop. Rom. 15:16; an offering, oblation, a thing offered, Eph. 5:2; Heb. 10:5, 8; a sacrifice, victim offered, Acts 21:26; 24:17*

προσφωνεω.definition: to speak to, address, Mt. 11:16; Lk. 7:32; 13:12; to address, harangue, Acts 22:2; to call to one’s self, Lk. 6:13

προσψαυω.definition: to touch upon, touch lightly, with the dative, Lk. 11:46*

προσωπολημψια.definition: respect of persons, partiality, Rom. 2:11; Eph. 6:9; Col. 3:25; Jas. 2:1*

προσωπον.definition: the face, countenance, visage, Mt. 6:16, 17; 17:2, 6; according to late usage, a person, individual, 2 Cor. 1:11; hence, a personal presence, 1 Thess. 2:17; from the Hebrew, πρόσωπον πρὸς πρόσωπον, face to face, clearly, perfectly, 1 Cor. 13:12; face, surface, external form, figure, appearance, Mt. 16:3; Lk. 12:56; external circumstances, or condition of any one, Mt. 22:16; Mk. 12:14; πρόσωπον λαμβάνειν, to have respect to the external circumstances of any one, Lk. 20:21; Gal. 2:6; ἐν προσώπῳ, in presence of, 2 Cor. 2:10; ἀπὸ προσώπου, from the presence of, from, Acts 3:19; also, from before, Acts 7:45; εἰς πρόσωπον, and κατὰ πρόσωπον, in the presence of, before, Acts 3:13; 2 Cor. 8:24; also, openly, Gal. 2:11; κατὰ πρόσωπον, ἔχειν, to have before one’s face, to have any one present, Acts 25:16; ἀπὸ προσώπου, from, Rev. 12:14; πρὸ προσώπου, before, Acts 13:24

προτεινω.definition: to extend before; to stretch out, Acts 22:25*

g4387.definition: former, prior, Eph. 4:22; before, formerly, Jn. 6:62

προτιθημι.definition: to place before; to set forth, propose publicly, Rom. 3:25; mid. προτίθεμαι, to purpose, determine, design beforehand, Rom. 1:13; Eph. 1:9*

προτρεπω.definition: to turn forwards; to impel; to excite, urge, exhort, Acts 18:27*

προτρεχω.definition: to run before, or in advance, Lk. 19:4; Jn. 20:4*

προυπαρχω.definition: to be before, or formerly, Lk. 23:12; Acts 8:9*

προφασις.definition: pr. that which appears in front, that which is put forward to hide the true state of things; a fair show or pretext, Acts 27:30; a specious cloak, Mt. 23:13; 1 Thess. 2:5; an excuse, Jn. 15:22

προφερω.definition: to bring before, present; to bring forth or out, produce, Lk. 6:45 (2x)*

προφητεια.definition: prophecy, a prediction of future events, Mt. 13:14; 2 Pet. 1:20, 21; prophecy, a gifted faculty of setting forth and enforcing revealed truth, 1 Cor. 12:10; 13:2; prophecy, matter of divine teaching set forth by special gift, 1 Tim. 1:18

προφητευω.definition: to exercise the function of a προφήτης; to prophesy, to foretell the future, Mt. 11:13; to divine, Mt. 26:68; Mk. 14:65; Lk. 22:64; to prophesy, to set forth matter of divine teaching by special faculty, 1 Cor. 13:9; 14:1

προφητης.definition: pr. a spokesman for another; spc. a spokesman or interpreter for a deity; a prophet, seer, Tit. 1:12; in NT a prophet, a divinely commissioned and inspired person, Mt. 14:5; Lk. 7:16, 39; Jn. 9:17; a prophet in the Christian church, a person gifted for the exposition of divine truth, 1 Cor. 12:28, 29; a prophet, a foreteller of the future, Mt. 1:22, et al. freq.; οἱ προφῆται, the prophetic scriptures of the Old Testament, Lk. 16:29

προφητικος.definition: prophetic, uttered by prophets, Rom. 16:26; 2 Pet. 1:19*

προφητις.definition: a prophetess, a divinely gifted female teacher, Lk. 2:36; Rev. 2:20*

προφθανω.definition: to outstrip, anticipate; to anticipate any one in doing or saying a thing, be beforehand with, Mt. 17:25*

προχειριζω.definition: also listed as a deponent, προχειρίζομαι, to take into the hand, to make ready for use or action; to constitute, destine, Acts 3:20; 22:14; 26:16*

πρυμνα.definition: the hinder part of a vessel, stern, Mk. 4:38; Acts 27:29, 41*

πρωι.definition: in the morning, early, Mt. 16:3; 20:1; Mk. 15:1; Acts 28:23; the morning watch, which ushers in the dawn, Mk. 13:35

πρωια.definition: morning, the morning hour, Mt. 27:1; Jn. 21:4*

πρωινος.definition: belonging to the morning, morning, Rev. 2:28; 22:16*

πρωρα.definition: the forepart of a vessel, prow, Acts 27:30, 41*

πρωτευω.definition: to be first, to hold the first rank or highest dignity, have the preeminence, be chief, Col. 1:18*

πρωτοκαθεδρια.definition: the first or uppermost seat, the most honorable seat, Mt. 23:6; Mk. 12:39; Lk. 11:43; 20:46*

πρωτοκλισια.definition: the first place of reclining at table, the most honorable place at table, Mt. 23:6; Mk. 12:39; Lk. 14:7, 8; 20:46

πρωτον.definition: an accusative singular neuter form of πρῶτος (G4755) that became solidified in function as an adverb, first in time, in the first place, Mk. 4:28; 16:9; τὸ πρῶτον, at the first, formerly, Jn. 12:16; 19:39; first in dignity, importance, etc., before all things, Mt. 6:33

πρωτος.definition: first in time, order, etc., Mt. 10:2; 26:17; first in dignity, importance, etc., chief, principal, most important, Mk. 6:21; Lk. 19:47; Acts 13:50; 16:12; as an equivalent to the compar. πρότερος (G4754), prior, Jn. 1:5, 30; 15:18; Mt. 27:64; adverbially, first, Jn. 1:42; 5:4; 8:7

πρωτοστατης.definition: pr. one stationed in the first rank of an army; a leader; a chief, ringleader, Acts 24:5*

πρωτοτοκια.definition: the rights of primogeniture, birthright, Heb. 12:16

πρωτοτοκος.definition: first-born, Lk. 2:7; Heb. 11:28; in NT prior in generation, Col. 1:15; a firstborn head of a spiritual family, Rom. 8:29; Heb. 1:6; firstborn, as possessed of the peculiar privilege of spiritual generation, Heb. 12:23

πταιω.definition: to cause to stumble; intrans. to stumble, stagger, fall; to make a false step; met. to err, transgress, Rom. 11:11; Jas. 2:10; 3:2 (2x); met. to fail of an object, 2 Pet. 1:10*

πτερυγιον.definition: a little wing; the extremity, the extreme point of a thing; a pinnacle, or apex of a building, Mt. 4:5; Lk. 4:9*

πτηνος.definition: as adj., winged, with feathers; as noun, a bird, fowl, 1 Cor. 15:39*

πτοεω.definition: to terrify, affright; pass. to be terrified, Lk. 21:9; 24:37*

πτολεμαις.definition: Ptolemais, a city on the seacoast of Galilee: the modern Acre, Acts 21:7*. See PhotoGuide.

πτυον.definition: a fan, winnowing fork, Mt. 3:12; Lk. 3:17*

πτυρω.definition: to scare, terrify; pass. to be terrified, be in consternation, Phil. 1:28*

πτυσσω.definition: to fold; to roll up a scroll, Lk. 4:20*

πτυω.definition: to spit, spit out, Mk. 7:33; 8:23; Jn. 9:6

πτωμα.definition: a fall; a dead body, carcass, corpse, Mt. 24:28; Mk. 6:29

πτωσις.definition: a fall, crash, ruin, Mt. 7:27; met. downfall, ruin, Lk. 2:34*

πτωχευω.definition: to be a beggar; to be or become poor, be in poverty, 2 Cor. 8:9*

πτωχος.definition: reduced to beggary, mendicant; poor, indigent, Mt. 19:21; 26:9, 11; met. spiritually poor, Rev. 3:17; by impl. a person of low condition, Mt. 11:4; Lk. 4:18; 7:22; met. beggarly, sorry, Gal. 4:9; met. lowly, Mt. 5:3; Lk. 6:20

πυγμη.definition: together with the forearm, or, with care, carefully, Mk. 7:3*

πυκνος.definition: dense, thick; frequent, 1 Tim. 5:23; πυκνά, as an adverb, frequently, often, Lk. 5:33; so the compar. πυκνότερον, very frequently, Acts 24:26*

πυκτευω.definition: to box, fight as a boxer, 1 Cor. 9:26*

πυλη.definition: a gate, Mt. 7:13, 14; Lk. 7:12; Acts 12:10; πύλαι ᾅδου, the gates of hades, the nether world and its powers, the powers of destruction, dissolution, Mt. 16:18

πυλων.definition: a gateway, vestibule, Mt. 26:71; Lk. 16:20; a gate, Acts 14:13; Rev. 21:12, 13, 15, 21, 25

πυνθανομαι.definition: to ask, inquire, Mt. 2:4; Lk. 15:26; to investigate, examine judicially, Acts 23:20; to ascertain by inquiry, understand, Acts 23:34

πυρ.definition: fire, Mt. 3:10; 7:19; 13:40, et al. freq.; πυρός, used by Hebraism with the force of an adjective, fiery, fierce, Heb. 10:27; fire used figuratively to express various circumstances of severe trial, Lk. 12:49; 1 Cor. 3:13; Jude 23

πυρα.definition: a fire, heap of combustibles, Acts 28:2, 3*

πυργος.definition: a tower, Mt. 21:33; Mk. 12:1; Lk. 13:4; genr. a castle, palace, Lk. 14:28*

πυρεσσω.definition: to be feverish, be sick of a fever, Mt. 8:14; Mk. 1:30*

πυρετος.definition: scorching and noxious heat; a fever, Mt. 8:15; Mk. 1:31

πυρινος.definition: pr. of fire, fiery, burning; shining, glittering, Rev. 9:17*

πυροω.definition: to set on fire, burn; pass. to be kindled, be on fire, burn, flame, Eph. 6:16; 2 Pet. 3:12; Rev. 1:15; met. to fire with distressful feelings, 2 Cor. 11:29; of lust, to be inflamed, burn, 1 Cor. 7:9; to be tried with fire, as metals, Rev. 3:18*

πυρωσις.definition: a burning, conflagration, Rev. 18:9, 18; met. a fiery test of trying circumstances, 1 Pet. 4:12*

πωλος.definition: a youngling; a foal or colt, Mt. 21:2, 5, 7; Mk. 11:2

πωποτε.definition: ever yet, ever, at any time, Lk. 19:30; Jn. 1:18

πωροω.definition: to petrify; to harden; in NT to harden the feelings, Jn. 12:40; pass. to become callous, unimpressible, Mk. 6:52; 8:17; Rom. 11:7; 2 Cor. 3:14*

πωρωσις.definition: a hardening; met. hardness of heart, callousness, insensibility, Mk. 3:5; Rom. 11:25; Eph. 4:18*

πως.definition: interrogative particle, How? In what manner? By what means? Mt. 7:4; 22:12; Jn. 6:52; used in interrogations which imply a negative, Mt. 12:26, 29, 34; 22:45; 23:33; Acts 8:31; put concisely for How is it that? How does it come to pass that? Mt. 16:11; 22:43; Mk. 4:40; Jn. 7:15; with an indirect interrogation, how, in what manner, Mt. 6:28; 10:19; Mk. 11:18; put for τί, What? Lk. 10:26; put for ὡς, as a particle of exclamation, how, how much, how greatly, Mk. 10:23, 24

g4458.definition: enclitic particle, in any way, by any means, Acts 27:12; Rom. 1:10

ρααβ.definition: Rahab, pr. name, indecl. (Jsh. 2; 6:17, 25) Heb. 11:31; Jas. 2:25*

ραββι.definition: also spelled ῥαββεί, rabbi, my master, teacher, Mt. 23:7, 8; 26:25, 49

ραββουνι.definition: a form of ῥαββί, my teacher, Mk. 10:51; Jn. 20:16

ραβδιζω.definition: to beat with rods, Acts 16:22; 2 Cor. 11:25*

ραβδος.definition: a rod, wand, Heb. 9:4; Rev. 11:1; a rod of correction, 1 Cor. 4:21; a staff, Mt. 10:10; Heb. 11:21; a scepter, Heb. 1:8; Rev. 2:27

ραβδουχος.definition: the bearer of a wand of office; a lictor, sergeant, a public servant who bore a bundle or rods before the magistrates as insignia of their office, and carried into execution the sentences they pronounced, Acts 16:35, 38*

ραδιουργημα.definition: pr. anything done lightly, levity; reckless conduct, crime, Acts 18:14*

ραδιουργια.definition: facility of doing anything; levity in doing; recklessness, wickedness, Acts 13:10*

ρακα.definition: raca, an Aramaic term of bitter contempt, worthless fellow, fool, Mt. 5:22*

ρακος.definition: a piece torn off; a bit of cloth, cloth, Mt. 9:16; Mk. 2:21*

ραμα.definition: Rama, a city of Judea. See PhotoGuide.

ραντιζω.definition: to sprinkle, Heb. 9:13, 19, 21; met. and by impl. to cleanse by sprinkling, purify, free from pollution, Heb. 10:22*

ραντισμος.definition: pr. a sprinkling; met. a cleansing, purification, Heb. 12:24; 1 Pet. 1:2*

ραπιζω.definition: to beat with rods; to strike with the palm of the hand, cuff, clap, Mt. 5:39; 26:67*

ραπισμα.definition: a blow with the palm of the hand, cuff, slap, Mk. 14:65; Jn. 18:22; 19:3*

ρεδη.definition: a carriage with four wheels for travelling, a chariot, Rev. 18:13*

ρηγιον.definition: Rhegium, a city at the southwestern extremity of Italy, Acts 28:13*. See PhotoGuide.

ρηγμα.definition: a rent; a crash, ruin, Lk. 6:49*

ρημα.definition: that which is spoken; declaration, saying, speech, word, Mt. 12:36; 26:75; Mk. 9:32; 14:72; a command, mandate, direction, Lk. 3:2; 5:5; a promise, Lk. 1:38; 2:29; a prediction, prophecy, 2 Pet. 3:2; a doctrine of God or Christ, Jn. 3:34; 5:47; 6:63, 68; Acts 5:20; an accusation, charge, crimination, Mt. 5:11; 27:14; from the Hebrew, a thing, Mt. 4:4; Lk. 4:4; a matter, affair, transaction, business, Mt. 18:16; Lk. 1:65; 2 Cor. 13:1

ρησσω.definition: in our text (Mt. 9:17). to rend, shatter; to break or burst in pieces Mt. 9:17; Mk. 2:22; Lk. 5:37; to rend, lacerate, Mt. 7:6; to cast or dash upon the ground, convulse, Mk. 9:18; Lk. 9:42; absol. to break forth into exclamation, Gal. 4:27

ριζα.definition: a root of a tree, Mt. 3:10; 13:6; met. ἔχειν ῥίζαν, or ἔχειν ῥίζαν ἐν ἑαυτῷ, to be rooted in faith, Mt. 13:21; Mk. 4:17; Lk. 8:13; met. cause, source, origin, 1 Tim. 6:10; Heb. 12:15; by synec. the trunk, stock of a tree, met. Rom. 11:16, 17, 18; met. offspring, progeny, a descendant, Rom. 15:12; Rev. 5:5; 22:16

ριζοω.definition: to root, cause to take root; firmly rooted, strengthened with roots; met. firm, constant, firmly fixed, Eph. 3:17; Col. 2:7*

ριπη.definition: pr. a rapid sweep, jerk; a wink, twinkling of the eye, 1 Cor. 15:52*

ριπιζω.definition: to fan, blow, ventilate; to toss, agitate, e.g. the ocean by the wind, Jas. 1:6*

ριπτεω.definition: also spelled ῥίπτω, frequent and repeated action, to toss repeatedly, toss up with violent gesture, Acts 22:23 (ῥιπτούντων)*

ριπτω.definition: also spelled ῥιπτέω, to hurl, throw, cast; to throw or cast down, Mt. 27:5; Lk. 4:35; 17:2; to throw or cast out, Acts 27:19, 29; to lay down, set down, Mt. 15:30; pass. to be dispersed, scattered, Mt. 9:36*

ροδος.definition: Rhodes, an island in the Mediterranean, south of Caria, Acts 21:1*

ροιζηδον.definition: with a noise, with a crash, etc., 2 Pet. 3:10*

ρομφαια.definition: pr. a Thracian broad-sword; a sword, Rev. 1:16; 2:12; by meton. war, Rev. 6:8; met. a thrill of anguish, Lk. 2:35

ρυμη.definition: pr. a rush or sweep of a body in motion; a street, Acts 9:11; 12:10; a narrow street, lane, alley, as distinguished from πλατεῖα, Mt. 6:2; Lk. 14:21*

ρυομαι.definition: to drag out of danger, to rescue, save, Mt. 6:13; 27:43; to be rescued, delivered, Lk. 1:74; Rom. 15:31; 2 Thess. 3:2; 2 Tim. 4:17

ρυπαρια.definition: filth; met. moral filthiness, uncleanness, pollution, Jas. 1:21*

ρυπαρος.definition: filthy, squalid, sordid, dirty, Jas. 2:2; met. defiled, polluted, Rev. 22:11*

ρυσις.definition: a flowing; a morbid flux, Mk. 5:25; Lk. 8:43, 44*

ρυτις.definition: a wrinkle; met. a disfiguring wrinkle, flaw, blemish, Eph. 5:27*

ρωμαιος.definition: Roman; a Roman citizen, Jn. 11:48; Acts 2:10; 16:21

ρωμαιστι.definition: in the Roman language, in Latin, Jn. 19:20*

ρωννυμι.definition: to strengthen, render firm; to be well, enjoy firm health; at the end of letters, like the Latin vale, farewell, Acts 15:29*

σαβαχθανι.definition: (Aramaic) sabacthani, you have forsaken me; interrogatively, have you forsaken me? preceded with λαμᾶ, Why? Mt. 27:46; Mk. 15:34*

σαββατισμος.definition: pr. a keeping of a sabbath; a state of rest, a sabbath-state, Heb. 4:9*

σαββατον.definition: pr. cessation from labor, rest; the Jewish sabbath, both in the sg. and pl., Mt. 12:2, 5, 8; 28:1; Lk. 4:16; a week, sg. and pl., Mt. 28:1; Mk. 16:9; pl. sabbaths, or times of sacred rest, Col. 2:16

σαδδουκαιος.definition: a Sadducee, one belonging to the sect of the Sadducees, which, according to the Talmudists, was founded by one, Sadoc, about three centuries before the Christian era: they were directly opposed in sentiments to the Pharisees, Mt. 3:7; 16:1, 6, 11, 12; 22:23, 34; Mk. 12:18; Lk. 20:27; Acts 4:1; 5:17; 23:6-8*

σαινω.definition: pr. to wag the tail; to fawn, flatter, cajole; pass. to be cajoled; to be wrought upon, to be perturbed, 1 Thess. 3:3*

σακκος.definition: sackcloth, a coarse black cloth made of hair (goat or camel), Rev. 6:12; a mourning garment of sackcloth, Mt. 11:21; Lk. 10:13; Rev. 11:3*

σαλαθιηλ.definition: Shealtiel, pr. name, indecl., Mt. 1:12; Lk. 3:27*

σαλαμις.definition: Saleim, also formed as Σαλίμ (G4890). John was baptizing at Aenon near Saleim, Jn. 3:26*. See PhotoGuide.

σαλευω.definition: to make to rock, to shake, Mt. 11:7; 24:29; Mk. 13:25; Lk. 6:38, 48; 7:24; 21:26; Acts 4:31; 16:26; Heb. 12:26; met. to stir up, excite the people, Acts 17:13; to agitate, disturb mentally, Acts 2:25; 2 Thess. 2:2; pass. impl. to totter, be ready to fall, be near to ruin, met. Heb. 12:36, 27*

σαλημ.definition: (Hebrew, meaning peace), Salem, pr. name, indecl., Heb. 7:1f.*

σαλμωνη.definition: Salmone, a promontory, the eastern extremity of Crete, Acts 27:7*

σαλος.definition: agitation, tossing, rolling, spc. of the sea, Lk. 21:25*

σαλπιγξ.definition: trumpet, 1 Cor. 14:8; Heb. 12:19; Rev. 1:10; 4:1; 8:2, 6; 13:9; 1 Thess. 4:16; sound of the trumpet, Mt. 24:31; 1 Cor. 15:52; 1 Thess. 4:16*

σαλωμη.definition: Salome, pr. name, a Galilean woman who followed Jesus, Mt. 27:56; Mk. 15:40; 16:1*

σαμαρεια.definition: Samaria, the city and region so called, Acts 8:14

σαμαριτης.definition: a Samaritan, an inhabitant of the city or region of Samaria, applied by the Jews as a term of reproach and contempt, Mt. 10:5; Jn. 4:9, 39f.; 8:48; Lk. 9:52; 10:33; 17:16; Acts 8:25*

σαμοθρακη.definition: Samothrace, an island in the northern part of the Aegean sea, Acts 16:11*

σαμος.definition: Samos, a celebrated island, in the Aegean sea, Acts 20:15*

σαμουηλ.definition: (1 Sam. 1:1-25:1), Samuel, pr. name, indecl., Acts 3:24; 13:20; Heb. 11:32*

σανδαλιον.definition: a sandal, a sole of wood or hide, covering the bottom of the foot, and bound on with leathern thongs, Mk. 6:9, Acts 12:8*

σαουλ.definition: Saul, pr. name, indecl. I. Saul, king of Israel, Acts 13:21; II. The Apostle Paul, Acts 9:4, 17; 22:7, 13; 26:14*

σαπρος.definition: pr. rotten, putrid; hence, bad, of a bad quality, Mt. 7:17, 18; 12:33; Lk. 6:43; refuse, Mt. 13:48; met. corrupt, depraved, vicious, foul, impure, Eph. 4:29*

σαπφιρα.definition: Sapphira, wife of Ananias and a member of the Jerusalem church, Acts 5:1*

σαπφιρος.definition: a sapphire, a precious stone of a blue color in various shades, next in hardness and value to the diamond, Rev. 21:19

σαργανη.definition: twisted or plaited work; a netword of cords like a basket, basket of ropes, etc. 2 Cor. 11:33*

σαρδεις.definition: Sardis, the capital city of Lydia, in Asia Minor Rev. 1:11; 3:1, 4*. See PhotoGuide.

σαρδιον.definition: carnelian, a reddish precious stone, Rev. 4:3; 21:20*

σαρδονυξ.definition: sardonyx, a gem exhibiting the color of the carnelian and the white of the calcedony, intermingled in alternate layers, Rev. 21:20*

σαρεπτα.definition: Sarepta, a city of Phoenicia, between Tyre and Sidon, Lk. 4:26*

σαρκικος.definition: fleshly; pertaining to the body, corporeal, physical, Rom. 15:27; 1 Cor. 9:11; carnal, pertaining to the flesh, 1 Pet. 2:11; carnal, low in spiritual knowledge and frame, 1 Cor. 3:3 (2x); carnal, human as opposed to divine, 2 Cor. 1:12; 10:4*

σαρκινος.definition: of flesh, fleshly, 2 Cor. 3:3; Rom. 7:14; 1 Cor. 3:1; Heb. 7:16*

σαρξ.definition: flesh, Lk. 24:39; Jn. 3:6; the human body, 2 Cor. 7:5; flesh, human nature, human frame, Jn. 1:13, 14; 1 Pet. 4:1; 1 Jn. 4:2; kindred, Rom. 11:14; lineage, Rom. 1:3; 9:3; flesh, humanity, human beings, Mt. 24:22; Lk. 3:6; Jn. 17:2; the circumstances of the body, material condition, 1 Cor. 5:5; 7:28; Phlm. 16; flesh, mere humanity, human fashion, 1 Cor. 1:26; 2 Cor. 1:17; flesh as the seat of passion and frailty, Rom. 8:1, 3, 5; carnality, Gal. 5:24; materiality, material circumstance, as opposed to the spiritual, Phil. 3:3, 4; Col. 2:18; a material system or mode, Gal. 3:3; Heb. 9:10

σαροω.definition: to sweep, to clean with a broom, Mt. 12:44; Lk. 11:25; 15:8*

σαρρα.definition: Sara, Sarah, pr. name, the wife of Abraham, Rom. 4:19; 9:9; Heb. 11:11; 1 Pet. 3:6*

σαρων.definition: Saron, a level tract of Palestine, between Caesarea and Joppa, Acts 9:35*

σατανας.definition: an adversary, opponent, enemy, perhaps, Mt. 16:23; Mk. 8:33; Lk. 4:8; elsewhere, Satan, the devil, Mt. 4:10; Mk. 1:13

σατον.definition: a satum or seah, a Hebrew measure for things dry, containing, as Josephus testifies, (Ant. 9.85) an Italian modius and one half, or 24 sextarii, and therefore equivalent to somewhat less than three gallons English, Mt. 13:33; Lk. 13:21*

σαυλος.definition: Saul, the Hebrew name of the Apostle Paul, Σαούλ with a Greek termination, Acts 7:58; 8:1, 3; 9:1

σβεννυμι.definition: to extinguish, quench, Mt. 12:20; 25:8; Mk. 9:44, 46, 48; Eph. 6:16; Heb. 11:34; met. to quench, damp, hinder, thwart, 1 Thess. 5:19*

σεαυτου.definition: of yourself, to yourself, etc. Mt. 4:6; 8:4; 19:19

σεβαζομαι.definition: to feel dread of a thing; to venerate, adore, worship, Rom. 1:25*

σεβασμα.definition: an object of religious veneration and worship, Acts 17:23; 2 Thess. 2:4*

σεβαστος.definition: pr. venerable, august; ὁ Σεβαστός, i.q. Latin Augustus, Acts 25:21, 25; Augustan, or, Sebastan, named from the city Sebaste, Acts 27:1*

σεβω.definition: mid., to stand in awe; to venerate, reverence, worship, adore, Mt. 15:9; Mk. 7:7; Acts 18:13; 19:27; part. σεβόμενος, η, ον, worshiping, devout, pious, a term applied to proselytes to Judaism, Acts 13:43; 16:14; 18:7; 13:50; 17:4, 17*

σειρα.definition: a cord, rope, band; in NT a chain, 2 Pet. 2:4*

σεισμος.definition: pr. a shaking, agitation, concussion; an earthquake, Mt. 24:7; 27:54; a tempest, Mt. 8:24

σειω.definition: to shake, agitate, Heb. 12:26; pass. to quake, Mt. 27:51; 28:4; Rev. 6:13; met. to put in commotion, agitate, Mt. 21:10

σελευκεια.definition: Seleucia, a city of Syria, west of Antioch, on the Orontes, Acts 13:4*. See PhotoGuide.

σεμνος.definition: august, venerable; honorable, reputable, Phil. 4:8; grave, serious, dignified, 1 Tim. 3:8, 11; Tit. 2:2*

σεμνοτης.definition: pr. majesty; gravity, dignity, dignified seriousness, 1 Tim. 2:2; 3:4; Tit. 2:7*

σημαινω.definition: to indicate by a sign, to signal; to indicate, intimate, Jn. 12:33; 18:32; 21:19; to make known, communicate, Acts 11:28; Rev. 1:1; to specify, Acts 25:27*

σημειον.definition: a sign, a mark, token, by which anything is known or distinguished, Mt. 16:3; 24:3; 2 Thess. 3:17; a token, pledge, assurance, Lk. 2:12; a proof, evidence, convincing token, Mt. 12:38; 16:1; Jn. 2:18; in NT a sign, wonder, remarkable event, wonderful appearance, extraordinary phenomenon, 1 Cor. 14:22; Rev. 12:1, 3; 15:1; a portent, prodigy, Mt. 24:30; Acts 2:19; a wonderful work, miraculous operation, miracle, Mt. 24:24; Mk. 16:17, 20; meton. a sign, a signal character, Lk. 2:34

σημειοω.definition: mid., to mark, inscribe marks upon; mid. to mark for one’s self, note, 2 Thess. 3:14*

σημερον.definition: today, this day, Mt. 6:11, 30; 16:3; 21:28; now, at present, Heb. 13:8; 2 Cor. 3:15; ἡ σήμερον, i.e. ἡμέρα, sometimes expressed, this day, the present day, Acts 20:26; ἕως or ἄχρι τῆς σήμερον, until this day, until our times, Mt. 11:23; 27:8

σηπω.definition: to cause to putrify, rot, be corrupted or rotten, Jas. 5:2*

σιαγων.definition: the jawbone; in NT the cheek, Mt. 5:39; Lk. 6:29*

σιγαω.definition: to be silent, keep silence, Lk. 9:36; 20:26; Acts 15:12f.; 1 Cor. 14:28, 30, 34; Lk. 18:39; trans. to keep in silence, not to reveal, to conceal; pass. to be concealed, not to be revealed, Rom. 16:25*

σιδων.definition: Sidon, a celebrated city of Phoenicia, Mt. 11:21f.; Mk. 3:8; 7:31; Lk. 6:17; Acts 27:3. See PhotoGuide.

σιδωνιος.definition: Sidonian; an inhabitant of Σιδών, Sidon, Acts 12:20; Lk. 4:26*

σιλας.definition: Silas, pr. name, in Luke, Acts 15:22; see Σιλουανός

σιλουανος.definition: Silvanus, pr. name, 2 Cor. 1:19; 1 Thess. 1:1; 2 Thess. 1:1; 1 Pet. 5:12, see Σίλας*

σιλωαμ.definition: Siloam, a pool or fountain near Jerusalem, Lk. 13:4; Jn. 9:7, 11*

σιμων.definition: Simon, pr. name. (1) Simon Peter, Mt. 4:18. (2) Simon (the Canaanite) the Zealot, Mt. 10:4; Acts 1:13 . (3) Simon, brother of Jesus, Mt. 13:55; Mk. 6:3. (4) Simon, the leper, Mt. 26:6; Mk. 14:3. (5) Simon, the Pharisee, Lk. 7:40. (6) Simon of Cyrene, Mt. 27:32. (7) Simon, father of Judas Iscariot, Jn. 6:71. (8) Simon, the sorcerer, Acts 8:9. (9) Simon, the tanner, of Joppa, Acts 9:43; 10:6

σινα.definition: Mount Sinai, in Arabia, Acts 7:30, 38; Gal. 4:24, 25*

σιναπι.definition: mustard; in NT probably the shrub, not the herb, Khardal, Salvadora Persica L., the fruit of which possesses the pungency of mustard, Mt. 13:31; 17:20; Mk. 4:31; Lk. 13:19; 17:6*

σινδων.definition: sindon; pr. fine Indian cloth; fine linen; in NT a linen garment, an upper garment or wrapper of fine linen, worn in summer by night, and used to envelope dead bodies, Mt. 27:59; Mk. 14:51, 52; 15:46; Lk. 23:53*

σινιαζω.definition: to sift; met. to sift by trials and temptations, Lk. 22:31*

σιρικος.definition: see also σηρικός, silk, of silk, silken; τὸ σηρικόν, silken stuff, Rev. 18:12*

σιτομετριον.definition: a certain measure of grain distributed for food at set times to the slaves of a family, a ration, Lk. 12:42*

σιων.definition: Zion, Mt. Zion, a hill within the city of Jerusalem, indecl., Heb. 12:22; Rev. 14:1; poetic use, Mt. 21:5; Jn. 12:15; people of Israel, Rom. 9:33; 11:26; new Jerusalem of Christianity, 1 Pet. 2:6*

σιωπαω.definition: to be silent, keep silence, hold one’s peace, Mt. 20:31; 26:63; Mk. 3:4; 9:34; 10:48; 14:61; Lk. 19:40; Acts 18:9; σιωπῶν, silent, dumb, Lk. 1:20; met. to be silent, still, hushed, calm, as the sea, Mk. 4:39*

σκανδαλιζω.definition: pr. to cause to stumble; met. offend, Mt. 17:27; to offend, shock, excite feeling of repugnance, Jn. 6:61; 1 Cor. 8:13; pass. to be offended, shocked, pained, Mt. 15:12; Rom. 14:21; 2 Cor. 11:29; σκανδαλίζεσθαι ἔν τινι, to be affected with scruples of repugnance towards any one as respects his claims or pretensions, Mt. 11:6; 13:57; met. to cause to stumble morally, to cause to falter or err, Mt. 5:29; 18:6; pass. to falter, fall away, Mt. 13:21

σκανδαλον.definition: pr. a trap-spring; also genr. a stumbling block, anything against which one stumbles, an impediment; met. a cause of ruin, destruction, misery, etc., Rom. 9:33; 11:9; 1 Pet. 2:8; a cause or occasion of sinning, Mt. 16:23; 18:7 (3x); Lk. 17:1; Rom. 14:13; 16:17; Rev. 2:14; scandal, offense, cause of indignation, Mt. 13:41; 1 Cor. 1:23; Gal. 5:11; 1 Jn. 2:10*

σκαφη.definition: pr. anything excavated or hollowed; a boat, skiff, Acts 27:16, 30, 32*

σκευος.definition: a vessel, utensil for containing anything, Mk. 11:16; Lk. 8:16; Rom. 9:21; any utensil, instrument; σκεύη, household stuff, furniture, goods, etc., Mt. 12:29; Mk. 3:27; the mast of a ship, or, the sail, Acts 27:17; met. an instrument, means, organ, minister, Acts 9:15; σκεύη ὀργῆς and σκεύη ἐλέους, vessels of wrath, or, of mercy, persons visited by punishment, or, the divine favor, Rom. 9:22, 23; the vessel or frame of the human individual, 1 Thess. 4:4; 1 Pet. 3:7

σκηνη.definition: a tent, tabernacle; genr. any temporary dwelling; a tent, booth, Mt. 17:4; Heb. 11:9; the tabernacle of the covenant, Heb. 8:5; 9:1, 21; 13:10; allegor. the celestial or true tabernacle, Heb. 8:2; 9:11; a division or compartment of the tabernacle, Heb. 9:2, 3, 6; a small portable tent or shrine, Acts 7:43; an abode or seat of a lineage, Acts 15:16; a mansion, habitation, abode, dwelling, Lk. 16:9; Rev. 13:6

σκηνοπηγια.definition: pr. a pitching of tents or booths; hence, the feast of tabernacles or booths, instituted in memory of the forty years’ wandering of the Israelites in the desert, and as a season of gratitude for the ingathering of harvest, celebrated for eight days, commencing on the 15th of Tisri, Jn. 7:2*

σκηνος.definition: a tent, tabernacle, lodging; met. the corporeal tabernacle, 2 Cor. 5:1, 4*

σκηνοω.definition: to pitch tent, encamp; to tabernacle, dwell in a tent; to dwell, have one’s abode, Jn. 1:14; Rev. 7:15; 12:12; 13:6; 21:3*

σκηνωμα.definition: a habitation, abode, dwelling, Acts 7:46; the corporeal tabernacle of the soul, 2 Pet. 1:13, 14*

σκια.definition: a shade, shadow, Mk. 4:32; Acts 5:15; met. a shadow, a foreshadowing, a vague outline, in distinction from ἡ εἰκών, the perfect image or delineation, and τὸ σῶμα, the reality, Col. 2:17; Heb. 8:5; 10:1; gloom; σκιὰ θανάτου, death shade, the thickest darkness, Mt. 4:16; Lk. 1:79*

σκιρταω.definition: to leap, Lk. 1:41, 44; to leap, skip, bound for joy, Lk. 6:23*

σκληροκαρδια.definition: hardness of heart, obstinacy, perverseness, Mt. 19:8; Mk. 10:5; 16:14*

σκληρος.definition: dry, hard to the touch; met. harsh, severe, stern, Mt. 25:24; vehement, violent, fierce, Jas. 3:4; grievous, painful, Acts 26:14; grating to the mind, repulsive, offensive, Jn. 6:60; stubborn, resistance to authority, Jude 15*

σκληροτης.definition: hardness; met. σκληρότης τῆς καρδίας, hardness of heart, obstinacy, perverseness, Rom. 2:5*

σκληρυνω.definition: to harden; met. to harden morally, to make stubborn, Heb. 3:8, 15; 4:7; as a negation of ἐλεεῖν, to leave to stubbornness and contumacy, Rom. 9:18; mid. and pass. to put on a stubborn frame, Acts 19:9; Heb. 3:13*

σκολιος.definition: crooked, tortuous, Lk. 3:5; met. perverse, wicked, Acts 2:40; Phil. 2:15; crooked, peevish, morose, 1 Pet. 2:18*

σκολοψ.definition: anything pointed; met. a thorn, a plague, 2 Cor. 12:7*

σκοπεω.definition: to view attentively, watch; to see, observe, take care, beware, Lk. 11:35; Gal. 6:1; to regard, have respect to, 2 Cor. 4:18; Phil. 2:4; to mark, note, Rom. 16:17; Phil. 3:17*

σκοπος.definition: a watcher; also, a distant object on which the eye is kept fixed; a mark, goal, Phil. 3:14*

σκορπιος.definition: a scorpion, a large insect, sometimes several inches in length, shaped somewhat like a crab and furnished with a tail terminating in a stinger from which it emits a dangerous poison, Lk. 10:19; 11:12; Rev. 9:3, 5, 10*

σκοτια.definition: darkness, Jn. 6:17; 20:1; privacy, Mt. 10:27; Lk. 12:3; met. moral or spiritual darkness, Jn. 1:5 (2x); 8:12; 12:35, 46; 1 Jn. 1:5; 2:8, 9, 11*

σκοτος.definition: darkness, Mt. 27:45; Acts 2:20; gloom of punishment and misery, Mt. 8:12; 2 Pet. 2:17; met. moral or spiritual darkness, Mt. 4:16; Jn. 3:19; Eph. 5:11; a realm of moral darkness, Eph. 5:8; 6:12

σκοτοω.definition: to darken, shroud in darkness, Eph. 4:18; Rev. 9:2; 16:10

σκυθης.definition: A Scythian, a native of Scythia, the modern Mongolia and Tartary, Col. 3:11*

σκυθρωπος.definition: of a stern, morose, sour, gloomy, or dejected countenance, Mt. 6:16; Lk. 24:17*

σκυλλω.definition: to flay, lacerate; met. to vex, trouble, annoy, Mk. 5:35; Lk. 7:6; 8:49; pass. met. ἐσκυλμένοι, in sorry plight, Mt. 9:36*

σκυλον.definition: spoils stripped off an enemy; σκῦλα, spoil, plunder, booty, Lk. 11:22*

σκωληκοβρωτος.definition: eaten of worms, consumed by worms, Acts 12:23*

σκωληξ.definition: a worm; met. gnawing anguish, Mk. 9:48*

σμαραγδος.definition: smaragdus, the emerald, a gem of a pure green color; but under this name the ancients probably comprised all stones of a fine green color, Rev. 21:19*

σμυρνα.definition: Smyrna, a maritime city of Ionia, in Asia Minor, Rev. 1:11; 2:8*. See PhotoGuide.

σμυρνιζω.definition: to mingle or flavor with myrrh, Mk. 15:23*

σοδομα.definition: Sodom, (Gen. 19:24) one of the four cities of the vale of Siddim, now covered by the Dead sea, Mt. 11:23f.; Lk. 17:29; Rom. 9:29; 2 Pet. 2:6; Rev. 11:8

σολομων.definition: Solomon, also spelled Σολομῶν, pr. name, son and successor of David, Mt. 1:6f.; 6:29; Lk. 11:31; Jn. 10:23; Acts 3:11; 7:47

σορος.definition: a coffer; an urn for receiving the ashes of the dead; a coffin; in NT a bier, Lk. 7:14*

σος.definition: yours, Mt. 7:3, 22; οἱ σοί, your kindred, friends, etc., Mk. 5:19; τὸ σόν and τὰ σά, what is yours, your property, goods, etc., Mt. 20:14; 25:25; Lk. 6:30

σουδαριον.definition: a handkerchief, napkin, etc., Lk. 19:20; Jn. 11:44; 20:7; Acts 19:12*

σοφια.definition: wisdom in general, knowledge, Mt. 12:42; Lk. 2:40, 52; 11:31; Acts 7:10; ability, Lk. 21:15; Acts 6:3, 10; practical wisdom, prudence, Col. 4:5; learning, science, Mt. 13:54; Mk. 6:2; Acts 7:22; scientific skill, 1 Cor. 1:17; 2:1; professed wisdom, human philosophy, 1 Cor. 1:19, 20, 22; 2:4, 5, 6; superior knowledge and enlightenment, Col. 2:23; in NT divine wisdom, Rom. 11:33; Eph. 3:10; Col. 2:3; revealed wisdom, Mt. 11:19; Lk. 11:49; 1 Cor. 1:24, 30; 2:7; Christian enlightenment, 1 Cor. 12:8; Eph. 1:8, 17; Col. 1:9, 28, 3:16; Jas. 1:5; 3:13

σοφιζω.definition: to make wise, enlighten, 2 Tim. 3:15; mid. to invent skilfully, devise artfully, pass. 2 Pet. 1:16*

σοφος.definition: wise generally, 1 Cor. 1:25; shrewd, clever, Rom. 16:19; 1 Cor. 3:10; 6:5; learned, intelligent, Mt. 11:25; Rom. 1:14, 22; 1 Cor. 1:19, 20, 26, 27; 3:18; in NT divinely instructed, Mt. 23:34; furnished with Christian wisdom, spiritually enlightened, Jas. 3:13; all wise, Rom. 16:27; 1 Tim. 1:17; Jude 25

σπαρασσω.definition: pr. to tear, lacerate; by impl. to agitate greatly, convulse, distort by convulsion, Mk. 1:26; 9:26; Lk. 9:39*

σπαργανοω.definition: to swathe, wrap in swaddling cloths, Lk. 2:7, 12*

σπαταλαω.definition: to live luxuriously, voluptuously, wantonly, 1 Tim. 5:6; Jas. 5:5*

σπαω.definition: to draw, pull; to draw a sword, Mk. 14:47; Acts 16:27*

σπειρα.definition: anything twisted or wreathed, a cord, coil, band, etc.; a band of soldiers, company, troop; used for a Roman cohort, about 600 soldiers, Mt. 27:27; Acts 10:1; the temple guard, Mk. 15:16; Jn. 18:3, 12; Acts 21:31; 27:1*

σπεκουλατωρ.definition: a sentinel, life-guardsman, a kind of soldiers who formed the body-guard of princes, etc., one of whose duties was to put criminals to death, Mk. 6:27*

σπενδω.definition: to pour out a libation or drink-offering; in NT mid. to make a libation of one’s self by expending energy and life in the service of the Gospel, Phil. 2:17; pass. to be in the act of being sacrificed in the cause of the Gospel, 2 Tim. 4:6*

σπερμα.definition: seed, Mt. 13:24, 27, 37, 38; semen virile, Heb. 11:11; offspring, posterity, Mt. 22:24, 25; Jn. 7:42; a seed of future generations, Rom. 9:29; in NT met. a seed or principle of spiritual life, 1 Jn. 3:9

σπερμολογος.definition: pr. seed-picking; one who picks up and retails scraps of information; a gossip; a babbler, Acts 17:18*

σπευδω.definition: trans. to urge on, impel, quicken; to quicken in idea, to be eager for the arrival of, 2 Pet. 3:12; intrans. to hasten, make haste, Acts 20:16; 22:18; the part. has the force of an adverb, quickly, hastily, Lk. 2:16; 19:5, 6*

σπηλαιον.definition: a cave, cavern, den, hideout, Mt. 21:13; Mk. 11:17; Lk. 19:46; Jn. 11:38; Heb. 11:38; Rev. 6:5*

σπιλας.definition: a sharply-cleft portion of rock; in NT a flaw, stigma, Jude 12*

σπιλος.definition: a spot, stain, blot; a moral blemish, Eph. 5:27; 2 Pet. 2:13*

σπιλοω.definition: to spot, soil; to contaminate, defile, Jas. 3:6; Jude 23*

σπλαγχνιζομαι.definition: to be moved with pity or compassion, Mt. 9:36; 14:14; 20:34; Lk. 7:13; to be compassionate, Mt. 18:27

σπλαγχνον.definition: the chief intestines, viscera; the entrails, bowels, Acts 1:18; met. the heart, the affections of the heart, the tender affections, Lk. 1:78; 2 Cor. 6:12; 7:15; Phil. 1:8, 2:1; Col. 3:12; Phlm. 7, 20; 1 Jn. 3:17; meton. a cherished one, dear as one’s self, Phlm. 12*

σπορα.definition: a sowing; seed sown; met. generative seed, generation, 1 Pet. 1:23*

σποριμος.definition: sown, fit to be sown; in NT τὰ σπόριμα, fields which are sown, fields of grain, cornfields, Mt. 12:1; Mk. 2:23; Lk. 6:1*

σπορος.definition: a sowing; in NT seed, that which is sown, Mk. 4:26, 27; Lk. 8:5, 11; met. the seed sown in almsgiving, 2 Cor. 9:10*

σπουδαζω.definition: to hurry; be bent upon, Gal. 2:10; to endeavor earnestly, strive, Eph. 4:3

g4709.definition: earnestly, eagerly, diligently, Lk. 7:4; 2 Tim. 1:17; Tit. 3:13; compar. σπουδαιοτέρως, more earnestly, with special urgency, Phil. 2:28

σπουδη.definition: haste; μετὰ σπουδῆς, with haste, hastily, quickly, Mk. 6:25; Lk. 1:39; earnestness, earnest application, diligence, enthusiasm, Rom. 12:8, 11; 2 Cor. 7:11, 12; 8:16; 8:7f.

σπυρις.definition: also spelled σφυρίς, a basket, handbasket for provision, Mt. 15:37; 16:10; Mk. 8:8, 20; Acts 9:25*

σταδιον.definition: pr. a fixed standard of measure; a stadium, the eighth part of a Roman mile, and nearly equal to a furlong, containing 201.45 yards, about 192 meters, Lk. 24:13; Mt. 14:24; Jn. 6:19; 11:18; Rev. 14:20; 21:16; a race-course, a race, 1 Cor. 9:24*

σταμνος.definition: can be masculine, but not in the NT, a wine jar; a pot, jar, urn, vase, Heb. 9:4*

στασις.definition: a setting; a standing; an effective position, an unimpaired standing or dignity, Heb. 9:8; a gathered party, a group; hence, a tumultuous assemblage, popular outbreak, Mk. 15:7; Acts 19:40; Lk. 23:19, 25; seditious movement, Acts 24:5; discord, dispute, dissension, Acts 15:2; 23:7, 10*

στατηρ.definition: pr. a weight; a stater, an Attic silver coin, equal in value to the Jewish shekel, or to four Attic or two Alexandrian drachmas, Mt. 17:27*

σταυρος.definition: a stake; a cross, Mt. 27:32, 40, 42; Phil. 2:8; by impl. the punishment of the cross, crucifixion, Eph. 2:16; Heb. 12:2; meton. the crucifixion of Christ in respect of its import, the doctrine of the cross, 1 Cor. 17:18; Gal. 5:11; 6:12, 14; met. to take up, or bear one’s cross, to be ready to encounter any extremity, Mt. 10:38; 16:24

σταυροω.definition: to fix stakes; later, to crucify, affix to the cross, Mt. 20:19; 23:34; met. to crucify, to mortify, to deaden, to make a sacrifice of, Gal. 5:24; pass. to be cut off from a thing, as by a violent death, to be come dead to, Gal. 6:14

σταφυλη.definition: a cluster or bunch of grapes, Mt. 7:16; Lk. 6:44, Rev. 14:18*

στεγη.definition: a roof, flat roof of a house, Mt. 8:8; Mk. 2:4; Lk. 7:6*

στεγω.definition: to cover; to hold off, to hold in; hence, to hold out against, to endure patiently, 1 Cor. 9:12; 13:7; absol. to contain one’s self, 1 Thess. 3:1, 5*

στειρα.definition: barren, incapable of bearing children, Lk. 1:7, 36; 23:29; Gal. 4:27; Heb. 11:11*

στελλω.definition: pr. to place in set order, to arrange; to equip; to despatch; to stow; mid. to contract one’s self, to shrink; to withdraw from, avoid, shun, 2 Cor. 8:20; 2 Thess. 3:6*

στεναγμος.definition: a sighing, groaning, groan, Acts 7:34; an inward sighing, Rom. 8:26*

στεναζω.definition: to groan, sigh, Rom. 8:23; 2 Cor. 5:2, 4; Heb. 13:17; to sigh inwardly, Mk. 7:34; to give vent to querulous or censorious feelings, Jas. 5:9*

στενοχωρεω.definition: to crowd together into a narrow place, straiten; pass. met. to be in straits, to be cooped up, to be cramped from action, 2 Cor. 4:8; to be cramped in feeling, 2 Cor. 6:12*

στενοχωρια.definition: pr. narrowness of place, a narrow place; met. straits, distress, anguish, Rom. 2:9; 8:35; 2 Cor. 6:4; 12:10*

στερεος.definition: stiff, hard; of food, solid, as opposed to what is liquid and light, Heb. 5:12, 14; firm, steadfast, 2 Tim. 2:19; 1 Pet. 5:9*

στερεοω.definition: to make firm; to strengthen, Acts 3:7, 16; to settle, Acts 16:5*

στερεωμα.definition: pr. what is solid and firm; met. firmness, steadfastness, constancy, Col. 2:5*

στεφανος.definition: that which forms an encirclement; a crown, Mt. 27:29; Rev. 4:4, 10; wreath, conferred on a victor in the public games, 1 Cor. 9:25; met. a crown, reward, prize, 2 Tim. 4:8; Jas. 1:12; a crown, ornament, honor, glory

στεφανοω.definition: to crown; to crown as victor in the games,

στηκω.definition: to stand, Mk. 3:31; 11:25; met. to stand when under judgment, to be approved, Rom. 14:4; to stand firm, be constant, persevere, 1 Cor. 16:13; Gal. 5:1; Phil. 1:27; 4:1; 1 Thess. 3:8; 2 Thess. 2:15*

στηριγμος.definition: pr. a fixing, settling; a state of firmness, fixedness; met. firmness of belief, settle frame of mind, 2 Pet. 3:17*

στηριζω.definition: to set fast; to set in a certain position or direction, Lk. 9:51; met. to render mentally steadfast, to settle, confirm, Lk. 22:32; Rom. 1:11; to stand immovable, Lk. 16:26; met. to be mentally settled, 2 Pet. 1:12

στιβας.definition: a stuffing of leaves, boughs, etc., meton. a bough, branch, Mk. 11:8*

στιγμη.definition: pr. a point; met. a point of time, moment, instant, Lk. 4:5*

στιλβω.definition: to shine, glisten, be radiant, Mk. 9:3*

στοα.definition: a colonnade, cloister, covered walk supported by columns, Jn. 5:2; 10:23; Acts 3:11; 5:12*

στοιχειον.definition: an element; an element of the natural universe, 2 Pet. 3:10, 12; an element or rudiment of any intellectual or religious system, Gal. 4:3, 9; Col. 2:8, 20; Heb. 5:12*

στοιχεω.definition: pr. to advance in a line; met. to frame one’s conduct by a certain rule, Acts 21:24; Rom. 4:12; Gal. 5:25; 6:16; Phil. 3:16*

στολη.definition: equipment; dress; a long garment, flowing robe, worn by priests, kings, and persons of distinction, Mt. 12:38; 16:5; Lk. 15:22; Rev. 6:11

στομα.definition: the mouth, Mt. 12:34; 15:11, 17, 18; 21:16; speech, words, Mt. 18:16; 2 Cor. 13:1; command of speech, facility of language, Lk. 21:15; from the Hebrew, ἀνοίγειν τὸ στόμα, to utter, to speak, Mt. 5:2, 13:35; also, used of the earth, to rend, yawn, Rev. 12:16; στόμα πρὸς στόμα λαλεῖν, to speak mouth to mouth, face to face, 2 Jn. 12; 3 Jn. 14; the edge or point of a weapon, Lk. 21:24; Heb. 11:34

στομαχος.definition: pr. the gullet leading to the stomach; hence, later, the stomach itself, 1 Tim. 5:23*

στρατεια.definition: a military expedition, campaign; and genr. military service, warfare; met. the Christian warfare, 2 Cor. 10:4; fight, 1 Tim. 1:18*

στρατευμα.definition: an army, Mt. 22:7; Rev. 19:14, 19; an armed force, corps, Acts 23:10, 27; troops, guards, Lk. 23:11; Rev. 9:16*

στρατηγος.definition: a leader or commander of an army, general; a Roman praetor, provincial magistrate, Acts 16:20, 22, 35, 36, 38; στρατηγός τοῦ ἱεροῦ, the captain or prefect of the temple, the chief of the Levites who kept guard in and around the temple, Lk. 22:4, 52; Acts 4:1; 5:24, 26*

στρατια.definition: an army, host; from the Hebrew, στρατιὰ οὐράνιος, or τοῦ οὐρανοῦ, the heavenly host, the host of heaven, the hosts of angels, Lk. 2:13; the stars, Acts 7:42*

στρατιωτης.definition: a soldier, Mt. 8:9; 27:27; met. a soldier of Christ, 2 Tim. 2:3

στρατολογεω.definition: to collect or gather an army, enlist troops, 2 Tim. 2:4*

στρατοπεδον.definition: pr. the site of an encampment; an encampment; meton. an army, Lk. 21:20*

στρεβλοω.definition: pr. to distort the limbs on a rack; met. to wrench, distort, pervert, 2 Pet. 3:16*

στρεφω.definition: to twist; to turn, Mt. 5:39; to make a change of substance, to change, Rev. 11:6; absol. to change or turn one’s course of dealing, Acts 7:42; mid. to turn one’s self about, Mt. 16:23; Lk. 7:9; to turn back, Acts 7:39; to change one’s direction, to turn elsewhere, Acts 13:46; to change one’s course of principle and conduct, to be converted, Mt. 18:3

στρηνιαω.definition: to be wanton, to revel, riot, Rev. 18:7, 9*

στρουθιον.definition: any small bird, spc. a sparrow, Mt. 10:29, 31; Lk. 12:6, 7*

στρωννυω.definition: the thematic form of στρώννυμι, the μι form never being visible in the NT, to spread, to strew, Mt. 21:8; Mk. 11:8; to spread a couch, make your own bed, Acts 9:34; used of a supper-chamber, pass. to have the couches spread, to be prepared, furnished, Mk. 14:15; Lk. 22:12*

στυγναζω.definition: to put on a gloomy and downcast look, to be shocked, appalled, Mk. 10:22; of the sky, to lower, Mt. 16:3*

στυλος.definition: a pillar, column, Rev. 10:1; used of persons of authority, influence, etc., a support or pillar of the Church, Gal. 2:9; Rev. 3:12; a support of true doctrine, 1 Tim. 3:15*

g4671,.definition: you, gen., σοῦ, dat., σοί, acc., σέ, Mt. 1:20; 2:6

συγγενεια.definition: kindred; kinsfolk, kinsmen, relatives, Lk. 1:61; Acts 7:3, 14*

συγγενης.definition: kindred, akin; as a subst. a kinsman or kinswoman, relative; Mk. 6:4; Lk. 1:58; 2:44; 14:12; 21:16; Jn. 18:26; Acts 10:24; one nationally akin, a fellow countryman, Rom. 9:3; 16:7, 11, 21*

συγκαθημαι.definition: to sit in company with, Mk. 14:54; Acts 26:30*

συγκαθιζω.definition: trans. to cause to sit down with, seat in company with, Eph. 2:6; intrans. to sit in company with; to sit down together, Lk. 22:55*

συγκακοπαθεω.definition: to suffer evils along with someone; to be enduringly adherent, 2 Tim. 1:8; 2:3*

συγκακουχεομαι.definition: to encounter adversity along with any one, Heb. 11:25*

συγκαλεω.definition: to call together, Mk. 15:16; Lk. 15:6, 9; Acts 5:21; mid. to call around one’s self, Lk. 9:1; 23:13; Acts 10:24; 28:17*

συγκαλυπτω.definition: to cover completely, to cover up; met. to conceal, Lk. 12:2*

συγκαμπτω.definition: to bend or bow together; to bow down the back of any one afflictively, Rom. 11:10*

συγκαταβαινω.definition: to go down with anyone, Acts 25:5*

συγκαταθεσις.definition: assent; in NT accord, alliance, agreement, 2 Cor. 6:16*

συγκατατιθημι.definition: to set down together with; mid. to agree, accord, Lk. 23:51*

συγκαταψηφιζομαι.definition: to count, number with, be chosen together with, Acts 1:26*

συγκεραννυμι.definition: pluperf., συνεκέκρατο (3 sg), to mix with, mingle together; to blend, 1 Cor. 12:24; pass. to be combined, united, Heb. 4:2*

συγκινεω.definition: to agitate, put in turmoil; to excite, Acts 6:12*

συγκλειω.definition: to shut up together, to hem in; to enclose, Lk. 5:6; met. to band under a sweeping sentence, Rom. 11:32; Gal. 3:22; pass. to be banded under a bar of disability, Gal. 3:23*

συγκληρονομος.definition: pr. a coheir, Rom. 8:17; a fellow participant, Eph. 3:6; Heb. 11:9; 1 Pet. 3:7*

συγκοινωνεω.definition: to be a joint partaker, participate with a person; in NT to mix one’s self up in a thing, to involve one’s self, be an accomplice in, Eph. 5:11; Rev. 18:4; to sympathize actively in, to relieve, Phil. 4:14*

συγκοινωνος.definition: one who partakes jointly; a coparticipant, Rom. 11:17; a copartner in service, fellow, 1 Cor. 9:23; Phil. 1:7; a sharer, 1 Cor. 9:23; Rev. 1:9*

συγκομιζω.definition: to prepare for burial, take charge of the funeral of any one, bury, Acts 8:2*

συγκρινω.definition: to combine, compound; to compare, to estimate by comparing with something else, or, to match, 2 Cor. 10:12 (2x); to explain, to illustrate, or, to suit, 1 Cor. 2:13*

συγκυπτω.definition: to bend or bow together; to be bowed together, bent over, Lk. 13:11*

συγκυρια.definition: concurrence, coincidence, chance, accident; κατὰ συγκρυίαν, by chance, accidentally, Lk. 10:31*

συγχαιρω.definition: to rejoice with any one, sympathize in joy, Lk. 1:58; 15:6, 9; Phil. 2:17, 18; met. 1 Cor. 12:26; to sympathize in the advancement of, congratulate, 1 Cor. 13:6*

συγχεω.definition: to pour together, mingle by pouring together; hence, to confound, perplex, amaze, Acts 2:6; to confound in dispute, Acts 9:22; to throw into confusion, fill with uproar, Acts 19:32; 21:27, 31*

συγχραομαι.definition: use in common; associate with, have dealings with, Jn. 4:9*

συγχυσις.definition: pr. a pouring together; hence, confusion, commotion, tumult, uproar, Acts 19:29*

συζαω.definition: to live with; to continue in life with someone, 2 Cor. 7:3; to coexist in life with another, Rom. 6:8; 2 Tim. 2:11*

συζευγνυμι.definition: to join together; trop. join together, unite, Mt. 19:6; Mk. 10:9*

συζητεω.definition: to seek, ask, or inquire with another; to deliberate, debate, Mk. 1:27; 9:10; Lk. 24:15; to hold discourse with, argue, reason, Mk. 8:11; 12:28; Lk. 22:23; Acts 6:9; 9:29; to question, dispute, quibble, Mk. 9:14, 16*

συζητητης.definition: a disputant, controversial reasoner, sophist, 1 Cor. 1:20*

συζυγος.definition: an associate, comrade, fellow laborer, or it could be the person’s name, Phil. 4:3*

συζωοποιεω.definition: to make alive together with another; to make a sharer in the quickening of another, Eph. 2:5; Col. 2:13*

συκαμινος.definition: a sycamore tree, mulberry tree, i.q. συκομοραία, q.v., Lk. 17:6*

συκομορεα.definition: the fig mulberry tree, sycamore fig, Lk. 19:4*

συκον.definition: a fig, a ripe fig, Mt. 7:16; Mk. 11:13; Lk. 6:44; Jas. 3:12*

συκοφαντεω.definition: to inform against; to accuse falsely; by impl. to wrong by false accusations; to extort money by false informations, Lk. 3:14; 19:8*

συλαγωγεω.definition: to carry off as a prey or booty; met. to make victims of fraud, Col. 2:8*

συλλαλεω.definition: to talk, converse, or discuss with, Mt. 17:3; Mk. 9:4; Lk. 4:36; 9:30; 22:4; Acts 25:12*

συλλαμβανω.definition: to catch; to seize, apprehend, Mt. 26:55; Acts 1:16; to catch, as prey, Lk. 5:9; to conceive, become pregnant, Lk. 1:24, 31, 36; 2:21; met. Jas. 1:15; mid. to help, aid, assist, Lk. 5:7; Phil. 4:3

συλλογιζομαι.definition: to reason together; to consider, deliberate, reason, Lk. 20:5*

συλλυπεω.definition: to be grieved together with; to be grieved, Mk. 3:5*

συμβαινω.definition: to step or come together; to happen, meet, fall out, Mk. 10:32; Lk. 24:14 ; Acts 3:10; 20:19; 21:35; 1 Cor. 10:11; 1 Pet. 4:12; 2 Pet. 2:22*

συμβαλλω.definition: pr. to throw together; absol. to meet and join, Acts 20:14; to meet in war, to encounter, engage with, Lk. 14:31; to encounter in discourse or dispute, Acts 17:18; to consult together, Acts 4:15; mid. to contribute, be of service to, to aid, Acts 18:27; συμβάλλειν ἐν τῇ καρδίᾳ, to revolve in mind, ponder upon, Lk. 2:19*

συμβασιλευω.definition: to reign with; met. to enjoy honor with, 1 Cor. 4:8; 2 Tim. 2:12*

συμβιβαζω.definition: pr. to cause to come together; to unite, knit together, Eph. 4:16; Col. 2:2, 19; to infer, conclude, Acts 16:10; by impl. to prove, demonstrate, Acts 9:22; in NT to teach, instruct, Acts 19:33; 1 Cor. 2:16*

συμβουλευω.definition: to counsel, advise, exhort, Jn. 18:14; Rev. 3:18; mid. to consult together, plot, Mt. 26:4; Acts 9:23*

συμβουλιον.definition: counsel, consultation, mutual consultation, Mt. 12:14; 22:15; 27:1, 7; 28:12; Mk. 3:6; Acts 27:1, 7; 28:12; a council of counsellors, Acts 25:12*

συμβουλος.definition: a counsellor; advisor, one who shares one’s counsel, Rom. 11:34*

συμεων.definition: Symeon, Simeon, pr. name. indecl. (1) Simeon, son of Juda, Lk. 3:30. (2) Simeon, son of Jacob, Rev. 7:7. (3) Simeon, a prophet of Jerusalem, Lk. 2:25, 34. (4) Simeon, or Simon Peter, Acts 15:14; 2 Pet. 1:1. (5) Simeon, called Niger, Acts 13:1*

συμμαρτυρεω.definition: to testify or bear witness together with another, confirm, add testimony, Rom. 2:15; 8:16; 9:1*

συμμεριζω.definition: to divide with another so as to receive a part to one’s self, share with, partake with, 1 Cor. 9:13*

συμμετοχος.definition: a partaker with any one, a joint partaker, Eph. 3:6; 5:7*

συμμιμητης.definition: an imitator together with any one, a joint imitator, Phil. 3:17*

συμμορφιζω.definition: to conform to, take on the same form as, Phil. 3:10*

συμμορφος.definition: of like form, assimilated, conformed, similar in form, Rom. 8:29; Phil. 3:21*

συμπαθεω.definition: to sympathize with, Heb. 4:15; to be compassionate, Heb. 10:34*

συμπαραγινομαι.definition: to be present together with; to come together, convene, Lk. 23:48*

συμπαρακαλεω.definition: to invite, exhort along with others; pass. to share in mutual encouragement, Rom. 1:12*

συμπαραλαμβανω.definition: to take along with, take as a companion, Acts 12:25; 15:37, 38; Gal. 2:1*

συμπαρειμι.definition: to be present with any one, Acts 25:24*

συμπασχω.definition: to suffer with, sympathize, 1 Cor. 12:26; to suffer as another, endure corresponding sufferings, Rom. 8:17*

συμπεμπω.definition: to send with any one, 2 Cor. 8:18, 22*

συμπεριλαμβανω.definition: to embrace together; to embrace, Acts 20:10*

συμπινω.definition: to drink with any one, Acts 10:41*

συμπληροω.definition: to fill, fill up, Lk. 8:23; pass., of time, to be completed, have fully come, Lk. 9:51; Acts 2:1*

συμπνιγω.definition: to throttle, choke; trop. to choke the growth or increase of seed or plants, Mt. 13:22; Mk. 4:7, 19; Lk. 8:14; to press upon, crowd, Lk. 8:42*

συμπορευομαι.definition: to go with, accompany, Lk. 7:11; 14:25; 24:15; to come together, assemble, Mk. 10:1*

συμποσιον.definition: a drinking together; a feast, banquet; a festive company; in NT, pl. συμπόσια, eating party, Mk. 6:39 (2x)*

συμπρεσβυτερος.definition: a fellow elder, fellow presbyter, 1 Pet. 5:1*

συμφερω.definition: to bring together, collect, Acts 19:19; absol. be for the benefit of any one, be profitable, advantageous, expedient, 1 Cor. 6:12; to suit best, be appropriate, 2 Cor. 8:10; good, benefit, profit, advantage, Acts 20:20; 1 Cor. 7:35; it is profitable, advantageous, expedient, Mt. 5:29, 30; 19:10

συμφυλετης.definition: pr. one of the same tribe; a fellow citizen, fellow countryman, 1 Thess. 2:14*

συμφυτος.definition: pr. planted together, grown together; in NT met. grown together, closely entwined or united with, Rom. 6:5*

συμφυω.definition: to make to grow together; pass. to grow or spring up with, Lk. 8:7*

συμφωνεω.definition: to sound together, to be in unison, be in accord; trop. to agree with, accord with in purport, Acts 15:15; to harmonize with, suit with, Lk. 5:36; to agree with, make an agreement, Mt. 18:19; 20:2, 13; Acts 5:9*

συμφωνια.definition: symphony, harmony of sounds, concert of instruments, music, Lk. 15:25*

συμφωνος.definition: agreeing in sound; met. harmonious, agreeing, accord, agreement, 1 Cor. 7:5*

συμψηφιζω.definition: to calculate together, compute, reckon up, Acts 19:19*

συμψυχος.definition: united in mind, at unity, Phil. 2:2

συν.definition: with, together with, Mt. 25:27; 26:35; 27:38; attendant on, 1 Cor. 15:10; besides, Lk. 24:21; with, with the assistance of, 1 Cor. 5:4; with, in the same manner as, Gal. 3:9; εἶναι σύν τινι, to be with any one, to be in company with, accompany, Lk. 2:13; 8:38; to be on the side of, be a partisan of any one, Acts 4:13; 14:4; οἱ σύν τινι, those with any one, the companions of any one, Mk. 2:26; Acts 22:9; the colleagues, associates of any one, Acts 5:17, 21

συναγω.definition: to bring together, collect, gather, as grain, fruits, etc., Mt. 3:12 6:26; 13:30, 47; to collect an assembly; pass. to convene, come together, meet, Mt. 2:4; 13:2; 18:20; 22:10; in NT to receive with kindness and hospitality, to entertain, Mt. 25:35, 38, 43

συναγωγη.definition: a collecting, gathering; a Christian assembly or congregation, Jas. 2:2; the congregation of a synagogue, Acts 9:2; hence, the place itself, a synagogue, Lk. 7:5

συναγωνιζομαι.definition: to combat in company with any one; to exert one’s strength with, to be earnest in aiding, help, Rom. 15:30*

συναθλεω.definition: pr. to fight or work on the side of any one; in NT to cooperate vigorously with a person, Phil. 4:3; to make effort in the cause of, in support of a thing, Phil. 1:27*

συναθροιζω.definition: to gather; to bring together, Acts 19:25; pass. to come together, convene, Acts 12:12*

συναιρω.definition: to take up a thing with any one; in NT συναίρειν λόγον, to settle accounts, reckon in order to payment, Mt. 18:23, 24; 25:19*

συναιχμαλωτος.definition: a fellow captive, Rom. 16:7; Col. 4:10; Phlm. 23*

συνακολουθεω.definition: to follow in company with, accompany, Mk. 5:37; 14:51; Lk. 23:49*

συναλιζω.definition: to cause to come together, collect, assemble, congregate; mid. to convene to one’s self, Acts 1:4*

συναλλασσω.definition: to negotiate or bargain with someone; to reconcile, Acts 7:26*

συναναβαινω.definition: to go up, ascend with someone, Mk. 15:41; Acts 13:31*

συνανακειμαι.definition: to recline with someone at table, Mt. 9:10; 14:9; Mk. 2:15; 6:22; Lk. 7:49; 14:10, 15*

συναναπαυομαι.definition: to experience refreshment or rest in company with someone, Rom. 15:32*

συνανταω.definition: to meet with, fall in with, encounter, Lk. 9:37; 22:10; Acts 10:25; Heb. 7:1, 10; to occur, happen to, befall, Acts 20:22*

συναντιλαμβανομαι.definition: pr. to take hold of with someone; to support, help, aid, Lk. 10:40; Rom. 8:26*

συναπαγω.definition: to lead or carry away with; to seduce; pass. to be led away

συναποθνησκω.definition: to die together with any one, Mk. 14:31; 2 Cor. 7:3; met. to die with, in respect of a spiritual likeness, 2 Tim. 2:11*

συναπολλυμι.definition: to destroy together with others; mid. to perish or be destroyed with others, Heb. 11:31*

συναποστελλω.definition: to send forth together with someone, 2 Cor. 12:18*

συναρμολογεω.definition: to join together fitly, fit or frame together, compact, Eph. 2:21; 4:16*

συναρπαζω.definition: pluperf., συνηρπάκειν, to snatch up, clutch; to seize and carry off suddenly, Acts 6:12; to seize with force and violence, Lk. 8:29; Acts 19:29; pass. of a ship, to be caught and swept on by the wind, Acts 27:15*

συναυξανω.definition: pass., to grow together in company, Mt. 13:30*

συνδεσμος.definition: that which binds together, Col. 2:19; a band of union, Eph. 4:3; Col. 3:14; a bundle, or, bond, Acts 8:23*

συνδεω.definition: to bind together; in NT pass. to be in bonds together, Heb. 13:3*

συνδοξαζω.definition: in NT to glorify together with, to exalt to a state of dignity and happiness in company with, to make to partake in the glorification of another, Rom. 8:17*

συνδουλος.definition: a fellow-slave, fellow-servant, Mt. 24:49; 18:28f., 31, 33; Col. 4:7; Rev. 6:11; 19:10; 22:9; a fellow-minister of Christ, Col. 1:7*

συνδρομη.definition: a running together, forming a mob, Acts 21:30*

συνεγειρω.definition: to raise up with any one; to raise up with Christ by spiritual resemblance of His resurrection, Eph. 2:6; Col. 2:12; 3:1*

συνεδριον.definition: pr. a sitting together, assembly, etc., in NT the Sanhedrin, the supreme council of the Jewish nation, Mt. 5:22; 26:59; meton. the Sanhedrin, as including the members and place of meeting, Lk. 22:66; Acts 4:15; genr. a judicial council, tribunal, Mt. 10:17; Mk. 13:9

συνειδησις.definition: consciousness, Heb. 10:2; a present idea, persisting notion, impression of reality, 1 Pet. 2:19; conscience, as an inward moral impression of one’s actions and principles, Acts 23:1; 24:16; Rom. 9:1; 2 Cor. 1:12; conscience, as the inward faculty of moral judgment, Rom. 2:15; 13:5; 1 Cor. 8:7b, 10, 12; 10:25, 27, 28, 29; 2 Cor. 4:2; 5:11; 1 Tim. 1:5, 19; 3:9; 4:2; 2 Tim. 1:3; conscience, as the inward moral and spiritual frame, Tit. 1:15; Heb. 9:9, 14; 10:22; 13:18; 1 Pet. 3:16, 21*

συνειμι.definition: from εἶμι, to come together, Lk. 8:4*

συνεισερχομαι.definition: to enter with someone, Jn. 18:15; to embark with, Jn. 6:22*

συνεκδημος.definition: one who accompanies another to foreign countries, fellow traveller, Acts 19:29; 2 Cor. 8:19*

συνεκλεκτος.definition: chosen along with others; elected to Gospel privileges along with, 1 Pet. 5:13*

συνεπιμαρτυρεω.definition: to join in according testimony; to support by testimony, to confirm, sanction, Heb. 2:4*

συνεπιτιθημι.definition: can also be spelled συνεπιτίθεμαι, mid., to set upon along with, join with others in an attack; to unite in impeaching, Acts 24:9*

συνεπομαι.definition: to follow with, attend, accompany, Acts 20:4*

συνεργεω.definition: to work together with, to cooperate, etc., 1 Cor. 16:16; 2 Cor. 6:1; to assist, afford aid to, Mk. 16:20; Jas. 2:22; absol. to conspire actively to a result, Rom. 8:28*

συνεργος.definition: a fellow laborer, associate, helper, Rom. 16:3, 9, 21; 2 Cor. 1:24

συνερχομαι.definition: pluperf., συνεληλύθεισαν (3 pl), to come together; to assemble, Mk. 3:20; 6:33; 14:53; to cohabit matrimonially, Mt. 1:18; 1 Cor. 7:5; to go or come with any one, to accompany, Lk. 23:55; Acts 9:39; to company with, associate with, Acts 1:21

συνεσθιω.definition: to eat with, Acts 10:41; 11:3; 1 Cor. 5:11; by impl. to associate with, live on familiar terms with, Lk. 15:2; Gal. 2:12*

συνεσις.definition: pr. a sending together, a junction, as of streams; met. understanding, intelligence, discernment, Lk. 2:47; 1 Cor. 1:19; meton. the understanding, intellect, mind, Mk. 12:33; Eph. 3:4; Col. 1:9; 2:2; 2 Tim. 2:7*

συνετος.definition: intelligent, discerning, wise, prudent, Mt. 11:25; Lk. 10:21; Acts 13:7; 1 Cor. 1:19*

συνευδοκεω.definition: to approve with another; to agree with in principle, Rom. 1:32; to stamp approval, Lk. 11:48; Acts 8:1; 22:20; to be willing, agreeable, 1 Cor. 7:12, 13*

συνευωχεομαι.definition: to feast together with, 2 Pet. 2:13; Jude 12*

συνεφιστημι.definition: to set together upon, join in an attack, Acts 16:22*

συνεχω.definition: pr. to hold together; to confine, shut up, close; τὰ ὦτα, to stop the ears, Acts 7:57; to confine, as a besieged city, Lk. 19:43; to hold, hold fast, have the custody of any one, Lk. 22:63; to hem in, urge, press upon, Lk. 8:45; to exercise a constraining influence on, 2 Cor. 5:14; pass. to be seized with, be affected with, as fear, disease, etc., Mt. 4:24; Lk. 4:38; 8:37; Acts 28:8; to be in a state of mental constriction, to be hard pressed by urgency of circumstances, Lk. 12:50; Acts 18:5; Phil. 1:23*

συνηδομαι.definition: to be pleased along with others; to congratulate; to delight in, approve cordially, Rom. 7:22*

συνηθεια.definition: use, custom; an established custom, practice, Jn. 18:39; 1 Cor. 8:7; 11:16*

συνηλικιωτης.definition: one of the same age, an equal in age, Gal. 1:14*

συνθαπτω.definition: to bury with; pass. in NT to be buried with Christ symbolically, Rom. 6:4; Col. 2:12*

συνθλαω.definition: to crush together; to break in pieces, shatter, Mt. 21:44; Lk. 20:18*

συνθλιβω.definition: to press together; to press upon, crowd, Mk. 5:24, 31*

συνθρυπτω.definition: to crush to pieces; met. to break the heart of any one, to make to recoil in fear, Acts 21:13*

συνιημι.definition: also συνίω, see BDAG 972 for a discussion, pr. to send together; met. to understand, comprehend thoroughly, Mt. 13:51; Lk. 2:50; 18:34; 24:45; to perceive clearly, Mt. 16:12; 17:13; Acts 7:25; Rom. 15:21; Eph. 5:17; absol. to be well judging, sensible, 2 Cor. 10:12; to be spiritually intelligent, Mt. 13:13, 14, 15; Acts 28:26, 27; to be religiously wise, Rom. 3:11

συνιστημι.definition: also spelled συνιστάνω and συνιστάω, to place together; to recommend to favorable attention, Rom. 16:1; 2 Cor. 3:1; 10:18; to place in a striking point of view, Rom. 3:5; 5:8; Gal. 2:18; to stand beside, Lk. 9:32; to have been permanently framed, Col. 1:17; to possess consistence, 2 Pet. 3:5

συνοδευω.definition: to journey or travel with, accompany on a journey, Acts 9:7*

συνοδια.definition: pr. a journeying together; meton. a company of fellow travellers, caravan, Lk. 2:44*

συνοιδα.definition: a defective verb that is actually perfect in form but present in meaning, to share in the knowledge of a thing; to be privy to, Acts 5:2; to be conscious; οὐδέν σύνοιδα, to have a clear conscience, 1 Cor. 4:4*

συνοικεω.definition: to dwell with; to live or cohabit with, 1 Pet. 3:7*

συνοικοδομεω.definition: to build in company with someone; pass. to be built up, form a constituent part of a structure, Eph. 2:22*

συνομιλεω.definition: pr. to be in company with; to talk or converse with, Acts 10:27*

συνομορεω.definition: to be next to, be next door, Acts 18:7*

συνοραω.definition: perceive, become aware of, realize, Acts 12:12; 14:6*

συνοχη.definition: pr. a being held together; compression; in NT met. distress of mind, anxiety, Lk. 21:25; 2 Cor. 2:4

συντασσω.definition: pr. to arrange or place in order together; in NT to order, charge, direct, Mt. 21:6, 26:19; 27:10*

συντελεια.definition: a complete combination, a completion, consummation, end, Mt. 13:39, 40, 49; 24:3; 28:20; Heb. 9:26*

συντελεω.definition: pr. to bring to an end altogether; to finish, end, Lk. 4:13; to consummate, Rom. 9:28; to ratify a covenant, Heb. 8:8; pass. to be terminated, Lk. 4:2; Acts 21:27; to be fully realized, Mk. 13:4*

συντεμνω.definition: pr. to cut short, contract by cutting off; met. to execute speedily, or from the Hebrew, to determine, decide, decree, Rom. 9:28 (2x)*

συντηρεω.definition: to keep safe and sound, Mt. 9:17; to observe strictly, or, to secure from harm, protect, Mk. 6:20; to preserve in memory, keep carefully in mind, Lk. 2:19*

συντιθημι.definition: to agree together, come to a mutual understanding, Jn. 9:22; Acts 23:20; to bargain, to pledge one’s self, Lk. 22:5*

συντρεχω.definition: to run together, flock together, Mk. 6:33; Acts 3:11; to run in company with others, met. 1 Pet. 4:4*

συντριβω.definition: to rub together; to shiver, Mk. 14:3; Rev. 2:27; to break, break in pieces, Mk. 5:4; Jn. 19:36; to break down, crush, bruise, Mt. 12:20; met. to break the power of any one, deprive of strength, debilitate, Lk. 9:39; Rom. 16:20*

συντριμμα.definition: a breaking, bruising; in NT destruction, ruin, Rom. 3:16*

συντροφος.definition: nursed with another; one brought up (NIV) or educated with another, intimate friend, friend of the court (RSV) Acts 13:1*

συντυγχανω.definition: to meet or fall in with; join, in NT to get to, approach, Lk. 8:19*

συνυποκρινομαι.definition: to dissemble, feign with, or in the same manner as another, join in the playing of the hypocrite, Gal. 2:13*

συνυπουργεω.definition: to aid along with another, help together, 2 Cor. 1:11*

συνωδινω.definition: pr. to travail at the same time with; trop. suffer together, Rom. 8:22*

συνωμοσια.definition: a banding by oath; a combination, conspiracy, Acts 23:13*

συρακουσαι.definition: Syracuse, a celebrated city of Sicily, Acts 28:12*

συρια.definition: Syria, an extensive country of Asia, Mt. 4:24; Lk. 2:2; Acts 15:23

συροφοινικισσα.definition: a Syrophoenician woman, Phoenicia being included in Syria, Mk. 7:26*

συρτις.definition: a shoal, sand-bank, a place dangerous on account of shoals, two of which were particularly famous on the northern coast of Africa, one lying near Carthage, and the other, the syrtis major, lying between Cyrene and Leptis, which is probably referred to in Acts 27:17*

συρω.definition: to draw, drag, Jn. 21:8; Rev. 12:4; to force away, hale before magistrates, etc., Acts 8:3; 14:19; 17:6*

συσπαρασσω.definition: to tear to pieces; to convulse altogether, Mk. 9:20; Lk. 9:42*

συσσωμος.definition: united in the same body; met. pl. joint members in a spiritual body, Eph. 3:6*

συσταυροω.definition: to crucify with another, Mt. 27:44; Mk. 15:32; Jn. 19:32; pass. met. to be crucified with another in a spiritual resemblance, Rom. 6:6; Gal. 2:20*

συστελλω.definition: to draw together, contract, straiten; to enwrap; hence, i.q. περιστέλλω, to lay out, prepare for burial, Acts 5:6; pass. to be shortened, 1 Cor. 7:29*

συστεναζω.definition: to groan or lament together, Rom. 8:22*

συστοιχεω.definition: pr. to be in the same row with; met. to correspond to, Gal. 4:25*

συστρατιωτης.definition: a fellow soldier, co-militant, in the service of Christ, Phil. 2:25; Phlm. 2*

συστρεφω.definition: to turn or roll together; to collect, gather, Acts 28:3; Mt. 17:22*

συστροφη.definition: a gathering, tumultuous assembly, Acts 19:40; a combination, conspiracy, Acts 23:12*

συσχηματιζω.definition: to fashion in accordance with; mid/pass. to conform or assimilate one’s self to, met. Rom. 12:2; 1 Pet. 1:14*

συχαρ.definition: Sychar, indecl., a city of Samaria, Jn. 4:5*

συχεμ.definition: Shechem, indecl., fem., a city of Samaria, Acts 7:16*. See PhotoGuide.

σφαγιον.definition: a victim slaughtered in sacrifice, offering, Acts 7:42*

σφαζω.definition: also spelled σφάττω, to slaughter, kill, slay; pr. used of animals killed in sacrifice, etc., Rev. 5:6, 9, 12; 13:8; of persons, etc., 1 Jn. 3:12; Rev. 6:4, 9; 18:24; to wound mortally, Rev. 13:3*

σφοδρα.definition: much, greatly, exceedingly, Mt. 2:10; 17:6; Mk. 16:4; Lk. 18:23; Acts 6:7

σφραγιζω.definition: to seal, stamp with a seal, Mt. 27:66; Rev. 20:3; to seal up, to close up, conceal, Rev. 10:4; 22:10; to set a mark upon, distinguish by a mark, Eph. 1:13; 4:30; Rev. 7:3, 4, 5, 8; to seal, to mark distinctively as invested with a certain character, Jn. 6:27; mid. to set one’s own mark upon, seal as one’s own, to impress with a mark of acceptance, 2 Cor. 1:22; to deliver over safely to someone, Rom. 15:28; absol. to set to one’s seal, to make a solemn declaration, Jn. 3:33*

σφραγις.definition: a seal, a signet ring, Rev. 7:2; an inscription on a seal, motto, 2 Tim. 2:19; a seal, the impression of a seal, Rev. 5:1, 2, 5, 9, 6:1, 3, 5, 7, 9, 12; 8:1; a seal, a distinctive mark, Rev. 9:4; a seal, a token, proof, 1 Cor. 9:2; a token of guarantee, Rom. 4:11*

σχεδον.definition: pr. near, of place; hence, nearly, almost, Acts 13:44; 19:26; Heb. 9:22*

σχημα.definition: fashion, form; fashion, external show, 1 Cor. 7:31; Phil. 2:7*

σχιζω.definition: to split, Mt. 27:51; Mk. 15:38; to rend, tear asunder, Mt. 27:51; Lk. 5:36; 23:45; Jn. 19:24; 21:11); mid. to open or unfold with a chasm, Mk. 1:10; pass. met. to be divided into parties or factions, Acts 14:4; 23:7*

σχισμα.definition: a split, Mt. 9:16; Mk. 2:21; met. a division into parties, schism, Jn. 7:43; 9:16; 10:19; 1 Cor. 1:10; 11:18; 12:25*

σχοινιον.definition: pr. a cord made of rushes; genr. a rope, cord, Jn. 2:15; Acts 27:32*

σχολαζω.definition: to be unemployed, to be at leisure; to be at leisure for a thing, to devote one’s self entirely to a thing, 1 Cor. 7:5; to be unoccupied, empty, Mt. 12:44*

σχολη.definition: freedom from occupation; later, ease, leisure; a school, Acts 19:9*

σωζω.definition: to save, rescue; to preserve safe and unharmed, Mark. 8:25; 10:22; 24:22; 27:40, 42, 49; 1 Tim. 2:15; σῴζειν εἰς, to bring safely to, 2 Tim. 4:18; to cure, heal, restore to health, Mt. 9:21, 22; Mk. 5:23, 28, 34; 6:56; to save, preserve from being lost, Mt. 16:25; Mk. 3:4; 8:35; σῴζειν ἀπό, to deliver from, set free from, Mt. 1:21; Jn. 12:27; Acts 2:40; in NT to rescue from unbelief, convert, Rom. 11:14; 1 Cor. 1:21; 7:16; to bring within the pale of saving privilege, Tit. 3:5; 1 Pet. 3:21; to save from final ruin, 1 Tim. 1:15; pass. to be brought within the pale of saving privilege, Acts 2:47; Eph. 2:5, 8; to be in the way of salvation, 1 Cor. 15:2; 2 Cor. 2:15

σωμα.definition: the body of an animal; a living body, Mt. 5:29, 30; 6:22, 23, 25; Jas. 3:3; a person, individual, 1 Cor. 6:16; a dead body; corpse, carcass, Mt. 14:12; 27:52, 58; Heb. 13:11; the human body considered as the seat and occasion of moral imperfection, as inducing to sin through its appetites and passions, Rom. 7:24; 8:13; genr. a body, a material substance, 1 Cor. 15:37, 38, 40; the substance, reality, as opposed to ἡ σκιά, Col. 2:17; in NT met., the aggregate body of believers, the body of the Church, Rom. 12:5; Col. 1:18

σωματικος.definition: bodily, of or belonging to the body, 1 Tim. 4:8; corporeal, material, Lk. 3:22*

σωματικως.definition: bodily, in a bodily frame, Col. 2:9*

σωρευω.definition: to heap or pile up, Rom. 12:20; met. pass. to be filled with sins, 2 Tim. 3:6*

σωτηρ.definition: a savior, preserver, deliverer, Lk. 1:47; 2:11; Acts 5:31

σωτηρια.definition: a saving, preservation, Acts 27:34; Heb. 11:7; deliverance, Lk. 1:69, 71; Acts 7:25; salvation, spiritual and eternal, Lk. 1:77; 19:9; Acts 4:12; Rev. 7:10; a being placed in a condition of salvation by an embracing of the Gospel, Rom. 10:1, 10; 2 Tim. 3:15; means or opportunity of salvation, Acts 13:26; Rom. 11:11; Heb. 2:3; ἡ σωτηρία, the promised deliverance by the Messiah, Jn. 4:22

σωτηριος.definition: imparting salvation, saving, Lk. 2:30; 3:6; Acts 28:28; Eph. 6:17; Tit. 2:11*

σωφρονεω.definition: to be of a sound mind, be in one’s right mind, be sane, Mk. 5:15; Lk. 8:35; to be calm, 2 Cor. 5:13; to be sober-minded, sedate, Tit. 2:6; 1 Pet. 4:7; to be of a modest, humble mind, Rom. 12:3*

σωφρονιζω.definition: encourage, to restore to a right mind; to make sober-minded, to steady by exhortation and guidance, Tit. 2:4*

σωφρονως.definition: in the manner of a person in his right mind; soberly, temperately, Tit. 2:12*

σωφροσυνη.definition: sanity, soundness of mind, a sane mind, Acts 26:25; female modesty, 1 Tim. 2:9, 15*

σωφρων.definition: of a sound mind, sane; temperate, discreet, 1 Tim. 3:2; Tit. 1:8; 2:2; modest, chaste, Tit. 2:5*

ταβερναι.definition: taverns, used in the NT only in the transliterated Latin name of “Three Taverns” (Τριῶν ταβερνῶν), see G5553, Acts 28:15*

ταγμα.definition: pr. anything placed in order; in NT order of succession, class, group, 1 Cor. 15:23*

τακτος.definition: pr. arranged; fixed, appointed, set, Acts 12:21*

ταλαιπωρεω.definition: to endure severe labor and hardship; to be harassed; complain, Jas. 4:9*

ταλαιπωρια.definition: toil, difficulty, hardship; calamity, misery, distress, Rom. 3:16; Jas. 5:1*

ταλαιπωρος.definition: pr. enduring severe effort and hardship; hence, wretched, miserable, afflicted, Rom. 7:24; Rev. 3:17*

ταλαντιαιος.definition: of a talent weight, weighing a talent, Rev. 16:21*

ταλαντον.definition: the scale of a balance; a talent, which as a weight was among the Jews equivalent to 3000 shekels, i.e., as usually estimated, 114 lbs. 15 dwts. Troy; while the Attic talent, on the usual estimate, was only equal to 56 lbs. 11 oz. Troy, Mt. 18:24; 25:15, 16, 20, 22, 24, 25, 28*

ταμειον.definition: a storehouse, granary, barn, Lk. 12:24; a chamber, closet, place of retirement and privacy, Mt. 6:6; 24:26; Lk. 12:3*

ταξις.definition: order, regular disposition, arrangement; order, series, succession, Lk. 1:8; an order, distinctive class, as of priests, Heb. 5:6, 10; 6:20; 7:11(2x), 17; order, good order, 1 Cor. 14:40; orderliness, well-regulated conduct, Col. 2:5*

ταπεινος.definition: low in situation; of condition, humble, poor, mean, depressed, Lk. 1:52; 2 Cor. 7:6; Jas. 1:9; met. of the mind, humble, lowly, modest, Mt. 11:29; Rom. 12:16; 2 Cor. 10:1; Jas. 4:6; 1 Pet. 5:5*

ταπεινοφροσυνη.definition: lowliness or humility of mind, modesty, Acts 20:19; Eph. 4:2; Phil. 2:3; Col. 2:18, 23; 3:12; 1 Pet. 5:5*

ταπεινοω.definition: to bring low, depress, level, Lk. 3:5; met. to humble, abase, Phil. 2:8; mid. to descend to, or live in, a humble condition, 2 Cor. 11:7; Phil. 4:12; to humble, depress the pride of, any one, Mt. 18:4; mid. to humble one’s self, exhibit humility and contrition, Jas. 4:10; 1 Pet. 5:6; to humble with respect to hopes and expectations, to depress with disappointment, Mt. 23:12; Lk. 14:11; 18:14; 2 Cor. 12:21*

ταπεινωσις.definition: depression; low estate, abject condition, Lk. 1:48; Acts 8:33; Phil. 3:21; Jas. 1:10*

ταρασσω.definition: to agitate, trouble, as water, Jn. 5:7; met. to agitate, trouble the mind; with fear, to terrify, put in consternation, Mt. 2:3; 14:26; with grief, etc., affect with grief, anxiety, etc., Jn. 12:27; 13:21; with doubt, etc., to unsettle, perplex, Acts 15:24; Gal. 1:7

ταραχος.definition: agitation, commotion; consternation, terror, Acts 12:18; excitement, tumult, public contention, Acts 19:23*

ταρσευς.definition: of, or a native of Ταρσός, Tarsus, the metropolis of Cilicia, Acts 9:11; 21:39*

ταρσος.definition: Tarsus, the chief city of Cilicia, and birth-place of the Apostle Paul, Acts 9:30; 11:25; 22:3*. See PhotoGuide.

ταρταροω.definition: to cast or thrust down to Tartarus or Gehenna, 2 Pet. 2:4*

τασσω.definition: to arrange; to set, appoint, in a certain station, Lk. 7:8; Rom. 13:1; to set, devote, to a pursuit, 1 Cor. 16:15; to dispose, frame, for an object, Acts 13:48; to arrange, appoint, place or time, Mt. 28:16; Acts 28:23; to allot, assign, Acts 22:10; to settle, decide, Acts 15:2*

ταφη.definition: burial, the act of burying, burial place, Mt. 27:7*

ταφος.definition: a sepulchre, grave, tomb, Mt. 23:27, 29; 27:61, 64, 66; 28:1; met. Rom. 3:13*

ταχα.definition: pr. quickly, soon; perhaps, possibly, Rom. 5:7; Phlm. 15*

g5032,.definition: adverb of ταχύς, quickly, speedily; soon, shortly, 1 Cor. 4:19; Gal. 1:6; hastily, Lk. 14:21; 16:6; with inconsiderate haste, 1 Tim. 5:22

ταχινος.definition: swift, speedy, 2 Pet. 2:1; near at hand, impending, 2 Pet. 1:14*

ταχος.definition: swiftness, speed, quickness; ἐν τάχει, with speed, quickly, speedily; soon, shortly, Lk. 18:8; Acts 25:4; hastily, immediately, Acts 12:7; 22:18; Rom. 16:20; 1 Tim. 3:14; Rev. 1:1; 22:6*

g5036.definition: swift, fleet, quick; met. ready, prompt, Jas. 1:19; Mt. 28:7f.; Mk. 9:39; Lk. 15:22; Jn. 11:29

τε.definition: enclitic, can function as a conj., serving either as a lightly-appending link, Acts 1:15; and, Acts 2:3; or as an inclusive prefix, Lk. 12:45; both, Lk. 24:20; Acts 26:16

τειχος.definition: a wall of a city, Acts 9:25; 2 Cor. 11:33; Heb. 11:30; Rev. 21:12, 14f., 17-19*

τεκμηριον.definition: a sign, indubitable token, clear proof, Acts 1:3*

τεκνιον.definition: a little child; τεκνία, an endearing appellation, my dear children, Jn. 13:33; 1 Jn. 2:1, 12, 28; 3:7, 18; 4:4; 5:21*

τεκνογονεω.definition: to bear children, to rear a family, 1 Tim. 5:14*

τεκνογονια.definition: the bearing of children, the rearing of a family, 1 Tim. 2:15*
